TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I seek your indulgence to raise a point of procedure. As you would know, during the presentation of the Budget on Tuesday night there was some disturbance in King's Hall. During and after that there seemed to have been a large number of police both within the precincts of this House and in places where they can only be with the approval of yourself and your colleague, the President of the Senate. I would ask you to advise the Parliament of the basis on which you now allow people access to King's Hall.

SPEECH.PARA: It would seem to us on this side of the House that there are two fundamental obligations in terms of the exercise of your authority: The first is that honourable members can undertake their responsibilities within the chamber; the other is the extent to which members of the public should have access both to be able to contact honourable members and also to see at any time those of us who are participating in the deliberations of the Parliament. If there have been changes in the number and frequency of visits of the police, I think that honourable members should be told about it. I understand that on occasions action has been taken by your predecessors to close off King's Hall. So that we should all know the basis on which action is taken by you and what access is given to police, perhaps at an appropriate time you could give a statement to this House on the way in which security arrangements are now being conducted. Some of my colleagues have expressed some concern that policemen, not only in uniform but also in plain clothes, are about this place. Because of the limitations of the exercise of their authority in this place I think honourable members would be interested to know the basis on which they are operating and the extent to which you intend to permit them to do so.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOUTH PACIFIC NUCLEAR FREE ZONE TREATY BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 20 August, on motion by Mr Hayden:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate was adjourned yesterday I was saying that the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty was basically a platitudinous treaty which covered many of the things already covered in the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons and that, indeed, when it was carefully examined the raison d'etre of this Treaty was really an attack on the French Government and its testing at Mururoa. I would like to emphasise that while I do not support the nuclear testing of the French Government at Mururoa-quite the contrary, I strongly deplore what it has been doing there-this Treaty creates very real problems for a number of our allies, particularly the United States of America and Great Britain, which were asked to sign the protocols of the Treaty. Forcing them-I suspect that will be the ultimate conclusion-to sign the protocols of this Treaty, will clearly generate some instability in our region because of the division and uncertainty which will then exist in the relationship between Britain, the United States and France. Instability in our region at a time when the region is changing substantially both economically and politically is the last thing we want. It is the last thing we want at a time when the Soviet Union is launching significant diplomatic initiatives in the region to gain a foothold and thereby create instability in a region which until now has been free of great power conflict.

SPEECH.PARA: The second objection I have to the Treaty is that it amounts to the thin end of the wedge in the concept of nuclear free zones. At this stage under the Treaty the United States of America, the British and others will be able to send their ships, whether nuclear powered, nuclear armed or not, into the region; they will be able to visit our ports and the ports of other countries that wish to invite them or harbour their vessels. But the moral implication of the Treaty is that these ships should no longer proceed in our waters. It is not a fact that the Treaty says they cannot; quite the contrary, but the moral implication is the way the Treaty should at least go in the longer term.

The United States and Britain have expressed concern about that aspect of the Treaty, but by contrast the Soviet Union has supported the Treaty for that very reason because, as it sees it, it will in the longer term keep the United States out of the region or minimise its role in the region. New Zealand has welcomed the Treaty. Mr Lange almost welcomed it too willingly when it was first drawn up by the Australian Government. Once more, that is indicative of the attitudes that are endemic in this Treaty. In other words, the Treaty is changing the intellectual debate in our region about the Western alliance and the balance of power in the region. The Opposition manifestly does not want to see that happen.

The Treaty is also based on the assumption of moral equivalence, which assumes that the United States is as amoral or immoral as is the Soviet Union. That may be acceptable to some Labor members, but my Party and the vast majority of Australians totally reject that doctrine. We regard the United States as one of the bastions of liberal democracy, a country that stands for all we in this country stand for in the world and a country that will guarantee our stability and security. To undermine that role which the doctrine of moral equivalence does in this region is to undermine our own security.

I support the Non-proliferation Treaty, I support anti-dumping measures, I support bans on testing, but I think that this legislation and this Treaty are an over-reaction to the French testing at Mururoa. These are matters for a balanced judgment. In this case the Australian Government and some other governments which have been forced against their wishes to sign this Treaty or will be forced to sign the protocols are making the wrong judgment. This Treaty is not in the longer term in the interests of the security of our nation or region.
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOUTH PACIFIC NUCLEAR FREE ZONE TREATY BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McHugh Ms J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty or the Treaty of Rarotonga is the reason for the introduction of the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty Bill. The Treaty has been criticised by some in that it does not go far enough. I remind those who offer that criticism that honourable members opposite in the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia actually oppose the introduction of the Bill at all. On the other hand, it is welcomed by many as a worthy first step and as a precedent. It is particularly welcomed by those of us who acknowledge another Australian Government initiative in international forums to convince the super-powers that many smaller nations are very wary indeed of so-called protection by nuclear weapons. It is a treaty that Australians can be proud of because with it we are joining the people of our region.

SPEECH.PARA: South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Bill

This Bill gives domestic legislative effect to certain of Australia's obligations under the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty and, as we have already said, it is supplemented by the amendments just passed by this House to the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Act 1981, relating to the dumping of radioactive waste, and the provisions of the yet to be introduced Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Safeguards) Bill 1986, relating to the application of safeguards to nuclear material which cover Treaty obligations referred to but not provided in this Bill. The Bill is quite specific in the application of this legislation. It makes it illegal to acquire, manufacture or carry out research and development relating to the manufacture or production of nuclear weapons. It prohibits the stationing and testing of nuclear weapons in Australia. The conditions of the Treaty require inspections in Australia by Treaty inspectors and this Bill establishes the legislative framework and provides the Australian Safeguards Office with powers to assist the Treaty inspector in carrying out those inspections. In this time of financial restraint this piece of legislation is not expected to have any financial impact on government spending at all.

The South Pacific nuclear free zone was an initiative of this Government but the Treaty itself represents a collective effort by the 13 member countries in the forum. Every member country of the forum contributed substantially to the development and drafting of the Treaty and it was endorsed by the 13 heads of government. As the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) said in his second reading speech:

At a time when the world has little to point to by way of progress on arms control and disarmament, this Treaty has been welcomed by the international community and widely recognised around the world as a significant measure.

He went on to say that the Treaty expressed a strong community of interest which members of the South Pacific Forum shared in environmental and security matters and reflected the deeply felt and long standing concern in the region about nuclear testing, the ocean dumping of nuclear waste and the horizontal proliferation of nuclear weapons. The honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) said that we showed negligence towards the Pacific region. On the contrary, it is our Government which is listening, responding to and joining our neighbours in the region. This Treaty did not come out of the blue. The South Pacific Forum was established in 1971. Since then the South Pacific islanders have expressed clearly their opposition to such things as the testing of nuclear weapons and have opposed just as vigorously the dumping of nuclear waste in their region.

The decision to test nuclear bombs and dump nuclear waste in the Pacific has been made by those who do not live in the places they choose for their explosions and their waste dumping. The nuclear atolls were the homelands for other people who hardly mattered and whose wishes could be disregarded-it appears by the Opposition in this place as well as by the super powers. The opinions of the other Pacific islanders were never taken seriously by the military authorities of all three testing powers in the Pacific-the United States, the United Kingdom and France. It is the islanders' long experience of this colonial attitude more than anything else that has united them in opposition on all things nuclear. How dare the Opposition refer to this as `a Mickey Mouse Treaty'. Honourable members should remember that none of the nations in the region has the military, industrial or economic muscle alone to be able to influence decisions made by the big powers and many of them are economically dependent on those very same powers.

The United States considers its military presence in the region as necessary to defend its political and economic interests. It has warned the Pacific islanders against a nuclear free Pacific saying to newly independent countries such as Vanuatu and Kiribati that if they exclude United States nuclear propelled or armed ships from their territories, the ability of its forces to respond to contingencies would be severely hampered. What was once a United States defensive posture has now become a forward offensive stance to keep a constant pressure on the sensitive Soviet naval military communication and nuclear facilities in the North West Pacific. Both the Soviet and the United States arms build up in the region is making the Pacific the most militarised and nuclearised ocean in the world. The Pacific islands are caught in a situation not of their making and not in their interests. In an atmosphere of increasing tension and uncertainty they need care and creativity in determining their real interests and how to achieve them. This Government is responding to those concerns. The South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty can form the basis for that achievement.

The shadow Minister for Foreign Affairs, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), said that this Treaty was a threat to ANZUS. On the contrary, as the Minister for Foreign Affairs has said, this Treaty does not seek to undermine the factors that have created and sustained the very favourable security environment that the South Pacific enjoys. It does not in any way conflict with Australia's defence arrangements, notably ANZUS. It does not run counter to our support for stable nuclear deterrence. It does not impede in any way our ability to co-operate militarily with our allies. That is true of this Bill. On the contrary, the Treaty seeks to build on those factors by, for example, the provisions against nuclear weapons which will help to ensure that the South Pacific, unlike other parts of the world, does not in the future become a theatre of nuclear confrontation.

What does the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty do and what does it fail to do? It prohibits the acquisition of nuclear weapons but Australia, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, Fiji, Tonga, Tuvalu, Western Samoa and Kiribati have all signed the Treaty on the Non-proliferation of Nuclear Weapons binding them not to have their own nuclear weapons, and Vanuatu declared itself nuclear-free in 1982. Article 3 of the Treaty also states what is already the case. Each country promises `not to manufacture or otherwise acquire, possess or have control over any nuclear explosive device by any means anywhere inside or outside the South Pacific nuclear free zone'. The honourable member for Mayo questioned why it was necessary to reiterate in this Treaty all those measures already agreed to. I ask: Why is it necessary to oppose it?

In my opinion, the most significant article in the Treaty is article 5 which bans the stationing of nuclear weapons-a provision which I believe goes beyond the non-proliferation Treaty. This ban closes off options for the super-powers, and not just the United States of America, in the future. Providing the South Pacific states adhere to the Treaty, nuclear weapons bases will not be allowed on their territory. There exists, however, a loophole in article 5 which gives de facto home porting to nuclear armed vessels. Nuclear weapons could be stationed more or less permanently in the harbours of Pacific countries, if not actually on their soil. Nothing in the Treaty will stop vessels from staying in port for considerable lengths of time. This loophole could be closed, however, if a definition were included of the word `stationing' so as to prevent this de facto home porting. As has been proposed by Vanuatu and Papua New Guinea, such a definition should include a time limit on the presence of nuclear weapons in ports.

Article 6 represents the original reason for recognising the need for the Treaty-that is, the testing of nuclear devices by the French. I am deeply concerned that our commitment to the spirit of the Treaty can be questioned if we sell uranium to France. There is no doubt that in contributing to France's nuclear power industry we cannot ignore the fact that that industry includes the production of nuclear weapons and that they are tested in the South Pacific.

Article 7 covers the other nuclear activity resented for so long by the Pacific islanders-that is, the dumping of radioactive waste at sea. The Opposition says that it too is against the dumping of radioactive waste at sea, yet it opposes this Treaty. Protocol 2, article 2, requires the five nuclear weapons powers-the United States of America, the Union of the Soviet Socialist Republics, the United Kingdom, France and China-to promise not to use or threaten to use any nuclear weapon against these South Pacific countries which have signed the Treaty.

The most significant advance made at the forum just concluded is securing agreement on the protocols for the nuclear weapons states. The success of the Treaty as it now stands will be in securing the signature of the five nuclear weapons states. The progress made in this direction is already most encouraging. The Union of the Soviet Socialist Republics and China have stated that they are favourably disposed to signing the protocols. France is still opposed and no definitive reply has yet been received from the United States or the United Kingdom. It does not sound like progress but, compared with the situation 12 months ago, progress has been significant indeed, and it is because of this Treaty.

Unfortunately, the Treaty in no way restricts the firing of nuclear weapons from the zone. A United States nuclear submarine could fire at the Soviet mainland from within the territorial waters of most island states without violating the Treaty, and this aspect is most disturbing. Given the deployment of the United States Trident submarine system in the Pacific, with its deadly accurate firepower, the instability of the area will grow more serious as more and more nuclear missiles are added to the Pacific arsenal and Soviet and American nuclear submarines traverse the region at will. To strengthen this part of the Treaty would require only the addition of an article to protocol 2 to include a ban on the use of nuclear weapons from the zone as well as against the zone.

The ultimate objective for the South Pacific must therefore be a comprehensive nuclear free zone in which true denuclearisation could take place. Such a situation would not only prohibit the activities laid down in the Treaty but also would prohibit many other nuclear activities such as the testing of missiles, the transit of nuclear weapons on ships and submarines within territorial waters, nuclear-powered vessel transit and port calls, nuclear weapons, transit on aircraft through territorial airspace, the maintenance of nuclear command, control and communications facilities, joint exercises with nuclear armed forces, the export and processing of nuclear fuels, the storage of nuclear waste and the disposal of such waste on land. As Greenpeace has said of the Treaty:

The South Pacific Nuclear Fee Zone Treaty is a valu- able first step along the road to comprehensive denuclearisation, and offers the world a precedent for other such treaties. It should be welcomed for these reasons.
It should not be opposed, as it has been by the Opposition, particularly as it is a precedent. Once the ratification of the Treaty has taken place, the task ahead is to work to strengthen it.

The most important change that should be made to the Treaty as soon as possible is the inclusion of a ban on missile testing. This could be achieved by adding a new protocol asking nuclear weapons states not to test nuclear missiles in the zone. For a long time the Pacific island states have been opposed to missile testing by China and the Soviet Union in the South Pacific, and I should like to remind the House that it was the Labor Government that decided not to offer support to the testing of the MX missile by the United States. This courageous and correct stand was clearly supported by the Australian people, and I am convinced that the Australian people will support us if we stand by our policy not to sell uranium to France. Australia is held in high regard by our Pacific neighbours. They look to us to use our influence on the super-powers in regard to the testing of nuclear bombs and nuclear missiles and the dumping at sea of radioactive waste. I regret, and I am sure that they will regret, the Australian Government's announcement to resume sales of uranium to France.

The Opposition belittled those of us who held this position within the Party. The honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) sneered at us for following the Party line and making flowery speeches because our bread and butter depended upon it. How dare the Liberals, in coalition with the extreme right-wing Nationals, talk about morality on this issue! How dare the Opposition, which supports Star Wars, the testing of MX missiles in this region and the United States in its policy here-I remind the Opposition that the United States is not very discriminatory about its friends and enemies when it comes to bread-and-butter issues such as trade-belittle our stand in this matter!

Nuclearism cannot be separated from colonialism in the Pacific region. As long as islands such as Tahiti, New Caledonia, Wallis and Futura are still colonised, the Pacific cannot become a truly nuclear-free and independent zone. The Labor Party and the Labor Government firmly believe that the principles of self-determination and independence should apply to non-self-governing Pacific territories. Our total support must be given to those Pacific neighbours who are still in the chains of the colonial powers. No nation can preach about democracy, freedom or justice when it also maintains colonialism. In a colonial situation there is no democracy and there is no freedom.

In accepting the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty, the countries of the South Pacific Forum have created an opportunity for themselves to make a major contribution to their own security and to world peace. We are setting a precedent and we are proud of so doing. We are part of that contribution and this Bill will make our contribution even more effective. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just had some evidence to back up my opening statement: Given that the agenda and rhetoric of our nation's peace efforts are almost entirely dominated by articulate and passionate advocates from the Left and utopian circles in the churches, it is a very risky business these days to criticise a piece of legislation such as the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty Bill which we are debating here today.

SPEECH.PARA: I would be failing in my duty to this Parliament, to my electorate and, indeed, to my own children, who will inherit the security environment which we are today involved in shaping, if I did not inform this House today that this Bill and the Treaty upon which it is based not only will not contribute to the prevention of nuclear war but also will, by the deceptive language and false assurances, significantly distract us from, and hamper us in, the real work of the diplomacy of peace and freedom in the South Pacific.

There are three significant threats to the stability and peace of the South Pacific region. The first arises from the struggles of Pacific nations to develop viable economic bases for their communities. Recently, for example, Stuart Inder of the Bulletin, commenting on the trip of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) to the region, identified trade, labour, finance and immigration as the bread and butter issues that most occupy the attention of the South Pacific nations.

The second threat arises from the evolution in the newly independent states of their own political systems and foreign policy. Quite simply, many of these states are facing internal debates and external pressures over, for example, whether they should align themselves with the West or with the Soviet bloc, or seek to play the dangerous game of playing the super-powers off against each other.

The third threat arises from a combination of these two vulnerabilities-the one economic, the other political, and is posed by the desire of the Soviet Union and its proxies, Cuba and Libya, to gain a foothold in a region which would significantly shift the balance of power in the Pacific and the globe.

One would have thought that the Foreign Minister, for whom I have a great deal of respect, having returned form the South Pacific in May, would have brought before us an integrated policy statement based on these economic, political and strategic threats to peace-a statement for this country to follow or a policy for fulfilling its responsibilities to the region and for pursuing its own national interests. He did not. Instead he brought before us this Bill, pursuant to the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty.

There are a number of ways we should interpret this Government's advocacy of the Treaty and this Bill. First, it satisfies the need, I believe, of some Labor politicians for that well-known inner glow and for the self perceptions of clean hands in a dirty world, and reflects their tendency to offer us mere moralisms and platitudes whenever they try to move beyond a statement of the problems of a nuclear world towards practical steps and solutions. Secondly, it mollifies the vocal critics from the Left and in some churches. In that sense, this Bill is a sign of philosophical and political exhaustion in the face of the continuing campaigns of the pacifists and neutralists. Thirdly, it represents the last resort of an inadequate statesman who, having failed to influence the underlying political and economic regional factors, now seeks satisfaction in the superficialities of a treaty which formalises moral and diplomatic platitudes.

This Bill reveals that the Minister still does not realise that any efforts to deal with weapons rather than the underlying political conflicts are misguided and futile. It reveals that the Government is not heeding the lessons of history. This Treaty and Bill are in the tradition of the Kellogg-Briand pact of 1928, which involves a declaration from all the major powers of the day of the renunciation of war. The authors of that pact believed that it `marked a new date in the history of mankind' and declared:
We have made peace at last.
The Minister appears to follow in the footsteps of Briand and Kellogg in placing faith in a vacuous declaration of principle.

The Minister must realise that this Treaty, like all others, contains an unwritten clause. Where a signatory perceives that substantial changes develop in its security conditions as they existed at the time the Treaty was signed, the obligations established are altered and allow unilateral withdrawal. In international relations and law, that fact is encapsulated in the Latin as `pacta surt servanda, rebus sic stantibus'-`treaties are to be observed, unless things change'. That is, in the last instance, for example-Vanuatu, mentioned by the honourable member for Phillip (Ms McHugh)-could offer bases to the Soviet fleet if it thought that it was in its security interests, notwithstanding its ratification of this Treaty.

The final reason why I must urge the House to oppose this Bill is that I believe that it is a concession to those who seek to subvert public acceptance of our alliance with the United States, our support for the West's diplomatic and political objectives in our region, our support for nuclear deterrence, and our active opposition to the Soviet Union, its proxies and its political system. Notwithstanding our feelings about the horrors of nuclear warfare, or the moral qualifications that we place on our acceptance of nuclear deterrence, we should never apologise for that acceptance, nor should we ever concede directly or, as in this Bill, indirectly, the moral equivalence myth, which has been mentioned by the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), which suggests that the United States is as great a threat to peace and freedom as the Soviet Union. Clearly, this Bill and the Treaty will strengthen the morally simplistic case and rhetoric of those who tell our young people that their peace is threatened by the presence of the United States Pacific fleet in our region and ports-a very sad state of affairs.
Leon Wieseltier, in a superb contribution on nuclear peace and nuclear war, has argued:

The struggle between democracy and totalitarianism did not end in 1945, because it is a struggle between different answers to some of the most important questions of human life. The nuclear danger has not robbed these questions of their urgency. What is necessary-
he warns us-
is to proceed with the historically urgent task of nuclear disarmament in a manner that will not have an effect upon the historically urgent task of resisting the Russians.
This Bill fails to address that balance between these two tasks in our region and would effectively undermine such a balance.

Australia has ratified the non-proliferation treaty and the London dumping convention, so there should be no doubt that we have already adequately addressed the concerns which appear to be priorities in the minds of those who might find the Treaty and this Bill attractive. In that regard, the Treaty and the Bill are superfluous.

But let me go further. I repeat that this Bill will not prevent nuclear war in our region because it does not address those factors which would provoke the use of the weapons systems which we all know are so destructive. Nor will the Soviet Union mellow in its attitudes to the geopolitical opportunities which are presenting themselves in our region, among others, because of this Bill. It will take the Bill as further evidence of the weakening of the moral and psychological preparedness of this country to uphold its own and the West's interests in the region.

Not enough has been given to preserving peace and strengthening stability and freedom in our region. Not enough thought has been given to the impact of the rhetorical concessions which this Bill involves to those articulate advocates of appeasement, neutralism and pacifism, on the Government's ability in the future to muster public support, especially among young people, for our support for the United States and nuclear deterrence. In that regard, this Bill reflects this Government's sorry record of one step forwards, and two steps backwards in the way it handles our alliance and the promotion of that alliance publicly.

I am sure I will be attacked publicly for what I have said in opposition to this Bill. Those who claim the sole rights to the title of peace activists in this country usually deal harshly with those who disagree with their line. My fear is that our nation is being mislead about the things that make for peace in our day and region. I believe that this Bill will further mislead it. I have a picture in my mind of Christ weeping over the impending destruction of Jerusalem. His contemporaries, he said, did not know the things that really made for peace. I must therefore oppose this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maher Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a contribution to the debate on the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty Bill. I commend the honourable member for Phillip (Ms McHugh), who has been a colleague of mine for some years. I believe nobody in our nation is more genuine and sincere in opposition to nuclear weapons, nuclear arms and uranium sales, and I thought her contribution today was masterly. I have been disappointed with some of the contributions made by my colleagues in the Opposition. If they see the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty as a moral and diplomatic platitude, that is disappointing. But all honourable members of Parliament and all Australians must have a commitment to disarmament, to reduction in the arms race and to the prevention of war and hostilities. I believe that if a nuclear war starts it could result in the destruction of the human race on this planet.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe in the theory of nuclear winter. I believe that, once one side starts using nuclear weapons, the human race as we know it can be in danger of extinction and nowhere in the globe will be safe. Even if this is only a small step, even if it is only a treaty, as the Opposition keeps saying, we should nevertheless give it our support and invest it with goodwill because it is something to hang on to and it is a start in our region. We live in the South Pacific, an important new part of the world, where many island states are emerging, many of them with very small populations, smaller that my own electorate in Sydney. Some of these nations have very limited finances and natural resources and they look to Australia as the richest nation in the region and a nation which can sometimes guide them.

We have all heard of the background to the Treaty. I wish to make a few preliminary remarks about nuclear matters. The first point is that many Australians have experienced a nuclear explosion. Literally thousands of Australians were prisoners of war in Japan in 1945. These people went through the trauma of nuclear bombs going off in their region where they were imprisoned, in camp or held in custody. A doctor in my electorate, Dr Ian Duncan, who is now retired, has examined many of those returned servicemen and found that they have a very high rate of medical illness compared with other returned servicemen of the same age. They have a lot of traumas, psychiatric problems and nervous conditions. There is almost a 50 per cent increase in all of these areas among such returned servicemen as distinct from the other groups of former prisoners of war who were not subject to a nuclear attack.

I want to put to bed one commonly held belief that the nuclear explosions in Japan ended the war. All historians of any standing refute the theory that it was the atomic bombs that ended the war. Is there a greater authority than Winston Churchill whom I could quote for the Opposition. He said that it was really not the dropping of the atomic bombs on Japan that ended the war. Churchill stated:
It would be a mistake to suppose that the fate of Japan was settled by the atomic bomb.

Other historians agree entirely. The American bombing of the Japanese cities forced the end of the war. It was about to happen. The atomic explosions may have precipitated it by only a day or two. The British historian Liddell Hart said:
The atomic bombs in August merely confirmed what most of the Japanese people, except for military fanatics, had already come to realise.

So the notion that atomic bombs win wars or stop wars is in my opinion wrong. But the Australian Government has agreed to peaceful uses for uranium. We are a signatory to the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons. Our uranium is sold for peaceful purposes around the world. Some nations-France, Belgium and other European countries-generate half of their electricity from nuclear reactors. The International Atomic Energy Agency closely supervises the use, the reprocessing and the disposal of nuclear waste. No other industry in the world is as closely checked and supervised as is the nuclear industry.

Nuclear power is cheap. It enables many countries to sell their products very competitively around the world because they can obtain cheap power. In Germany, the electrical unions almost encourage the use of up to 10 per cent nuclear power because they say it is a subsidy on the cost of generating electricity from coal. Also, in Europe there are enormous problems with acid rain. Basically for me the need is to preserve the fossil fuels around the world because of their use in making pharmaceuticals. They are not replaceable fossil fuels and they have other uses besides generating power.

Another argument in favour of nuclear power is that extracting coal to generate electricity is a very dangerous business. We know of the recent appalling accident in Queensland where 12 men were killed. In the Sydney Morning Herald of 17 July, there was a long catalogue of hundreds of people who have been killed in coal mine disasters in our nation over the course of time.

But these matters aside, the big argument against nuclear power and using uranium to generate electricity is the toxic waste-the danger of handling used and spent fuel. I believe people hold genuine fears that the uranium used for peaceful purposes will be used in warheads and be used in war. My inquiries have led me to believe that this fear is hard to sustain. There are such checks, counter-checks, investigations and an enormous web of inspectorates that any nation that is a signatory to the nuclear non-proliferation treaty really can be assured that its uranium will not find its way into warheads. If a nation wants to make plutonium, there are much simpler ways to make it than to try to extract plutonium from spent fuel in a nuclear reactor. There are more simple ways that plutonium can be manufactured.

The Treaty we are debating today is one of the treaties that follows on from a number of others around the world. As the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) said, the first treaty of great significance was the Treaty of Tlatelolco in South America in 1967, which followed the Antarctic Treaty in 1959 which made the Antarctic a nuclear free area-an area which should not be militarised. The South American Treaty preceded in 1967, the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons in 1968 and the Seabed Arms Control Treaty in 1971.

The Treaty we are debating today contains a number of important clauses. Firstly, it provides that no South Pacific country which becomes a party to the Treaty will develop, manufacture, acquire or receive from any others any nuclear explosive device. Australia has already renounced this right, as have most of the other nations which have signed the Treaty-the Cook Islands, Fiji, Kiribati, New Zealand, Niue, Tuvalu, Western Samoa and Papua New Guinea. The Treaty also provides that there should be no testing of nuclear explosive devices in the South Pacific; that there will be no stationing of nuclear explosive devices in the territories of the existing states; and that nuclear activity in the region, including the export of nuclear material, will be conducted under strict safeguards to ensure its exclusively peaceful and non-explosive use. Australia has already signed the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons and has pledged to ensure that our uranium which is sold to European countries or Japan is not used for other than peaceful, non-explosive use. The Treaty seeks to prevent the dumping of radioactive material at sea in the region. Other matters have been canvassed by my colleagues and I will not delay the House by raising them.

I am disappointed that the Opposition is not taking the opportunity to support this legislation. Our membership and support of the United States alliance is a cornerstone of the Australian Government's foreign policy. The United States has three bases in our nation which are joint facilities. To talk about moral pressure on the United States, as one member of the Opposition did, is absolute nonsense. No nuclear nation admits that its vessels are carrying nuclear weapons. There is no question that United States vessels cannot visit Australia. They can visit Australia at any time, as that is specifically provided for in the Treaty being debated in the House today. I commend the legislation to the House and I ask the Opposition to have another look at the whole proposal. It is not enough to use rhetoric and attack the Treaty because it talks about a nuclear free zone. The Liberal and National parties supported the nuclear non-Proliferation treaty when they were running this country. They agreed not to have nuclear weapons in our nation. They agreed not to have nuclear weapons stationed or manufactured here. Because of this, I feel there is a certain degree of hypocrisy in Opposition members saying that they oppose this Treaty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Lowe (Mr Maher) said that all people should give a commitment to peace and disarmament and that is certainly true; the Opposition is committed to peace in this nation and the world and it is committed to disarmament. The real question faced by the world, Australia and this Government is how to achieve that objective. That is what this debate is really all about. The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) stated in his second reading speech:

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the . . . Bill is to give effect to certain obligations that Australia has as a party to the Treaty on a South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone.

How long will it be and what number of governments will Australia have to have before we realise that many international agreements are more of a hindrance than a help to this nation? I fully applaud the efforts made by leaders of this and other nations to seek co-operation, harmony and goodwill, but it should not be at any price.

This legislation is one of many pieces of legislation which has its raison d'etre in the obligation to fulfil an international agreement, or an agreement with other nations around the world. Other pieces of legislation based in recent years on international covenants have caused anguish and anger to many Australians. I mention a couple of them: The World Heritage Properties Conservation Act and the Australian Bill of Rights Bill, both of which are based on interna- tional agreements. Too often agreements are entered into without the broad approval of the majority of State governments, let alone the Australian people, and too often they impose obligations on Australia that in hindsight run contrary to our best interests.

Forcing through legislation that has been developed in international committees often leads to government by remote control-and remote control outside this nation. People from the more distant parts of Australia find it hard enough accepting decisions made in Canberra, let alone Rarotonga. It would not be as hard to swallow if one could rationally accept that they were to our benefit. It is sad to say that so often they are not. No one in charge of all their powers of reason could say that this Bill, if passed, would maintain our security arrangements, let alone enhance them. How plausible is this Government which only six weeks ago reaffirmed its policy not to sell uranium and which, in the Budget only this week, said that it will sell uranium? The Government is all over the place on that issue. Overnight the yellowcake issue has become a hot potato. The same argument applies to foreign affairs and the Government's approach to peace and security. The Government is all over the place. Does the Government believe that the United States is our ally? Does it believe in the Western democracies, as the coalition does? What does the Government really believe?

After such an about face on what was a basic plank in Australian Labor Party policy, the Australian people cannot trust that this Government is genuinely interested in protecting the national security of this nation. How can we believe that the reasons given by the Government in seeking to maintain peace by this legislation are genuine? This legislation is just another way of fracturing long established ties with America that may well set us adrift into a sea of uncertainty and insecurity. Pass this legislation and it will become the launching pad for further attacks on our security. It was interesting to note in the Australian today just what is going on in New Zealand-a country which wanted to maintain contact with the people of the United States in the form of ANZUS but which is still virtually denying the fact that New Zealand is out of ANZUS. A New Zealand defence inquiry committee report is about to be released today indicating that when the New Zealand people are given a choice between remaining in ANZUS and not allowing ships carrying nuclear warheads into their ports, they prefer to stay in ANZUS. When the chips are down, they believe in the Western alliance and in a definite defence system. It is interesting to see the response of the peace groups. I am for peace, as I said earlier, but there are many people who are very naive about the way in which we can maintain world peace. It is interesting to see the tactics used by the peace groups. The Australian today reports:
Peace group spokesmen last night gave an indication of the tactics they would adopt to undermine the report.
The article points out that the spokesmen would say that the way in which the poll was taken was faulty and they would attack the way in which the survey was carried out. The article continues:
The peace groups consider the committee placed too much weight on poll results, rather than the weight of submissions presented by concerned groups.

How long do we in Australia and the South Pacific have to go on listening to small minority groups of so-called concerned citizens? They are concerned, but they are minorities. They are prepared to attack the fundamentals of our defence system in this region. This shows that the unreality of the present Federal Government exists in New Zealand in the same way. Mr Lange still claims to retain membership of ANZUS, and yet only in the last few weeks New Zealand has been told that it is not part of ANZUS. Mr Lange exists in a world of unreality by still believing that he is protected by that alliance.

The honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) said yesterday that the Prime Minister of New Zealand, Mr Lange, regards this Treaty as a first step. A first step to what? It is not a final statement of position in regard to our defence but a cornerstone in putting in place policies that ultimately ban the transit, visit or navigation of any nuclear aircraft or ship through our region. That is what it is all about.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear! An excellent idea.

—The honourable member for Melbourne says that that is what it is all about. He wants to ban all these contacts and set Australia adrift from the Western alliance. The coalition is firmly committed to the values of that Western alliance. We know where we stand on this matter, as do the Australian people. We are firmly convinced that it is the right place to stand. The Government does not know where it stands on these types of issues.

SPEECH.PARA: The coalition is committed to a whole range of positive steps for this nation. Let me mention just a few. I refer to individual freedom, enterprise and self-reliance, success and excellence, compassion, family security and, last but not least, national security. What value is there in trying to develop these good, positive qualities in a nation if we do not have external security? Once national security is diminished, fractured and ultimately broken, family security and all the other strong positive qualities that should be the goal of any federal government fade into the background as all the energies and resources are focused on rebuilding the nation's external security. Twenty-four months ago we still had ANZUS intact. It is now defunct. Professor Harry Gelber said earlier this year:

Official America thinks about Australia at two levels. At one-the operational-Australia remains a firm established ally. At the other there is widespread American concern at a lack of reality in much Australian thinking!

That typifies what Americans think of the present Australian Government. There is a lack of reality in that the Government wants to have things both ways. It cannot be done that way in this world of ours. That lack of reality of which Professor Gelbar speaks is the product of this Government. That is what this Hawke Government has done to Australia. It has developed in the American mind a feeling of unease as to where Australia does stand.

TALK.START.PARA: —With good reason.

—Certainly with good reason. We are reminded of the MX missile crisis 18 months ago. That crisis not only led to the fracturing of our relationship with the United States of America, but also fractured our economic relationship and our viability as a nation. It is that which tipped off the devaluation of the dollar, as most Australians know.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation will further erode the confidence and trust of the United States in Australia. Any serious rupture with the leader of the Western nations, the United States, should not be taken lightly. The Opposition does not take it lightly. We are convinced of where we stand on maintaining peace, and it is not down this track under the form of legislation that is now being proposed to the House. The present Government does not want to maintain the security which has been developed over many years by this nation under former governments. The Government is here to provide a platform for people to get a foot in the door to argue against those alliances, and it will be to the detriment of this nation. We should make sure that this type of legislation is rejected and we should affirm our strong position in the Western alliance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wholeheartedly welcome the introduction into the Parliament of the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty Bill which, together with the Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Safeguards) Bill and the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Amendment Bill forms a legislative package designed to give effect to Australia's international non-proliferation obligations, under various treaties, including the Treaty for the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons and the Treaty of Rarotonga. This Bill will contribute measurably to increasing Australia's national security. Australia is the first country to introduce legislation of this type and the introduction of this Bill to the Parliament is, I believe, indicative of the seriousness with which this Government takes arms control issues. The package of Bills goes far beyond the minimum technically required for the purposes of ratification of the Treaty of Rarotonga and will, I hope, give encouragement to other countries in the South Pacific to ratify that Treaty. Ratification will enable it to be deposited with the United Nations along with the Treaty of Tlatelolco, the Latin American nuclear free zone treaty, as a reminder to the international community of the determination of the peoples of the Pacific to rid this region of nuclear dangers.

SPEECH.PARA: Article VII of the Treaty for the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons recognises the right of any group of states to conclude regional treaties so as to ensure the total absence of nuclear weapons from their respective territories. The South Pacific region has borne the brunt of the nuclear age. From the mining of uranium and the testing of nuclear weapons and delivery systems, to the visits of nuclear ships and the disposal of nuclear waste, the Pacific has been involved in all aspects of the nuclear cycle. The bomb dropped on Hiroshima was launched from the Micronesian island of Tinian. Many residents of Bikini and Rongelap Islands suffered tragically as a result of United States nuclear testing in Micronesia. The Polynesians of Tahiti also suffer increased health problems and dislocation of their economy and society as a result of French nuclear testing. The French bombing of the Rainbow Warrior last year drew world attention to the South Pacific islanders and their anti-nuclear aspirations. It also illustrated the lengths to which the French Government will go to cover up the effects of nuclear testing in the Pacific. This is one important reason why Australia should not export uranium to France. I believe that the proposal to sell uranium to France would be inconsistent with this opposition to French action. Not only do the French continue testing, despite the opposition of all countries in the region, but they also refuse to sign the non-proliferation treaty or to take part in serious arms control or disarmament negotiations.

Continued nuclear testing by the French Government has provoked increasingly strong opposition from all Pacific governments, whatever their political orientation. Threats by the Japanese Government to dump nuclear waste off the Northern Mariana Islands in the late 1970s led to unprecedented protests from island leaders throughout the region. In short, the nuclear issue is one of the most unifying issues in the South Pacific, and the region is one of the most sensitive areas of the world to nuclear issues. Thus it is not surprising that the South Pacific region should become the second inhabitated region after Latin America to introduce a treaty aiming to limit nuclear activities.

The negotiation of this Treaty has a long history and its final form is a compromise. Nevertheless, its coming into force will represent an advance in arms control measures of regional and global significance, particularly if the five nuclear powers can be convinced to sign its protocols. The initiative for a nuclear free zone in the South Pacific was taken by the New Zealand Labour Prime Minister, Norman Kirk, in the early 1970s. At the 1975 United Nations General Assembly a resolution sponsored by New Zealand, Fiji and Papua New Guinea, urging the creation of a South Pacific nuclear free zone, was carried. However, with the demise of Labor government's in Australia and New Zealand in the mid-1970s, the proposal did not resurface until the Canberra meeting of the South Pacific Forum in 1983 after the election of the Hawke Labor Government.

The Treaty of Rarotonga, which was opened for signature at the 1985 meeting of the South Pacific Forum in the Cook Islands, is more comprehensive than the Treaty of Tlatelolco. It outlaws the dumping of nuclear waste at sea and so-called `peaceful nuclear explosions', both of which are permitted by the Latin American treaty. Perhaps the most controversial aspects of the Treaty in the region have been that it does not prohibit the passage of nuclear armed and powered ships, fails to prevent missile testing, such as that conducted by the United States in Kwajelein in the Marshall Islands, and says nothing about uranium mining, processing or export. During the negotiations, four forum island members, Papua New Guinea, the Solomons, Vanuatu and Nauru, urged the inclusion of a ban on nuclear missile testing. Vanuatu and Nauru also sought to include bans on uranium exports. Countries such as Vanuatu and the Solomons, which ban the transit of nuclear powered or armed vessels in their territorial waters, argued that such a ban should be mandatory within the zone. However, the consensus reached was that this should be a matter for individual countries.

The Rarotonga Treaty was signed by eight South Pacific countries-Australia, the Cook Islands, Fiji, Kiribati, New Zealand, Nieu, Tuvalu and Western Samoa on Hiroshima day, 6 August 1985. It was later signed by Papua New Guinea and Nauru, but not by Vanuatu or the Solomons, who claimed the provisions of the Treaty were not comprehensive enough. Tonga has not signed on the grounds that it believes the Treaty is too restrictive to the nuclear powers.

Despite the fact that many had hoped it would go further, the Rarotonga South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty represents an advance in arms control. An integral part of the Treaty is the protocols to be signed by the nuclear weapons powers. So far, only China has indicated definitely that it will sign the protocols. The Soviet Union has welcomed the Treaty but has not yet indicated whether it will sign. The United States initially ridiculed the Treaty but later announced that it was being studied. More recently there are indications that it will probably sign the protocols. Britain will obviously be guided by whether the United States signs and it is most unlikely that France will sign. The Australian Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen) said on 11 August that the four nuclear weapons powers other than France would sign. Whether this means that the United States State Department's Pacific Bureau, which apparently favours the signing of the protocol, has won a debate with its European Bureau, which is concerned about the exemplary effect or the `contagion of the anti-nuclear allergy', and in turn overridden any Defense Department objections, is unclear. Thus, it looks as if four of the five nuclear states will now sign the protocols of the Treaty. Once the Treaty has been signed and ratified by eight members and registered with the United Nations, it will provide a legal basis for pressure from the international community on the nuclear powers to abide by its requirements.

The Treaty is also a demonstration to other countries that steps can and should be taken by regional groups of countries which will limit the nuclear activity of the nuclear powers in other regions. In the South East Asian, Indian Ocean and African regions, proposals have been initiated for nuclear free zones, inspired by the Treaty of Rarotonga. At its most recent meeting of Foreign Ministers, the Association of South East Asian Nations commissioned a working group to look into the possibility of inaugurating a nuclear free zone in the South East Asian region, modelled on the South Pacific zone. The proposal for a zone of peace in the Indian Ocean, which was first initiated over a decade ago, has received new impetus since the finalising of the Rarotonga Treaty, as have proposals for zones in Africa and various parts of Europe. Nuclear free zones are clearly a way for smaller countries to send a message to the nuclear powers that they wish to see nuclear activity reduced or halted altogether.

The initiation of the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty, despite its limitations, is an action with ramifications out of proportion to the small populations of its sponsoring countries. It is an initiative which can set limits to nuclear proliferation in this region which is, unfortunately, becoming an area of increased super-power contention. This legislation, which provides for verification and monitoring of the provisions of the Treaty, is an important contribution by Australia to entrenching the Treaty and encouraging other countries to do the same. It will also prevent tests like those at Maralinga and their permanently radiation polluting results from ever happening again in Australia. However, there are indications that several South Pacific countries, including the Melanesian states of Vanuatu and the Solomon Islands and Papua New Guinea are dissatisfied with the Treaty because it allows the super-powers free access with nuclear powered vessels to the region. In 1988 the United States will begin deploying its Trident 2D5 missiles which will be highly accurate and will have first strike capacity. Australia will be involved in communications for this first-strike weapon through its hosting of the joint United States-Australian communications facilities.

There are also other reasons for grave concern about the current United States policies. The massive annual increase in United States military spending-8 per cent per year in real terms for the last six years-are of greatest concern. But policies such as the strategic defence initiative, the attack on Libya, the decision to produce a new generation of chemical weapons, the abandonment of SALT II, the long refusal to negotiate a comprehensive nuclear test ban or even to respond constructively to the Soviet Union's test moratorium and the failure to approach the Geneva arms control and disarmament negotiations seriously suggest, even to friends of the United States such as Australia, that the current Administration wishes only to prevaricate about arms control and disarmament while dramatically increasing military strength. That is clearly the view of the United States Congress.

The Reagan Administration is acting in ways which can only be described as aggressive. The Australian Government has criticised or opposed each of those policies, yet verbal protest by allies have made no impact on that behaviour. Therefore, more direct action will be required to emphasise to the United States Administration the strength of opposition to its current policies. New Zealand has already taken such action by prohibiting visits by nuclear powered and armed vessels. Australia could well consider withdrawing agreement to locate one or more of the joint communication facilities in the country for the same reason. The North West Cape communications station is the joint facility with least justification, for its purpose is to maintain reliable communications with submarines of the United States fleet serving in the Indian and western Pacific oceans. It is an integral part of the United States military system but has no subsidiary role in early warning or verification of arms control and disarmament agreements as do the other two major joint facilities in Australia. There are no unique geographic or other features which require the North West Cape facility to be located in Australia. Therefore, the threat not to renew the agreement covering the North West Cape when it expires in 1988 would be a significant but not particularly disruptive action indicative of the strength of Australian opposition to many aspects of current United States military policy. It is a possibility which Australians must seriously consider.

The Rarotonga South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty is a clear expression of the extent of concern about the nuclear arms race in the region. It embodies significant constraints on action by present and future governments of signatory countries on the action of nuclear powers in the region. It sets an example to other regions. However, it is only one step, and many more steps are required before the arms race is effectively ended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) in his speech in November last year remarked that the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty would establish `only the second nuclear free zone in a permanently inhabited region'. He indicated in his second reading speech that the first is the Treaty of Tlatelolco signed in 1967. He went on to say that that Treaty broke important ground by establishing the first nuclear weapons free zone in a populated region-namely, Latin America. The Treaty of Tlatelolco was a Latin-American initiative towards arms control. It prohibits the direct or indirect possession of nuclear weapons. However, since only Latin American nations involved include Colombia, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela as full parties without reservation, it has become the lazy practice to say that Latin America is a de facto nuclear free zone. Unfortunately, neither Cuba nor Argentina is a full party to that Treaty and, although both Brazil and Chile have ratified the accord, they have stipulated that it will not enter into force for them until all eligible countries have fully ratified it. The zone is thereby incomplete and not, as the Minister might have led some to believe, of more than marginal relevance to this measure.

SPEECH.PARA: What is more, while the United States of America, during the Carter Administration, did ratify protocol 1 under that Treaty, which calls upon non-Latin American states with territories in the zone to place them under treaty restrictions, France has not acceded. To talk about nuclear free zones in that general context reminds me of the chairman of a committee who reports that unanimous agreement has been achieved except for those who dissent from a measure. Having found both the Government's history and its comparative analysis not particularly compelling we are left with the substance, such as it is, of the South Pacific Treaty itself. We do not need to go beyond its title to encounter our first brush with a brutal lack of reality, as it refers to the `South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone'. Although the Rarotonga agreement may purport to foster a nuclear free zone, it does no such thing. It does not establish or seek to establish a zone in which all nuclear activities are banned. If one were to be very polite one might describe it as a partial nuclear free zone or an attempt at one. It is really just a sort of regional arms prevention agreement with one non-wea-pons prohibition in the form of a ban on the dumping of radioactive wastes which has been thrown in, as it were, for good measure. All other sections of the nuclear fuel cycle are unaffected. Biomedical, energy and resource uses of nuclear technology are not banned. As to its effectiveness even as an arms prevention agreement, opinion has not been exactly ecstatic. Greg Fry of the Australian National University has noted that the Treaty has significant limitations. Writing in August of last year, he argued:
Some direct weapons involvement and weapons-related activities are unaffected by it.
He concluded:
. . . it cannot be said that the Rarotonga Treaty even established a nuclear weapons free zone, let alone the broader concept of a nuclear free zone.

There is a fairly widespread view that the nuclear free label is designed to give the impression of a comprehensiveness that does not exist. The object is apparently not so much to impress the misnamed peace movement which, incidentally, rejects this Treaty as insufficient in itself, it seems to set out to reassure voters at the margins that the Australian Labor Party is really doing all it can.

I turn to the major provisions affecting or determining the conduct of each party to the South Pacific Treaty. What are its arms prevention objectives? The first is not to manufacture or otherwise acquire, possess, or have control over any nuclear explosive device inside or outside the zone or to seek or receive assistance with such activity, or to give assistance to other states engaged in this activity. The second is to prevent the stationing of any nuclear explosive device in its territory-the word `stationing' being defined specifically as `emplantation, emplacement, transportation on land or inland waters, stockpiling, storage, installation and deployment'. The third is to prevent in each territory the testing of any nuclear explosive device and not to assist in the testing activity of any State. In relation to the latter two disciplines the word `territory' refers to and is defined as `internal waters, territorial sea and archipelagic waters, the seabed and subsoil beneath, the land territory and the air space above them'. This adds up to an attempted prohibition on the presence of nuclear weapons, or on their manufacture or testing, anywhere within the territories of the participating South Pacific states up to the 12-mile sea limit.

Attached to the Treaty are three draft protocols which respectively invite Britain, France and the United States to apply key provisions of the Treaty to their territories within the zone; seek undertakings from the five nuclear weapons states to undertake not to use or threaten to use nuclear weapons against a party to the Treaty; and seek undertakings from the five nuclear weapons States that they will not test explosive devices within the zone. It is patently clear that France is unlikely to agree to propositions one and three and that the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics is very likely to use proposition two as a stick with which to beat Australia about the head over the existence of the joint American-Australian facilities. There can be no doubt that in due course the snake oil merchant, which is the misnamed `peace movement', will take up that line of argument.

As geographically defined, the scope of the treaty is ambitious to the point of ridicule. Although the actual area of application is confined to the territories of the South Pacific Forum countries and of any dependencies for which an administering power might sign, the Treaty defines the geographical scope of the South Pacific nuclear free zone in a very broad fashion. Its boundaries stretch from the border of the so-called Latin America nuclear weapons-free zone in the east to the west coast of Australia in the west, and from the border of Antarctica in the south to the equator in the north, with some extension into the northern hemisphere to include Kiribati. This encompasses a vast area of ocean over which the Treaty signatories simply and plainly do not have jurisdiction.

It is also instructive to note under a section headed `The Global Framework', in a pamphlet printed by the Foreign Affairs Department entitled `Australia and Disarmament: Steps in the Right Direction' that the Department seems not only to be deficient historically, but also betrays through the authors of that document a very shallow view of the world.

In welcoming the slightly improved relations between the United States of America and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics over the past 18 months or so, the pamphlet alleges that this development followed on from a period `when relations between the two superpowers reached their lowest point for more than 30 years'. Either the Foreign Affairs Department was asleep during the Cuban missile crisis and other sharp disagreements that have permeated superpower relations during the past 30 years or, as is more likely, excessive caution was taken in that document not to offend the prejudices of the target audience, which is undoubtedly the misnamed `peace movement'. Either way, it is not good enough.
Nor is the substance of the pamphlet's presentation on superpower conflicts good enough. It claims:

. . . progress towards nuclear disarmament will inevitably be slow and painstaking since it involves the fundamental security interests of each of the superpowers, steady confidence building between them to overcome the fears and suspicions born of very different cultural backgrounds and historical experiences, and nuclear arsenals similar only in their size and destructive potential but made up of weapons systems mostly dissimilar in characteristics and capabilities.

Is that the substance of the Department's understanding of the causes of differences between the United States of America and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics? Is it merely fears and suspicions born out of cultural difference and historical experience, with complex weapons systems making negotiation difficult and the need for both sides to recognise each other's security interests? Is the USSR just a power like any other, albeit with greater resources? Is it all really a question of greater understanding to overcome reconcilable differences?

Again, either the Department is seriously deficient in historical and contemporary analysis, or it is genuflecting towards the prejudices of the target audience. Why not tell the truth? Self-delusions concerning the urbane sophistication of Australia's international outlook vis-a-vis the supposedly `naive' American approach, dominated, so we are told, by a `cold war mentality', may be flattering to many members of Australia's foreign policy establishment, but it is not an honest response to the realities that we face. This measure is a perfect illustration of that failure to explain and to face reality.

We would be better to tell Australians and our allies among the island states of the overriding and mutual need for the Americans to be able to move their naval units freely around the South Pacific. Whatever our reservations, that would at least be frank. The nuclear-free genie is now well and truly out of the bottle. The Treaty itself, and especially the Bill, lays the foundation for further and more restrictive practices of this kind in future. I am implacably opposed to the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we reach the high-water mark of the Kosciusko-like hypocrisy of the Hawke socialist Government. In 20 years in politics I have never seen a greater example of hypocrisy than what is happening in the chamber right now. Less than 40 hours after the Hawke socialist Government announced that it would be resuming the sale of uranium to France, the same hypocritical Government comes into this chamber and asks the House of Representatives to pass the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty Bill. If that is not the greatest example of hypocrisy, double standards and doublespeak that anyone has ever heard of, I do not know what is.

SPEECH.PARA: That Government is revealed as a motley, discredited collection of two-faced bandicoots, ferrets and bushrats. How it can have any credibility in the eyes of any thinking Australian is beyond me. Whatever view one takes on the nuclear question, the plain fact remains that just 40 hours after saying that the green light is to come on and it is all systems go with sales of uranium to France, the Government asks us to pass legislation which it knows in its own mind is more than likely to be breached by a purchaser of Australian uranium.

Let me make this quite clear: In an ideal world, I should like to see the South Pacific nuclear free. I would like to see the world nuclear free. Surely no member on either side of the House would contradict that proposition. Unfortunately, we live in the real world and not a dream world. I commend and respect the views of those who push for what is known colloquially as unilateral disarmament-some very well-meaning and well-intentioned people who firmly believe that someone should make the first move-but it is my fundamental belief that in maintaining the security of our nation, the preservation of the Western alliance and those things which we hold dear, the only form of disarmament acceptable to me and to the majority of Australians would be multilateral, simultaneous and verifiable disarmament. Anything else would be a repeat of the tragedy of the discredited policies of appeasement in 1930s. Anything else would bring Australia in 1986 the debacle of Munich. Anything else would place the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in a position in which he would be remembered long after he left the political scene as the Australian latterday equivalent of Neville Chamberlain.

Do the people of Australia realise that under the Hawke socialist Government-and I acknowledge the presence in the chamber of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) who is one of the more honourable past leaders of the Australian Labor Party; a person who at least stuck by what he said, right or wrong-clause 11 of the Bill provides the power to make it illegal for an ally of Australia to bring into our waters and ports in time of war vessels which are nuclear powered? I want to emphasise that and I am going to quote what the Minister for Foreign Affairs said on this point in his second reading speech.

This Bill, if enacted and if taken before the International Court of Justice, would as a matter of law, override the ANZUS Treaty. Why is that so? One of the most fundamental propositions of statutory interpretation is that where there are two conflicting pieces of legislation, the courts, including the International Court of Justice, determine which piece of legislation represents the views of the Parliament and the people of Australia. The Bill is clearly in conflict with ANZUS and it would prevail in law. Let me put it to honourable members quite simply that if Australia were subject to a military attack and if the United States, under the ANZUS Treaty, were called to aid us, under this legislation United States vessels could not enter Australian waters.

I suggest to honourable members that this legislation is quasi-treason and that no patriotic Australian in his right mind could vote for it. The honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), in a magnificent speech last night in this Parliament, made the statement that it had been said to him by a person high in authority in the Government-although he did not name that person: `Don't worry. If that situation developed in time of war we would ignore this Treaty. We would give effect to ANZUS'. I think, Mr Deputy Speaker, you may have been in the chamber at the time. I uttered the words `Was that Old Silver?', and the honourable member for Kooyong, being a most honourable member and a most statesmanlike person, said that he would not name the person who made the statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Allen Blanchard, was it?
—The Deputy Speaker is not only silver haired--
—I trust there is no reflection on the Chair in those remarks.

—Certainly not. I think everybody knows who Old Silver is; I am sure everyone does. Anyway, having said that, that is the sort of nonsense that is going on. I must just say in passing that I wonder how the sincere and genuine members of the peace movement feel about that sort of doublespeak coming on top of the monumental, Kosciusko-like hypocrisy of a government which 40 hours ago said `We are going to sell uranium to France' and then comes into this Parliament and says `We want you to pass this Bill which will provide for a nuclear free zone' when it knows damn well that the uranium it is selling to France will be coming back in another form. I just cannot believe it. I thought the Hawke socialist Government had reached the depths of intellectual and moral bankruptcy months ago. I did not believe that it could go lower, but surely it has.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us have a good look at the Bill, drawn up by somebody who ought to be on the payroll of the Soviet Embassy. What fantastic legislation this is! What did the Minister say? He said that it had been widely recognised around the world as a significant measure. I will be quite frank. I have followed world opinion on this matter and the only enthusiastic comments I have seen about it have appeared in Pravda or have come from Tass, and I am told that the night it was introduced into this Parliament by the Minister for Foreign Affairs the vodka ran very freely in the Soviet Embassy right here in Canberra. People there must have been tickled pink.

TALK.START.PARA: —Red.

—I bow to the honourable member. Sixty years ago Lenin made a very profound statement. He said: `We will overcome the West; we will hang them'. But, interestingly enough, he also said: `The West will provide the rope with which we hang them'. This is another strand in the rope with which the Hawke socialist Government has carefully manufactured and put together in conjunction with its lunatic colleague across the Tasman, comrade Lange, because in the last two years more damage has been done to our national security than ever before.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me continue with this premise: We are less defended today than we were on 3 September 1939. We have a Minister for Defence, from your home State, Mr Deputy Speaker, who said that he was going for a 3 per cent increase in defence expenditure. He got a one per cent increase in money terms, which is a cut in real terms; yet he told a Press conference yesterday that he had a magnificent victory.

TALK.START.PARA: —And with the fringe benefits tax, another $116m out of it.

—Indeed. I just do not understand it. I would think that if I went for 3 per cent and finished up with minus one per cent I would have had a pretty rugged defeat, that I had been rolled in that inner sanctum around there next to the fuhrerbunker where the Cabinet of the Hawke socialist Government meets in secret conclave. But this Minister comes out and tells the world that he has had a great victory. I do not understand it.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us never forget that the MX missile crisis started the plunge of the Australian dollar. Why? It was because we betrayed an ally. I have told this House before how the New York Times, in an article syndicated and read by over 60 million Americans, sons and daughters of the servicemen and women who fought alongside the servicemen and women of this nation in World War II, wrote that Australia had reneged on treaty obligations and that Premier-that is what the New York Times called him, but it meant the Prime Minister-Hawke blamed a split in the Party. We have the situation in which the Tasman Sea is now a Soviet naval playground. There is no naval surveillance by the United States because it does not have access to New Zealand ports. The Royal Australian Navy, which I love and which celebrated its seventy-fifth anniversary this year, is an absolute disgrace. It is tiny, almost useless and run down. That is how this Government gave it its seventy-fifth birthday present.
