We also have the situation of fishing deals being done with the Soviet Union in Kiribati, using maps which were prepared by a surveying team from the Australian Army. My time has nearly expired, unfortunately.
Opposition members-Oh!

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable members for their support.
—Your time runneth by, Michael.

—My time in this debate, Minister, not my political time. I want to ask the Minister to explain, when he replies, whether it is due to the fact that he is slightly deaf or that he is very forgetful that never since he has been Foreign Minister have we heard one squeak from him or any other member of the Hawke socialist Government-this two-faced, bandicoot, ferret and bush rat Government-stand in this Parliament and say something about the testing of Soviet missiles in the Pacific. I note with great pleasure the presence in the chamber of a senator who says what she thinks, even though I do not always agree with her. Senator Vallentine from Western Australia might like to follow up this matter. Why has the Hawke socialist Government not uttered one squeak of protest about the fact that recently the Soviet Union engaged in test firing SS18 Mark 4 missiles with a range of 16,000 kilometres and with 10 warheads, each 50 times more destructive than the Nagasaki weapon, into the vicinity of the Cook Islands? The Cook Islands are not very far from Australia; they are not very far from New Zealand. The Minister has gone on his walkie-talkie. He will be told that his advisers have not heard about it. It has been written up in the Bulletin; it has been written up in the international Press. If we are going to have a nuclear free zone, let us have it totally nuclear free. Let us not capitulate to and appease the Soviet Union and destroy the Western alliance which saved this nation once and is our only hope for salvation in the future. I oppose the Bill, I will vote against it and if I had the chance I would vote against it, twice, thrice and as many times as I was allowed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Mr W.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel at some disadvantage following such a superb speech by the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman), but I will do my best. I want to deal with three matters of concern in the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty Bill which, in my view, justify a total rejection of it and the substitution for it of other measures better suited to attaining those objectives of the Bill which should be attained. I am referring to such things as the dumping of nuclear waste. From one perspective, the Bill is, as the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) put it last night, a Mickey Mouse Bill, a splendid example of Hawkespeak. We know that the Bill is a Hawke initiative to con the anti-nuclear movement in this country. The Left asks, reasonably: `What sort of anti-nuclear measure is it that allows the passage of nuclear-powered and armed vessels freedom of movement?'. Vanuatu, Papua New Guinea and the Solomon Islands have not signed the Treaty, SPINFIZT, as it is called, for that reason. The Bill is seen as a confidence trick, rather like the Keating Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: Within the Mickey Mouse clauses-this is my first cause for concern-is one article which is not a con or a charade. I refer to article 5 of the Treaty which is followed up by clauses 11 and 18 of the Bill, which provide penalties of 20 years gaol and $500,000 fines. Article 5 prohibits the stationing of any nuclear explosive device in the territory of the country concerned. Stationing is defined in the Schedule as including deployment. This means on one view that even a ship visit could be prohibited. That view has certainly been put forward strongly by the Prime Minister of New Zealand. But on any view, it means that in a future grave crisis Australia would be prevented from having nuclear-armed vessels here for a longer period than a mere visit. In other words, this treaty-SPINFIZT-overrides ANZUS. It is unconscionable, to say the least, although not surprising, that the Government should be proposing this without explaining it or even trying to justify it. That is the first reason for rejecting it as a threat to Australian security. I am sure that the Minister will comment on article 5 in his reply. My second reason for rejecting the Bill is that even if we assume that my reading of article 5 is debatable-no-one can say that it is definitely wrong-and even if its meaning is uncertain, it adds a great element of uncertainty and instability to an already unstable region.

All questions of this character in the world today come down to the Soviet question-to the role and expansion of the USSR and its gulag. We are in a region in which, compared with 20 years ago, the Soviet Union is moving forward dramatically. Cam Ranh Bay in Vietnam is the largest Soviet forward deployment base outside the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, and the Soviet Pacific fleet has doubled over the past 20 years and is expanding. With 800 ships, it is already the largest of the Soviet fleets. The Union of Soviet Socialist Republics has signed a fishing agreement with Kiribati, paying to Kiribati one tenth of its annual budget, and is trying to negotiate other such agreements with, for example, Fiji. Of course, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics has promoted the Pacific Trade Union Forum as one of its most active arms throughout the region. In this region, too, New Zealand has scuttled ANZUS and moved as it were, off the planet. Under New Zealand's proposed nuclear free zone legislation, New Zealand officers could spend 10 years in prison for even attending a United States military staff college. It wants to New Zealandise the whole region, of course to the applause of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics.

In New Caledonia, there is the Kanak independence movement, developing at times into insurrection, with backing from Colonel Gadaffi. Vanuatu has become the first Pacific member of the non-aligned-that is, the anti-Western-movement. The Cuban and Libyan presence is already apparent there. This region is being destabilised and the opportunities for the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics are growing. In this context, the Bill and the Treaty weaken the capacity of the United States and its allies to respond or at least add to the uncertainties of the region with a treaty containing uncertain articles.

One can never eliminate uncertainties from world affairs. Great events, including the Hitler-Stalin alliance, Pearl Harbour, the Korean war, the Yom Kippur war, the fall of the Shah, the Falklands war and so on, took the world and its intelligence services by surprise. No one can eliminate the unexpected from world affairs, but one can at least refuse to add to the uncertainties, as this Treaty does, and for the most cynical and frivolous reason of alleged party advantage. But there is a third reason for concern. The egregious Prime Minister of New Zealand-a country and a people, although not a government, that enjoy the greatest respect and affection of Australians-has welcomed the treaty as an `important first step'. He says in effect: `Yes, the Treaty still permits the passage of nuclear vessels, but it prevents the deployment of weapons.' Of course, later we can take further steps, such as the notorious steps already take by the temporary government of New Zealand. Prime Minister Lange says that even port visits violate the treaty, and he would want that spelt out more clearly at a later stage.

In this House, the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner) has said that, in his view, the mining and export of uranium is inconsistent with the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty. Others have welcomed the treaty because it overrides ANZUS as a step towards a unilaterally disarmed or neutralist Australia, and others want to take it as a step towards making the whole Pacific Ocean a nuclear free zone, totally excluding the United States fleet. Mr Halfpenny is associated with that view. They have some reason on their side. The Bill can be seen as a step in that direction.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry, Peter, what direction? I missed something.

—As a first step towards a more extreme interpretation of the measure-towards a neutralist Australia, the banning of uranium mining and making the Pacific Ocean a nuclear free zone, excluding the United States entirely. Those views have been put forward by the people supporting the Bill, although they are dissatisfied with it in its present form. I referred to the honourable member for Hughes, Mr Halfpenny and others.

SPEECH.PARA: More generally, the Bill and the Treaty involve another nitpicking quarrel with our allies and associates-in this case, the United States. But with whom has this Government not quarrelled? It has quarrelled with the United Kingdom by refusing to service HMAS Invincible. It has quarrelled with the French by its stupid banning of uranium sales and by constant and ignorant attacks on the defence policies of this Western ally. It has quarrelled repeatedly with Singapore, Malaysia and Indonesia. It insulted Papua New Guinea recently by the way in which it informed that country of the reduction of Australian aid. We have irritated Israel by our withdrawal from the Sinai peacekeeping force. Whom have we not irritated, insulted or alienated? There are one or two, principally communist Vietnam.

Now we are further antagonising the United States. Whatever the Government may say-it says some sensible things from time to time-its record is marked by the cowardly MX cave-in and by its niggling criticisms of United States policy on everything from Nicaragua to Libya to the strategic defence initiative, which it says we will not join no matter how much it would be in Australia's scientific and national interests to do so. Now we have this Treaty aimed exclusively at inevitably weakening the United States vis-a-vis the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics in this region.

The Government is doing this, first, to appease its own loony left and also to try to take a leadership role among the island states, whose leaders are anti-nuclear, belong to a post-war generation with no experience of Japanese conquest and see Soviet totalitarianism as a long way away. The Government hopes to achieve this leadership role and at the same time offers the United States a set of winks, nods and nudges suggesting that it should not take it all too seriously. It is another example of the Government's frivolity.

Real leadership in the region would be of a different character. It would mean persuading and explaining the facts to the island states and their leaders: The facts of deterrence, the facts of nuclear energy and the facts of Soviet expansion. It would mean offering alternatives to this foolish measure. That would be leadership, but this Government prefers con jobs and Mickey Mouse jobs to real leadership.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-The Government is extremely pleased with the achievement that this legislation represents. The South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty is one of the most substantial achievements of any nation state in the area of arms control, and it has been put in place in a relatively short period. Moreover, it has had widespread support among the island states of the South Pacific. Ten of the 13 states entitled to sign it have done so. There are four ratifying signatures to the treaty, and there are clear undertakings from four more countries that they, too, will ratify it. The formal ratification and its deposit at the United Nations are only a short time away.

SPEECH.PARA: The debate followed fairly general themes of criticism from the Opposition. Accordingly, I shall reply to those largely in the same general way. However, I must say that the debate was enlivened by a characteristically flamboyant rhetorical display from the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman). I would say this about his performance: As usual, it is a hard act to follow-extremely hard. In fact, I found it to be totally incomprehensible. He appealed to thinking Australians, which I thought was a rather novel and excessive presumption on his part, given the status that he has managed to establish for himself in this Parliament.

I mention only two matters from the lengthy discordant statement that the honourable member for Denison made to the House. He said that the only nuclear disarmament acceptable to him would be multilateral and verifiable. What of armament? What of instances where there are new areas of competition and new geographical areas? If he was unable to achieve total multilateral and verifiable disarmament measures, does that mean that he would take no steps at a regional level and that he would stand by and watch this proliferation affect the global order and create the tensions and instability that these things tend to do? His principle seems to be that, if he cannot avoid all sin, there will be no prescription against any sin. If this is so, life for him is a cavalcade of temptation unresisted.

The other matter he mentioned was a criticism of the Government party for not objecting to Russian missile testing targeted near the Cook Islands. I have discussed the matter with experts from the Department of Foreign Affairs who are in the House, in the despatch box, and they are mystified by this. The honourable member might be kind enough to give us the information on this. The only information we have about Russian missile testing concerns missile testing in the north Pacific. There was, of course, a Chinese test in 1980 which landed near Fiji, not the Cook Islands-but no matter, the geography is pretty shonky all the way through if one cannot distinguish between the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and China. I was Leader of the Opposition then and I clearly recall having expressed a public criticism of that testing. I can recall no objection and no criticism from the Government of the day led by the then Prime Minister, Mr Malcolm Fraser.

I find much of the criticism which has been made by members of the Opposition difficult to fathom. It seems to me that they are struggling to manufacture objections and that at heart what we have done is something they probably very much would wish to have done themselves or something like it. I refer to their documentation entitled `Policy on Peace and Disarmament', released by one of their more distinguished members in May 1985. On page 12 it is said of the South Pacific:
We will oppose any proposal for a Nuclear Free Zone which restricts, or could have the tendency to restrict . . .

I will run through the restrictive criteria which would be unacceptable to the Opposition. The presumption is that other matters outside the ones which are stipulated would be acceptable. The unacceptable restrictive criteria are: Nuclear power generation or nuclear medicine-this Treaty quite consciously does not stand in the way of that; the purchase or sale of uranium for peaceful purposes-again, this Treaty does not stand in the way of that, the transit of nuclear-powered and/or nuclear-armed ships, submarines or aircraft quite explicitly does not stand in the way of that and we have made that clear; visits and port/air base facilities for the above-again, the Treaty does not stand in the way of that; the operation of communications and surveillance bases-the Treaty has been very carefully drafted to make sure that it does not stand in the way of that, that being a role we fulfil as did the conservative coalition parties in government. There is a bipartisan commitment on this; and missile testing-the Treaty does not stand in the way of missile testing and does not refer to it although there would obviously be objections from the Government Party in relation to such a proposal affecting Australian sovereign territory. But on all of the criteria which have been stipulated here as those which, if restrictive, would be unacceptable to the Opposition, not one of them is embodied in the Bill or in the Treaty.

On the criteria which have been set down by the Opposition, this Bill should be acceptable. Of course, spurious opposition has been mounted to try to gain a little publicity perhaps and to create a little concern. There have been some extraordinarily excessive statements about the scourge of the red menace in the region. It will be unfortunate should any of those be believed in their excessiveness, because then we will be tilting at distorted images, and if we tilt at distorted images in developing policy we are not developing appropriate policy responses.

The Opposition claimed in various ways that this Bill and, of course, the Treaty represent a sort of wedge which will be driven into the Western alliance to fragment and weaken it and that they favour the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. This is nonsense. In fact, insofar as our alliance associations and our commitments to support and protect Western interests go, this Bill will not stand in the way of those commitments and obligations. What it does do-I think that this is in the interests of all people on the globe-is establish an obligation on the countries which become members of the Treaty not to do certain things-not to allow the testing, stock- piling or manufacturing of nuclear weapons on their territory. That is an important contribution to the halting or the breaking of aspects of the nuclear arms race.

Importantly again the Treaty on Non-proliferation of Nuclear Weapons under article 7 specifically refers to the right of states to conclude such regional treaties. So what is being done is being done with all of the authority, credibility and respectability which the non-proliferation Treaty, the most important anti-nuclear weaponry international convention that we have in place, can provide. The nuclear powers, to some extent in the case of protocol 1 to the Treaty and in all cases in respect of protocols 2 and 3, are encouraged to sign those protocols. Protocol 1, for France, the United Kingdom and the United States of America, prohibits manufacturing, stationing and testing of nuclear explosive devices. Protocols 2 and 3, covering all of the nuclear powers, require undertakings not to use nuclear explosive devices and not to test anywhere. The obligations for protocol signatories are consistent and even as between East and West. I believe we have a highly desirable set of propositions both in the Treaty and in the protocols. Those propositions are designed to restrain the nuclear arms race, one of the most destabilising and potentially the most awesomely threatening prospect that we have in the globe.

It was said by one speaker that concern had been expressed about the Treaty by the United Kingdom and the United States of America. This just is not true. Indeed, no country, none of the nuclear weapon states, has signed the protocols to this point for the simple reason that it was only a fortnight ago at Suva that the protocols were finalised.

Some speakers from this side of the House argued for variations to take place in the Treaty, for instance, that the Treaty should be strengthened to prevent the sale of uranium. If a country wishes to go beyond the floor of obligations which were established in this Treaty, it is entirely within the sovereign authority of that country to do so. An obvious example of a country going further than the Treaty is New Zealand with its policy of prohibiting port access for American nuclear-powered or presumed nuclear-capable vessels. It was suggested by another speaker on this side of the House that the Treaty and the legislation should be amended to prevent the firing of nuclear weapons at sea. But it is quite specifically declared in the Treaty that this Treaty, and indeed the legislation, insofar as it binds us to the Treaty as a legislative expression of our committment, cannot do that. It cannot do that for the simple reason that it is well established at international law that sovereign states do not have authority to restrict the open seas or the open air-space, that there is freedom of shipping movement and aircraft movement in those respective spheres.

The Opposition spokesman on foreign affairs matters said, among other things, that the dumping of nuclear waste should be provided under a separate convention. It was our view initially and until quite recently that dumping should be prohibited under the South Pacific regional environmental program. But the countries of the South Pacific made it clear that they preferred to have the prohibition included in the South Pacific Nuclear-Free Zone Treaty. We have been persuaded of the advantages of doing that and that is why the proposition is included. But I stress that this is a Bill for an Act covering a regional treaty. That regional treaty could be put in place only if there were general agreement about the base or the floor on which the countries of the region were prepared to stand commonly. The floor could be lifted no higher than those countries commonly were prepared to accept. If particular countries want to go to a higher elevation, that is a matter for them. They can proceed past the floor provided under the South Pacific nuclear free zone. The point I am making, very simply, is that the final result is very much a matter of negotiation, as it must be with treaties, between the member countries of the South Pacific.

I said that I would address the matters raised in a general way, and I have done that. But the exception I will make is that I intend to address some of the comments made by the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) as the Opposition spokesman on foreign affairs matters. I regret that I will address only some of the remarks, but time limitations are the determining factor. I make this exception because his was a carefully thought out statement. His views were cogently put and there is considerable force to them. But that does not mean that I endorse them, which will be of no surprise to him.

The honourable member for Kooyong said that it is no wonder that the Soviets have so embraced this Government's South Pacific nuclear free zone. I am unaware of that. I am aware that the Chinese have been quite encouraging in their comments. But from my recollection the only comment from the Soviet Union brought to my notice is a rather ambiguous one and a bit of a cop-out. My recollection of the only comment from the Soviet Union brought to my attention is that the Soviets are prepared to sign the Treaty if all of the other nuclear powers sign it first.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was their more recent statement. They had earlier endorsed it. I have the copies.

—If I can take the dictum that was handed down by `Justice Hodgman' a little while ago, it is the most recent declaration that always prevails in these matters. The honourable member for Kooyong said: `It restricts the United States-the only weapons state to deploy in the defined zone-yet the Soviet Union's power base at Cam Ranh Bay will be unaffected'. I am rather mystified by that. Cam Ranh Bay is rather removed from this particular zone. But his comment also ignores the fact that the Americans are at Subic, Clark and Guam-all much nearer to this particular zone.

SPEECH.PARA: At another stage he said: `While Soviet penetration and actual gains are still restricted in the South West Pacific region, it is important that we appreciate the opportunity the increased regional destabilisation has given them'. Again, I am mystified about this increased regional destabilisation. There is a difference between the ANZUS parties over New Zealand's porting policy. It is indisputable that there is more activity in the South Pacific on the part of the Soviets. On top of that, there are some developing tensions; for instance, New Caledonia was referred to by at least one Opposition spokesman. But in their magnitude these things are not huge and they certainly do not represent destabilisation. That is the sort of unwholesome exaggeration which can cause the general public, if they listen to such comments and accept them at face value, to presume the situation to be much more serious than it is. Accordingly, they could be encouraged to respond to unwise policies, excessive policies, or policies that go past a target that does not even exist. Many of these problems are more appropriately attended to by diplomatic undertakings by the professionals in the Department of Foreign Affairs in this country, in New Zealand and in the other countries of the region.

The Soviet presence in the South Pacific occurs because the Soviets are prepared to enter into fishing agreements under which they make payments which go beyond what would be regarded as sensibly commercially justifiable by Western commercial interests. So it is quite clear that the Soviets are out to pay a relatively small moiety to gain a relatively advantageous political presence. However, the important thing is that, if we are active in the region in heading off those things that cause countries to head in a direction which goes beyond merely a commercial engagement and which allows the Soviets to establish land-based facilities and from that to embark into whatever other activities they want to embark into-activities which most often bear little resemblance to straight commercial activity-we are going in the right direction. Kiribati has been sedulous in ensuring that its commercial agreement does not provide for any sort of land-based operations or facilities. That should be acknowledged and should not be exaggerated, as was done in the course of this debate.

There are other problem countries in the region too. The United States attitude towards the fishing rights of its tuna fishermen has been one of the most discordant presences in the South Pacific. We trust that this will be resolved soon. With regard to nuclear testing we see the perhaps imperious way in which some policies are proceeded with by France in the region. At least that is the way in which they are seen by the Pacific island countries and the way in which those countries express themselves about these things. These things create some strain and some disaffection among the island states of the South Pacific. But these things are more likely to be resolved by persistent and constructive diplomatic endeavour.

The only matter I refer to from the honourable member for Kooyong's speech is his invocation of Prime Minister Lange's statement that frequent Australian port visits by United States warships could be interpreted as stationing, which is disallowed by the Treaty. It would be better to leave to the Government of Australia the interpretation of what we regard as stationing or not stationing in relation to visits by United States warships. It is our right to determine that. There is absolutely no dispute that the visits of United States warships in no way conflict with the provisions and obligations under this Treaty.

This has been a most constructive debate. The Government is most rewarded that it has been able to bring this legislation into the Parliament to effect the provisions of the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty. It is only the second such treaty, putting aside the Antarctic Treaty as a special case, that has been established in the global order to this point.
Question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Motion (by Mr Hayden)-by leave-proposed:
That the Bill be now read a third time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I only want to take one minute to place on record in this Parliament, before honourable members leave the chamber, my belief that Australia will live to rue the day when this Bill is passed. This disgraceful legislation, which is an absolute gift to the Soviet Union, is anti-United States of America and anti-Western alliance; it is a scandal.
—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat.
—I am speaking on the third reading, sir.
—I will allow the honourable member to proceed.

—I will finish in a moment. It is only a matter of time before the mob opposite will be paid in roubles instead of dollars; it is only a matter of time before that coat of arms over the Speaker's chair will be taken away and replaced by a hammer and sickle. Shame on the Hawke socialist Government! This is disgraceful legislation-it is Pearl Harbour all over again. The Government will live to regret this day; it will be thrown out at the next election.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member will resume his seat.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a third time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government proposes that amendment No. 2 be agreed to and amendment No. 1 be disagreed to. I suggest, therefore, that it may suit the convenience of the Committee to consider amendment No. 2 first and, when that amendment has been disposed of, to consider amendment No. 1.
—Does that course of action suit the convenience of the Committee?
—Yes.
—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That amendment No. 2 be agreed to.

The Government has tried to streamline the procedure a bit. We do not hold very strong feelings about the amendment. It related only to the way in which ministerial salaries would in future be dealt with. The Opposition considers that this still requires the use of Public Service time to draft legislation rather than proceeding by way of regulation, which would still have the same scrutiny. For a party that cries out for smaller governments, it is a strange amendment; the first the Opposition has moved in this new session. I appreciate that the Opposition members in this chamber do not know anything about it but that is what their colleagues have done in the Upper House. The second amendment is even stranger, but in view of the time factor the Government agrees to the first amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Special Minister of State (Mr Young) said that we will use public servants' time drafting amendments and that they will be presented here. Of course that is so, but he seems to have overlooked that if it were to be done by regulation, precisely the same amount of Public Service time would be required to deal with the regulations and have them brought here.
