TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That amendment No. 1 be disagreed to.

This relates to the amendment moved by the Senate to extend the definition of nominee for overseas study travel, the purposes of which have been considered by the Remuneration Tribunal. It would establish a most undesirable precedent for the Parliament to override a determination of the independent Tribunal. Referring to the matter of salaries, which was rejected earlier in the legislation, the proposals put by all parties to the Tribunal were that we should merely follow the cost of living, which is what the Government has accepted. In rejecting the 11.7 per cent recommendation the Tribunal pointed out that it felt it had a statutory obligation to bring up the date for salaries. That was not accepted by the Government, and nor is this amendment. The Tribunal has examined all these matters, and it has seen a clear demarcation between the purposes for which people may be nominated for internal travel as against overseas study leave. The amendment moved by the Senate is not acceptable to the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment which was agreed to in the Senate and which is being disagreed to by the Government would have the effect of removing the existing definition of nominee and the provision dealing with entitlements for overseas travel and substituting a definition in the same term as that applicable to interstate travel-that is, a member is entitled to take with him overseas a spouse, a parent, a son or daughter other than a dependent child, a brother or sister or other person approved by the Special Minister of State. The amendment avoids members being entitled to the expenses of overseas travel of de facto spouses. That is its purport and the Opposition supports it.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Resolution reported; report adopted.
Committee of Reasons
Motion (by Mr Young) agreed to:
That Mr Maher, Mr Lindsay and the mover be appointed a committee to draw up reasons for the House of Representatives disagreeing to amendment No. 1 of the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Committee appointed to draw up reasons for the House disagreeing to amendment No. 1 of the Senate, I bring up such reasons which have been circulated to honourable members.

SPEECH.PARA: The reasons read as follows-
The Senate amendment is not acceptable because-
Proposals to extend the definition of nominee for overseas study travel purposes have been considered by the Remuneration Tribunal, including in its 1986 Review, and not accepted.
It would establish a most undesirable precedent for the Parliament to override a Determination of the independent Tribunal so as to widen an entitlement available to Senators and Members.
Motion (by Mr Young) agreed to:
That the Committee's reasons be adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 5 June, on the following paper presented by Mr Beazley:
Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities-Ministerial Statement, 3 June 1986.
and on motion by Mr Young:
That the House take note of the papers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In continuation of my remarks in this House, the Guam doctrine made it clear that the United States of America would protect its allies against nuclear threats but that it would expect its allies to bear a greater share of their own defence burdens. It was obvious that, henceforth, we would have to make more of an effort to look after ourselves. Regrettably, the Fraser Government pursued a globalist view based on the assumption that Australia's security was dependent on a great and powerful ally. Our preoccupation with distant commitments left us with serious deficiencies in our force structure.

SPEECH.PARA: The 1976 Defence White Paper recognised some of these deficiencies and identified increased self-reliance as primary requirements for Australia's security and defence policies. But the Fraser Government did not pursue self-reliance to the extent that the 1976 White Paper intended. The Fraser Government took little account of our regional defence needs, which assumes that the American alliance can no longer be related as closely to Australia's security as it was before the Vietnam war. The election of the Hawke Government in March 1983 firmly committed Australia to a policy of self-reliance and to strengthening the bonds between Australia and its great ally, the United States of America. In an essay published in the Journal of the Australian Naval Institute in February 1984, Lieutenant-Commander R. J. Willis, Royal Australian Navy, wrote:

Regardless of the political nature of future Australian governments, the self-reliance posture is likely to remain as an enduring concept in defence planning. Australia will probably never be able to achieve absolute self-reliance, so the likely enduring problem is to determine an appropriate level of self-reliance based on both the strategic outlook and budgetary constraints.
It is a policy that has been required by our great ally, the United States of America, since the early 1970s. It is a policy that must be pursued by a loyal and responsible partner of that alliance.
The Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) in his tabling statement correctly observed:
The ability to defend itself is the absolute minimum that any self-respecting country could contribute to an alliance.

There is no doubt that just as a policy of self-reliance contributes to the strength of the Australia-United States alliance so, too, does the Australia-United States alliance contribute to Australia's ability to defend itself. Australia's access to intelligence and surveillance sensors, advanced technology such as the FFGs and FA18s, opportunities for combined exercises and availability of logistic support, greatly assist us in being able to provide for our own defence. I agree with the Dibb Review of Defence Capabilities that our force structure should be based on a strategy relying on three key elements. I refer first to Australia's area of direct military interest; secondly, layered defence within this region; and, thirdly, priority being given to meeting low level threats which could develop quickly, rather than developing capabilities more suited to higher level threats for which we would have more warning.

There will never be enough money in peace-time defence budgets to satisfy all the apparently sensible proposals that come forward. However, over the last four Budgets of the Hawke Government, defence spending has grown by an average of 2.7 per cent. This year the defence bill is over $7.4 billion, that is, almost 10 per cent of total Commonwealth outlays and 2.9 per cent of gross domestic product. Only 17 countries in the world spend more absolutely on defence than Australia. In per capita terms we now spend three times more than Japan, and a defence budget of 3 per cent of GDP puts us in middle rank of North Atlantic Treaty Organisation countries.

The Dibb report deserves full marks for its rational approach to our defence needs in the short term. However, we must ensure that our allies know exactly what we are doing and why we are doing it. The Government must emphasise that we stand ready in the long term to shoulder our regional commitments and to offer whatever assistance we can to those allies should any perceived threat to the stability of this region arise. Difficult decisions will have to be made on how to accomplish a policy of self-reliance. Although these decisions may disturb long held beliefs and traditions, Australia cannot afford any longer to avoid the challenge of reality. I am reassured by discussions held in the United States of America last week in this regard. I refer honourable members to the comments on the Dibb report by the Secretary of Defence, Mr Weinberger, who said:

We think it is very desirable for Australia to strengthen their military forces to act in the various regions set out in the Dibb report . . . we think if the Australian forces are strengthened . . . that will benefit all of us.

The Dibb report on defence is good news for Australia and it is particularly welcome news for northern Australians. For the people of northern Australia it is tangible recognition of their persistent pleas to successive Australian governments to defend the north. I am very pleased that the Government has decided to transfer the Royal Australian Air Force's No. 9 helicopter squadron from Amberley to Townsville. The move, which will take place in early 1989, will follow the re-equipping of the squadron at Amberley with Sikorsky Black Hawk helicopters. No. 9 squadron is currently equipped with Bell Iriquois helicopters. These will be replaced during 1987-88 by the Black Hawks, the purchase of which, along with eight Sikorsky Seahawks for the Royal Australian Navy's missile frigates, was announced on 1 May 1986. The move of the Black Hawks helicopters from Amberley to Townsville will considerably assist the training and capability of the Army's Operational Deployment Force already based at Townsville. Where other governments have failed, I am sure that the Hawke Government, by implementing most of the recommendations contained in the Dibb report, will earn the confidence and respect of the people of north Queensland. The report's recommendations are realistic and they are financially sustainable.

The report proposes to retain the F-111 force with an appropriate update, for service until around the mid-1990s. The report recommends that eight light patrol frigates be built in Australia to enter service from the mid-1990s as the last three destroyer escorts and the first five Fremantle class patrol boats pay off. The new vessels would perform ocean patrol and sovereignty tasks in Australia's key maritime areas for which smaller patrol boats would be unsuitable. These vessels would be equipped with reconnaissance helicopters, missiles, air defence systems and a gun. This is in addition to the two guided missile frigates presently being constructed at Williamstown dockyard.

The report states that many of our northern approaches are susceptible to mining and their closure would have a substantial political and economic effect. Ports such as Dampier, Port Hedland, Darwin, Gove and Weipa could be seen as particularly attractive for mining operations. The major ports of the south, essential for national survival, are also vulnerable. At present Australia has a single token mine countermeasures vessel, suitable only for training. This has resulted from poor planning and procrastination over many years. This deficiency is unacceptable and Australia needs, as a matter of priority, a capability to clear mines. Accordingly, programs for mine sweeping should be accelerated as a matter of priority.

The report confirms Australia's need for new submarines. It notes that submarines are versatile and can be operated very formidably for intelligence collection, surveillance, mining and special operations in addition to their traditional anti-shipping and anti-submarine capabilities. Members will recall how effective submarines were in the Falklands crisis of 1982. The Hawke Government is proceeding with plans to acquire new high capability conventional submarines, appropriate for our circumstances. The report proposes that Australia's main submarine base be located at Cockburn Sound, Western Australia-HMAS Stirling-with a secondary base on the east coast.

The report proposes to retain the approximate present size of the regular army of about 32,000 personnel. The report proposes to base units of the regular army in the Darwin-Tindal area beginning in the early 1990s with at least an infantry battalion and in the longer term a brigade-size formation. In respect of ground surveillance forces, the report notes that there would be a priority for surveillance and reconnaissance elements, particularly for the timely identification of enemy activity during a period of heightened tension or in the early stage of hostilities. The review encourages the further development of the largely reserve regional force surveillance units, including the possibility of increasing the regular army component. In this regard, units of the Townsville 11 Field Force Group, commanded by the dynamic Colonel George Mansford, AM, have deployment exercises planned for September and November 1986 and May 1987. Colonel Mansford proposes to conduct platoon level deployment exercises into the Cape York Peninsula area. These exercises are designed to practise platoons and companies in battle procedure, add realism and variety to training and practice marry-up procedures with regular troops.

The report urges the establishment of an airfield facility on Cape York Peninsula and a new naval facility on the north-west coast of Western Australia. The report identifies the need to conduct a program of sustained exercises in the north with support from the south to identify logistic weaknesses. It is recommended that the Army's Operational Deployment Force, based at Townsville and commanded by the extremely able Brigadier Michael Harris, MC, be further developed.

One of the most important recommendations in the Dibb report is for the rapid expansion of our intelligence and surveillance systems. The report, therefore, gives special attention to the over-the-horizon radar project which offers a very real possibility of allowing continuous monitoring of the great expanses of our sea and air approaches. The report proposes the establishment of at least five such radar systems by the mid-1990s. I urge the Government to give the highest priority to this recommendation.

These are just several of the recommendations contained in the Dibb report. I regard their early implementation as a national priority. To his credit, Paul Dibb has produced a report which attempts to structure the defence forces to meet Australia's strategic circumstances within a realistic budget. It is without any shadow of doubt the most realistic document of its kind in military, political and economic terms ever prepared in Australia. The Northern Territory News in its editorial of 11 June 1986 said:

It is to the enormous credit of Defence Minister, Mr Kim Beazley, probably the best and most far-sighted Defence Minister Australia has had since 1945, that he immediately undertook a review of our strategic priorities. And it is to the enormous discredit of the Opposition coalition that for little more than rank political reason they prefer to stick to the shibboleths of the past than go along with Dibb's recommendations.
Like the Bourbons, the Liberal-National Parties appear to have learned nothing and forgotten everything.
I commend the Government's initiative in implementing the Dibb report. I will follow its implementation with great interest and determination.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Time does not permit me to respond to some of the comments that have already been made as there are only a few minutes left for this debate. A couple of hours before the tabling of the Dibb Report on Australia's Defence Capabilities on 3 June, the head of the Strategic and Defence Studies Centre, Dr Des Ball, was asked by a reporter on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation what he thought the weaknesses of the Dibb report might be. Dr Ball's response was as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: I would say that some of the strategic justifications are probably not as well developed as one would like and there are obvious reasons for that. The whole exercise only took 12 months in which the greater part of the time has been spent on the capability side rather than the strategic rationales. I think that because of that there could well be some uncertainty or doubts arising which would lead to some discussion about really what the strategic rationale of this exercise is.

I am one of those for whom doubts have arisen concerning the strategic rationale of this report. On page 37 of the report, Mr Dibb identifies the first two principal national security interests of Australia as being the avoidance of global conflict and the maintenance of a favourable strategic situation in South East Asia and the South Pacific generally-Australia's sphere of primary strategic interest where developments can affect our national security.

A few years ago the very highly respected Dr Robert O'Neill, formerly head of the Strategic Studies Centre and now head of the respected International Institute for Strategic Studies, considered the same national security interests, and it is interesting to compare his view of an appropriate strategic concept and force structure with those of Mr Dibb. Concerning global conflict, Dr O'Neill emphasised the need for the Western allies to maintain forces for rapid deployment to contain limited outbreaks of conflict or to demonstrate reactive capacity which might deter hostile actions. He argued that Australia had a positive interest to be served by the development of such a capacity and further that it must wish to avoid the negative consequences of perceived unwillingness or incapacity to make some contribution to this wider effort. In regard to the implications of a concern for the security of our region on force structure, Dr O'Neill's views were as follows. I shall quote this at length because of the significance of his remarks and the stark contrast his conclusions make when considered with the Dibb report. He said:

In the event of a major regional or extra-regional threat to ASEAN states, support by Australian naval and air power may help considerably in either deterring or defeating any hostile initiatives. While Australian land power is not likely to be as significant a factor in the operational balance, its deployment in modest form (say a task force) within the region could be important for training from both Australian and ASEAN points of view, for deterrence and for diplomatic purposes . . . It seems to be time to develop Australia's capacity to play a large role in regional affairs . . . Sight should not be lost of a possible need to contribute the modest ground force . . . Unpalatable though the implications of this conclusion may be for many Australians in the aftermath of the Vietnam war, it would be foolish to forswear forever the use of one of their most applicable military strengths, in situations where it could maintain deterrence or tip the balance operationally.
Dr O'Neill went on:

If I may pre-empt one line of criticism of this argument, that I am thereby opening the door to the development of major intervention forces which will consume huge quantities of resources and thereby detract from current capabilities to defend Australia against direct threat-let me reiterate that the scale of force contribution likely to be required from Australia for regional deployment is modest. The defence strengths of regional partners are appreciable against local threats. What they are looking for in time of crisis is supplementation, not suppression. Let me also point out that failure to help maintain a favourable regional environment could require the maintenance of much greater forces to defend Australia. In other words, there is an economic argument to be faced by the strict constructionist of the `defence of Australia' posture.

It should be obvious that this report does not give sufficient importance to our responsibilities in the region or to the effectiveness of a strategic rationale based on effective collective or common security and peace. It has also become obvious that the report has been seen to reflect increasing unwillingness to contribute to a wider Western security effort. I refer, for example, to the comments of the United States Commander in the Pacific, Admiral James Lyons, who has described this report's prescriptions as `insular'. Many comments have referred to the report as being insular. To be fair, this seems to be because Mr Dibb believes that Australia can afford what is best described-we have to admit this in view of the Budget brought down the other night-as an `I am all right, Jack' defence force. That view is apparently shared by the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) who seems to have accepted, in his statement on the report, that realistic Budget parameters should be the overdetermining factor in developing strategic and military policy. That, of course, was shown when the Budget was brought down a couple of nights ago.

I reject that view. This Government should determine what our interests are as a nation and how they are best to be pursued and protected. It should determine its defence budget on the basis of the realities of our international and regional strategic environment. Money should then be allocated on that basis and not in the inverted fashion of setting a politically defined domestic budget and then determining which targets we will meet and which obligations we will jettison. But, of course, to proposed such a course of action to this Government after the savage blow that it dealt defence in the 1986-87 Budget handed down two nights ago is obviously wishful thinking. In the Budget defence has been placed in a position where it could face an actual negative growth rate over the next 12 months.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is nonsense.

—It is a possibility. The Budget has made a mockery of the Dibb report and has called for a minimum annual real term growth rate of 3 per cent. That is a fact. It will mean that our defence forces will not be able adequately to defend our area on direct military interest, let alone to project force into the area of primary strategic interest in our own interests or to assist our allies.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government should remind itself and the nation that the defence of the country is, in the last instance, the most important of a Federal government's responsibilities and that at the moment programs which duplicate State responsibilities or are essential only in terms of favourable public opinion polls are being funded at the expense of adequate Defence Force development. The Minister claims that the Dibb report is an intellectually complex and rigorous analysis-a significant intellectual achievement-but complexity, clarity and consistency are not as important as the substance of the rationale and the final recommendations.

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! It being 12.45 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with sessional order 106a. The debate may be resumed at a later hour. The honourable member will have leave to continue his speech when the debate is resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mayer Ms H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House approves the Government's commitment to develop policies and programs to improve opportunities for young Australians in education and training, employment, health and housing, and its decision to put in place income support arrangements which will make those opportunities available to disadvantaged youth in particular.

In moving this motion today I wish to draw the attention of the House to the development of policies and programs in education and training and in income support in particular. Before I do that I want to look at the situation that existed before 1983. Prior to 1983 the retention rate in schools and in educational institutions generally was appallingly low, and that augured very badly for the future of this country. We were looking at having a large number of people growing into adulthood with neither the educational basis nor the training in skills that would allow us to have a competent and creative work force. We had instead government policies which ignored the interests of young people, which provided little or nothing for them, which indulged in the rhetoric of excellence without backing that up with money, and which year by year was taking money away from tertiary and post-secondary education. It was actually ending up in the private schools system-a pretty interesting point. Young people were becoming very depressed about their chances to obtain useful employment and therefore began to see little or no point in working at secondary school in order to achieve nothing very much when they left. It became not only disappointing for teachers to see promising young people leaving school at the earliest possible opportunity but also it became increasingly difficult to motivate students to tackle difficult parts of the curriculum. Resources in the schools, particularly in the government schools, were becoming depleted and there was very little imagination, creativity or excitement in the system.

In 1983 this Government identified many of the problems in the education, training and income support areas which had effectively denied many young people the opportunity to have a fair chance in life. Retention rates in schools, participation in a meagre range of training and post-compulsory education programs, the lack of resources going to these areas and a confused, confusing and inadequate array of support measures militated against the chances of many of our young people to do anything but join the ranks of the unemployed.

A number of factors worked against young people from low income families continuing at school and going on to post-secondary education. The most glaring of these was the difference between the income support available to students remaining at school and the unemployment benefit available to those 16- and 17-year-olds who left school but did not obtain work. There was a difference of $27 a week between those two rates: $23 a week for secondary students from low income families and $45 rising to $50 a week for similar young people on the unemployment benefit. This was a substantial reason to discontinue schooling. As life became tougher for low income families pressure could be and often was put on young people to leave school because at the very worst they would be contributing $50 a week to the family income. The result of that, of course, was that many students who on an income-tested basis would have qualified for tertiary education assistance, had they finished secondary school, chose to leave instead, thus denying themselves the necessary qualifications for obtaining work in the first place and improving their life chances in the second place.

Recognising that this could lead only to a long term deficiency in the ability and skills of our work force and an increasing number of severely disadvantaged adults in the years to come, the Government established the rationalisation of income support as one of the major parts of its Priority One youth strategy. The three main education-related income support schemes have been brought together as Austudy, an age-related income support scheme for students engaged in secondary or post-secondary education. To be phased in over the years 1986 to 1988, the result will be that there will be no difference between education-related income support and the unemployment benefit. A similar scheme for young people 18 years and over is being considered at the moment.

I go back to that difference of $27 a week for the children of low income families-$23 a week if they stayed at school and $50 a week if they left and did nothing. We have been bringing that up-this year to $35, next year to $40 and in 1988 to $50-so that there will be no financial disincentive for 16- and 17-year-olds either at secondary school or engaged in post-secondary education to continue with that education. For the first time we have a living away from home allowance for secondary students who fulfil the strict conditions for the young homeless allowance, or who are unable to live at home. We know, and it is becoming more public every day, that a number of young people find it impossible to live at home, for a number of reasons. It may be because they are physically abused, because they are psychologically maltreated, because they are asked to leave by one or the other of their parents, who may or may not be their biological parents, or because they are sexually abused.

Before this Government came to power those young people had nothing. They had no right to social security benefits; they had no right to an education allowance; they had nothing. They now have income support which will enable them to stay at school and to live away from home. Of course there is a very strict set of conditions for the provision of this support. We do not wish, any more than any other government would wish, to encourage young people to leave home lightly and irresponsibly, but we do believe it is imperative that the Government take notice of young people who are unable to live at home. By 1988, when the desired commonality will have been achieved for nearly all rates, those rates will be indexed annually and linked to maintain relativities so that they will not be at the mercy of budgetary constraints; they will not be left to rot away, as some allowances have been. They will be indexed and they will maintain their value.

Assured income support at a reasonable level for the children of low income families will assist those young people and their families to plan a future based on a sound educational background and salable skills. It is not with pleasure that people who have low incomes see their children leaving school, see them jobless, see them bored, see them wasting the talents that they have. For many of those families it is a painful experience. This kind of incomes support, which will mean that that is not necessary, will have the approval of the families affected as well as the young people themselves and will reduce the tensions that are an inevitable part of trying to break up an income into very small pieces.

None of this would have been any good at all had we not at the same time taken initiatives to increase the number of post-secondary places available to the students who want them and to increase the range, variety and quality of courses available in both secondary and post-secondary schools. There is absolutely no point in having a standard curriculum which does not recognise both the growing nature of the work opportunities available and the interests and concerns of young people. The number of tertiary places, for example, will increase next year-they are budgeted for in this year's Budget-by between 2,700 and 3,300, bringing the increase in the number of places in tertiary institutions in the 1985-1987 triennium to a possible 29,600, or 9,600 more than we had actually forecast. That is an 11 per cent increase in the number of tertiary places available to young people.

Retention rates at secondary schools, of course, have increased over the period of our Government. We had in 1980 a participation rate of 35.4 per cent for 15- to 19-year-olds; we have now a 41.2 per cent participation rate for 15- to 19-year-olds. We had in 1985 a 46.4 per cent apparent retention rate until the final year of school-a very significant increase. Those retention rates are the results of some very carefully tailored funding to allow young people who have perhaps lost their way a bit to take part in catch-up courses, in transition courses, and in all sorts of educational opportunities which will lead them back into the mainstream. As a result of that carefully tailored funding 145,000 more young people are continuing their education than when we came to office in 1983.

The long term effect of that increase is almost incalculable but we should understand that firstly we will have a more skilled work force. We will also have more competent young people-competent not only in their work but also in their daily lives. Greater value will be placed on staying in education. We will have, of course, a great deal more demand for post-secondary courses and skills training. That will give us an opportunity that we have been denied for many years-an opportunity to take advantage of the talents and abilities of our young people in a way that has not been possible previously. Apprenticeships also have been paid very considerable attention because this area of skilled work has suffered some very severe setbacks. Special support has been given to employers because the cost of releasing apprentices to their trade courses and to their off-the-job training in schools has become an increasing burden which has often resulted in employers not seeing their way clear to take on apprentices. In 1985-86 76,000 apprentices were assisted through the employer rebates and in 1986-87 we are looking at 89,000 apprentices being assisted. When we realise that many apprenticeships have not been the subject of such assistance, we are looking at a fair addition to our skilled work force.

I have spoken about the Government's program of reform of educational opportunities and allowances for young people but I would like to turn now to the challenges and needs of young job seekers and the Government's labour market assistance programs for young people. Young people have shared in the buoyant labour market conditions over the last three years. Parallel to the increase in retention rates at school and increased participation in tertiary education and full time post-secondary training, there has been a rise in teenage employment as well as a rise in the number of those seeking work. Total teenage employment grew strongly over the past year with a greater number of teenagers combining part time work with study or vocational training. Teenage full time employment rose by 8,300, or 1.9 per cent, over the last year. It is not enormous and it is certainly not the figure we would like to have, but it has reached that level and it is rising. The interesting thing is that so many teenagers now combine part time study and part time work. That is an encouraging trend because it means that young people are beginning to take advantage of the educational opportunities that exist and at the same time are seeking to support themselves through part time work.

However, the unemployment rate for teenagers remains at 22 per cent. That is caused by the number of school leavers seeking their first job. It was, however, 25.1 per cent in 1983, so we are down a little. The number of teenagers finding work has increased, but so too has the number who want a job, who want to join the labour force. All in all, I believe that the policies we have implemented since 1983 have indicated our commitment to youth, our commitment to improving the desperate position that they were in and our commitment to improving the overall capacity of Australians to contribute to this country. I guess the Priority One program is an overall label for our great collection of youth employment, youth training and youth education policies.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is an advertising campaign.
—I can tell from that interjection that the honourable member really does not understand what the Priority One program is about.
—They do not understand young people.
—They do not understand people; that is absolutely right.
—They do not care about young people.

—That is obvious; they never have. We have had to implement all of those programs in three years in order to save our young people from the desperate situation that they were in. Priority One encompasses the income support rationalisation--
—We are still waiting for that.

—The income support rationalisation is already in place. It encompasses also education initiatives, including the increase in places. My friend opposite might wish to remember that there are 145,000 more young people in full time education than there were at the beginning of 1983. That might be some indication of the advantage that is being taken of the policies and programs that we have implemented. We have implemented a program to improve the worth and attractiveness of completing secondary education. We have improved the range of courses available. We have implemented a range of courses to tide young people over if they have left school as discouraged students and wish to return. We have improved the basic education programs in both primary and secondary schools through resources agreements with the States, and the Australian traineeship system is beginning to bear its first fruit. So we have looked at all of those areas for young people-income support, a range of educational opportunities and a range of skills training programs. I know that the motion's seconder, the honourable member for Jagajaga (Mr Staples), will be paying attention to some additional policies, especially in the area of housing and health initiatives. I believe that this motion befits the times. We have brought down a Budget which was difficult to bring down, but we live in difficult times. However, our commitment to youth, our commitment to enabling young people to achieve their aims, to fulfil their objectives and become contributing citizens of this country in every way is unarguable.
—Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion with pleasure and reserve my right to speak at a later time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shack Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —This motion was first listed for debate in the Notice Paper in February 1985. Its terms are effusive and certainly the speech that we have just heard from the honourable member for Chisholm (Ms Mayer) is very approving of the Government's supposed commitment to young Australians. We are now dealing with it in August 1986, eighteen months after it was first proposed. I hasten to say that that is not the fault of the mover, and that is not the point I wish to make; it is the fault of the parliamentary program. But the 18- month delay since the motion was first put down has provided us with yet another insight into the way in which this Government operates and into one of its fundamental weaknesses. It is a weakness that is becoming increasingly apparent to the Australian electorate and it is a weakness that will see it driven from office.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Deputy Speaker, how does this Government operate? Firstly, it is a government of the big public relations self-promotion exercise; a government of the big sell. It is a government of the public relations extravaganza. What is its weakness? The weakness is that there is a yawning gap between the Government's full-blown rhetoric and its performance. Nowhere is the gap between rhetoric and performance more apparent than in the area of youth policy, which is the subject of this motion. A year ago, almost to the day, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made his great play for the youth vote. He made his television address to the nation announcing the Priority One youth package. We have had it all since then including the balloons and the whistles. We have had the hype about the traineeships and we have had the phone-in campaign. Remember that expensive con job-ring up Bob and tell him what you think! We have had the billboard and the cinema advertisements: `Priority One; we are the one'. We have had the rock concerts. We have even had Bob on Countdown with Molly. We have seen all the balloons and heard all the whistles relating to the Priority One program: `Hey man, we are hip, we know where you are coming from; we are attuned to the problems of young people and we are going to solve all those problems'.

Hundreds of thousands of taxpayers' dollars have been wasted on this sort of self-promotional rubbish. It is designed to convince and con young Australians, that the Australian Labor Party is the party for them. That is all the rhetoric. We should put that behind us and look at the performance of this Government in the area of youth policy. On every count of this motion the Government has failed young Australians and will continue to fail them while it remains in office.

The honourable member's motion covered five specific policy areas which particularly impact on young people: First, education and training; secondly, employment; thirdly, health; fourthly, housing; and, fifthly, income support. The honourable member for Chisholm bravely tried to argue that in these five areas this Government has shown unique concern for young people and has delivered special benefits to them. I accept that the honourable member's heart is in the right place but her efforts have been in vain. The facts rather than the hype, the realities rather than the rhetoric, reveal a completely different picture. They show that young Australians are having the screws put on them by this Government and that its policies are worsening rather than improving the position of young people. For every minor initiative, for every dodgy promotional program launched in the name of the Government's love and concern for young Australians, a multitude of problems has intensified the social, psychological and economic pressures on young people.

I would like quickly to run through the honourable member's five-point checklist. In running through it I shall give the House a taste of the other side of the story, the down side of the Government's impact on the lives of young Australians. The honourable member spoke long about the Budget and the initiatives that have been taken in it. If we look at the area of education and training, we see that this Budget cuts school funding. Almost every part of the Commonwealth schools budget has been cut. Recurrent funding to government schools is down by 1.6 per cent; capital funding for government schools is down by 7.2 per cent; capital funding for non-government schools is down; and the funding for a whole series of joint programs is down by 38.6 per cent. The multicultural education program has been scrapped; the English as a second language program has been slashed; and the ethnic schools program has been restricted. All of this directly impacts on the hundreds of thousands of young people in Australian schools today.

Tertiary fees have been introduced. Senator Ryan and the honourable member for Jagajaga (Mr Staples), who will speak shortly, can fudge all they like-the plain fact is that they have reintroduced tertiary fees and students themselves will be financing the gap left in university and college of advanced education budgets as the Government begins to roll back its financial commitment to the higher education sector. The traineeship scheme-Pete Steedman's great Priority One flagship-is an absolute shambles. The fundamental problems of union resistance and the Government's lack of success in negotiating trainee wages remain, discouraging the private employer involvement crucial to the scheme's success. The benefits of the scheme remain very much potential rather than real.

Remember what we were promised? We were promised 10,000 traineeships for last financial year. In August, a month after last financial year, only 2,025 traineeship places have been filled. The Government talks about 4,000 places having been created but only half of those created have been filled, and that falls well short of half the 10,000. What about the 75,000 traineeships that we are supposed to have by 1988? This Budget provides funding for only a further 15,000 places and, if this Budget is as successful in funding those schemes as the projections for last year, we can look askance at the traineeship program.

Let me turn to unemployment, or employment as the honourable member for Chisholm would have us believe. Youth unemployment is higher now than it was when the Prime Minister spoke a year ago. In August 1985 the Prime Minister announced Priority One. The unemployment rate for 15- to 19-year-olds looking for full time work was 21.5 per cent. Last month's preliminary figure was 22.7 per cent-a full 1.2 per cent increase in youth unemployment. The average length of unemployment for 15- to 19-year-olds is now 29.1 weeks, and 46.2 weeks for 20- to 24-year-olds. The Government's youth employment policies are simply not working. Forget about the hype; the facts prove the case.

I turn to health. I am waiting to hear what the honourable member for Jagajaga has to say about health, but young people, like all Australians, have been hit by a 25 per cent increase in compulsory health insurance costs as a result of the Government's Budget decision to increase the Medicare levy. If we turn to housing, young people make up one of the primary groups being hardest hit by the spiralling rents resulting from the tightening of conditions in the rental market since the Government announced its decision to end negative gearing. Rent is probably the biggest cost for young people striking out and setting up independently. It is well within the Government's power to do something about the end of negative gearing and the rent hikes which have followed and will continue to follow. So if we look at rental housing, young people have been disadvantaged, not advantaged, since this Government has been in office. Young home buyers have also been disadvantaged, not advantaged, since this Government came to office. Young people attempting to break out of the rental market and into their first home of their own are finding it incredibly difficult to cope with the high interest rates they are now facing as a result of this Government's economic policies.

The fifth area that the honourable member raised concerned income support. We accept that the Austudy income support package for young people in late secondary and tertiary education does have some merit, but the Government still has not faced up to the fact that the different means tests applying to education benefits and the unemployment benefit will continue to disadvantage students, even when the gap between the levels of Austudy and the unemployment benefit are eliminated. That problem has to be faced up to as well.

Let me go beyond the five points mentioned in the honourable member's motion. As I said earlier, youth unemployment is rising. It can be expected to rise even more and at a faster rate in the coming financial year as a result of the Government's economic mismanagement. The Government has admitted that unemployment will rise. It is not being candid, however, about the fact that young people especially will be particularly disadvantaged in the unemployment growth downturn. New labour force entrants, overwhelmingly young people, will suffer most as new hirings taper off and job opportunities consequently become scarcer. More young people will be thrown on the dole scrapheap, and all of the negative psychological and economic problems attendant on that will follow. The education system will hardly be a receptive haven for the growing number of young people. Thousands of them are already being locked out of our tertiary education system, unable to get the education and training they want, which they need to improve themselves and their prospects in later life.

To wrap it all up, on top of all this young Australians are being hit hard by dramatic rises in the cost of living. Inflation is unacceptably high, leading to higher prices month by month. On top of general price inflation the Government, with this Budget, is throwing its own additional cost hikes into the system. I have mentioned the health insurance cost hike, thanks to the increased Medicare levy and tertiary fees. The increase in petrol excise of 3c a litre will severely impact on highly mobile young people-driving to universities, driving to work and conducting their leisure activities on weekends. It would be hard enough as it is, without this extra increase.

Look at just one minor area of consumption relating to young people. The 10 per cent excise on flavoured milk, for heaven's sake, on Big M, and on fruit juice and cider, will further subject young people to additional cost hikes. That is a result of the direct policies of this Government. We have spiralling rents due to the end of negative gearing, and higher overseas travel costs thanks to the drop of the Australian dollar. When I was a young person, and when the honourable member for Jagajaga was a young person, it was almost an institution to save up and go overseas to broaden one's horizons, to backpack around Europe or the United Kingdom, to get that experience and then come back and take up higher education studies. They are not within a bull's roar of what we were able to do because of the fall of the Australian dollar, thanks to the Government's economic policies. I turn to another area of consumer purchases. The bankcard rate since this Government came to power has gone from 18 per cent to 21 per cent. If people put their jeans and sweaters on bankcard, they can thank this Government for a proportion of the increased price that they are now paying.

So quite frankly, Mr Deputy Speaker, we reject this motion. It is an embarrassment to the Government and I wonder why the honourable member who moved it did not take it off the Notice Paper 18 months ago. Young people are being left only one thing by this Government-a very high national debt, expected to be $1,000 billion next year. Young Australians will be pleased to note that their share is about $6,000 each.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Staples Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with considerable pleasure that I support this motion of the honourable member for Chisholm (Ms Mayer), a member who has dedicated a lot of work in her electorate to the development of opportunities for all young people. It is also worth noting that at the time notice of this motion was given, 25 February 1985, this Government had made substantial improvements in a short time to opportunities for young people. But there was more to follow throughout that year, and indeed further improvements have been made in this 1986-87 Budget as well. However it should be noted that this Government did not have to do much to create improvements because the Liberal and National parties ignored young people in the community and in general terms their policies led our young people into the fear of unemployment, poor education, sub-minimal incomes and a powerless status on the fringe of this society. It is important for all to note that the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack) failed to tell us what Opposition members actually did in their periods in office over the last four or five decades; nor did he say what they had failed to do. He could not point to one single positive thing that they had done. Furthermore he failed again, because he does not have the answers, to point out what the Opposition would do now. That is what people have to recognise: The Opposition failed to do anything before and it does not have any ideas now.

SPEECH.PARA: That failed government was made up of people such as the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), known at that time as the world's worst Treasurer and today known as the world's worst Opposition Leader, and the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown)-or Diamond Valley, as he was until I came along-was known across the land as the person who tried to close down the community youth support scheme. He was then the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs. I should not be too hard on him because he was only one of a long string of failures in that Government who contributed to the highest level of unemployment, including youth unemployment, in Australia since the Depression. At a time of record levels of unemployment he tried to abolish CYSS but, thankfully, the Australian electorate and the Australian Labor Party stopped that. I ask: Which parties tried to turn public education into welfare education? It was the Liberal Party and the National Party, and they would do it again. Which parties downgraded the tertiary education system and tried to bring in tertiary tuition fees and have said they would do it again? That is right, it is the Liberal and National parties. Which government made tertiary education the privilege of the rich? Which government downgraded the tertiary education assistance scheme allowance from 22.6 of average weekly earnings in 1974 to 15.4 per cent of average weekly earnings in 1982? Yes, right again, it was the Liberal and National parties.

Here is another question that should be easy for everyone here to answer. Which parties in government imported skilled migrants, while they watched our own apprenticeship system fall into oblivion and at the same time failed to train our own young people in Australia? I say `imported', not `migrated', because that is the way they treat people-just like production goods, just like machines. Right again-I hear the echoes of the shadow Ministers over there from the Liberal and National parties. Their only solution to youth unemployment, and all unemployment, was to cut wages, especially youth wages, and which parties' only solution is to do it again? The Liberal and National parties. Which parties in government ran pilot schemes for three years, year after year, for youth emergency accommodation while our kids lived under bridges, in concrete pipes or wherever they could find some shelter for the night? The Liberal and National parties. Why did they not bring in a supported accommodation assistance scheme, as this Government has done? That is a small glimpse of the dismal record of the former discredited government of the Liberal and National parties, that dismal Opposition that sits over there today and has the gall to criticise this Government for its role and its good work in dealing with young Australians.

That is the record that young Australians and Australians generally have to compare with the record of this Government. Quite frankly I do not have the time-I have only 11 minutes left-to go through the record of this Government, but let me make a few simple points. On Sunday, 18 August 1985 in West Heidelberg, in my electorate of Jagajaga, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) nationally launched Priority One-Young Australia. He said that young people are Australia's most important resource. Priority One-Young Australia announced to all Australians at that time that our young people are a vital and dynamic section of our society and our economy. They are not only the future; they are also an intrinsic element of the present. All Australians should recognise this role and this status of young people today. They are important not just for the future but for the present as well.

These are not empty sentiments, because Priority One has brought together the mish-mash of the old programs and rationalised them and revitalised them, then enmeshed them with a range of new programs to cover comprehensively the major elements of youth needs. I refer to education, income support, training and information and support services. Since the Hawke Government came to office, a mere 41 months ago, we have seen this commitment to young people put into dollars, bricks and mortar and recognition. This Government has encouraged more young people to stay at school in order to build their skills, employability and future. In 1982, under the present Opposition, only 36.3 per cent of our young people completed Year 12. Today, only 41 months later, the figure is 46.4 per cent, and 64,000 more teenagers are in post-compulsory education. They are staying there because this Government has given them better schools, more interesting and relevant studies and more financial security for themselves and their families. It is honouring its commitment to young Australians.

This Labor Government has honoured its commitment to increase tertiary education places. By the end of 1987 the number of higher education places will have increased by 36,800 to 299,900-a phenomenal growth of 14 per cent. There are now an estimated 145,000 more young people in post-compulsory education than there were 41 months ago. That is a 17 per cent increase. What this means is that seventeen more young people in every 100 are now furthering their education than was the case 41 months ago. That is only the beginning. People should think what that will mean to Australia's future prospects for a stable society and a dynamic new order of economic and industrial development. Young Australians have been able to take these opportunities provided by their Labor Government because it has increased expenditure and improved accessibility of student support schemes. Only the wealthy could keep their kids at school under the former Government, often with the assistance of the perks of their employment. We are now putting a stop to those perks, as well. Now more ordinary Australian kids are getting a fair go.

I turn now to training and employment. Youth unemployment is a major concern of the Government and of the community and a major target of the Priority One strategy. Priority One is indeed increasing young people's competitiveness by providing new skills, training and higher education levels and this is assisted, despite what the shadow Minister says, by the Australian traineeship system and the rationalisation of wage subsidy programs into a single program. We have also seen the targeting of assistance to those most disadvantaged and an increased apprenticeship intake. The honourable member for Tangney talked about having only 4,000 traineeships. That is 4,000 more than the previous Government ever put on the ground or even attempted to produce, and that is the bottom line that people have to consider. Of course all these developments would have been so much harder to obtain if the Government had not been able to develop economic growth and growth in employment which has stood out ahead of the world. Contrasting that with the record of those opposite is superfluous. They despise and denigrate the role of the community employment program. Thankfully their views are rejected by this Government and by young people and the electorate in general.

The income support program of the previous government had gaps all over the place. It used acronyms and schemes like band-aids on a sinking boat. In effect, it often took band-aids from one hole to place them over new leaks. It was a disastrous and confusing mess. But this Government has restructured and increased the value of income support for young people. In 1986 the secondary assistance scheme payments have been raised, bridging the gap between TEAS and the unemployment benefit, although these benefits have also been increased. In 1988 the basic rates for 16- and 17-year-old secondary and tertiary students and the unemployed will be at the same level. Older young students will be getting parity with the unemployed. That is a major breakthrough, but the Opposition would have neither the brains nor the desire to implement such a scheme. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard tables that deal with the participation, retention and employment rates of young people.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I consider information and support services to be of the most immediate value. Young people have always had a culture of their own-their language, their music and many of their attitudes. Governments and older members of society in general have until now failed to recognise not only the culture of young people but also their needs and their potential contribution to our society. This Labor Government, not the Liberal and National parties, has introduced information and support services specifically targeted at young people for their use. It is true that already an extensive range of support services in the community is provided by government and many non-government sources. However, those services have been traditionally delivered in a disjointed and ad hoc fashion. That is because there has not been any effective Commonwealth co-ordination. This Australian Labor Government has constructively brought together many of those services. We are seeing that now-on the ground, in the streets, in shopping centres and in clubs; wherever we go where young people are. Under the Priority One banner we have seen the establishment by this Government of Commonwealth Employment Service youth access centres. These centres, which will be progressively expanded throughout the nation, are already providing information on labour markets, education, income support, accommodation and referral services. Youth access centre workers are trained to communicate with young people, their teachers and parents. This is vital in ensuring that the services provided by government are known of and used effectively.

SPEECH.PARA: I pay tribute at this stage to the dedication of CYSS workers. Under this Government CYSS workers and people using CYSS have been guaranteed security. I pay special tribute to all those local management committees and project workers throughout Australia, particularly those in my own electorate who work tirelessly for the unemployed with those at the Project For Unemployed Self Help and the Youth and Others Unemployed Resources Centre within the Bundoora-Watsonia Employment Development Project. The tremendous contribution those people are making to the young people of Jagajaga should not be underestimated. It does not stop there. We have youth services and development programs, youth worker training schemes, the national campaign against drug abuse, access to public housing for young people, the supported accommodation assistance program for homeless young people, the Government's commitment to the International Year of Shelter for the Homeless and support for young people with disabilities. On and on it goes. I have not the time to go through it all. A range of Government departments have revamped their information services so that these services appeal to and communicate better with young people. I pay special tribute to the Department of Social Security, the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations, the Prime Minister's own department, the Department of Education and the Attorney-General's Department. Their involvement and efforts are a direct result of their recognition of what the International Year of Youth was all about.

While on the subject of the International Youth Year, let me say this to the House and the older members of society in general: Do not underestimate the strength and ability of young people as individuals or as a section of societies. Unfortunately, International Youth Year was seen as a year solely for young people. But it was not. It was a year for all of us, young and old, to begin to understand that young people in Australia, young people throughout the world, have a role and a status in society today that must be recognised by all. It is up to all of us in the older society who do have the power to share that power with young people, as it is their right. That applies to the Federal Government, to all of us here, to State government, to local government, to the local football and netball club committees, to the school, to the work-place, and, indeed, to the family. I say to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and to others listening: `Do not ignore young people; give them their rights; give them your ears'.

I must say in closing that this Government and in particular our Prime Minister has done more than any other government, than any other Prime Minister. Having just returned from the Commonwealth Youth Affairs Council meeting in Guyana I can say on an international scale that our Prime Minister has done more to listen to and involve young people in his society than just about any other Prime Minister in the world. As we all know, our young people, in common with their peers throughout the world have an abhorrence of nuclear weapons and a desire for disarmament and peace. That is the greatest hope of this world in the history of humanity. I ask the Prime Minister on behalf of Australian youth to re-examine the Budget and take note of the concern of young people to see the cessation of the arms race and, in particular, their concern for French nuclear testing in the South Pacific, and have regard to their overwhelming objection to uranium sales to France,

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper Mr P.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just a few short days ago we saw the spectre of the Prime Minister of this nation softening it up for what was to be a hard Budget. He mentioned that we were in a wartime crisis situation, that the country was in real difficulty and that it needed tough policies for tough times. For once I agree with the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that this nation faces a political, economic and social crisis of truly mammoth proportions. We have seen a walk-out by three Labor members from the House. We see a bitter revolt by Australian Labor Party factional members opposed to the Government's continued refusal to take any notice of party policy and the plea by the member for Jagajaga (Mr Staples) a moment ago is a public indication of the divisions in the ALP over various issues.

SPEECH.PARA: Our dollar is virtually worthless with the latest crash taking it down to just a shade over 60 US cents. I am afraid that soon Monopoly money will be worth more than our ailing currency under Labor. Any financial newspaper in the nation will show that share prices are plummeting and the market is nervous. Interest rates are set to go to an all-time high, bankrupting even more businesses and causing people to lose their homes and to be thrown out on to the street.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would remind the honourable member that he is rather extending his views away from the subject of the debate.

—Thank you for your guidance, Mr Deputy Speaker. I will continue to point out that Labor's dole queues will lengthen even further and Australia's young people, the people whom we are concerned about, will in fact be injured and will be disadvantaged further by this Government's continued policies. In the Treasurer's Budget Speech, Mr Keating himself foreshadowed a growth in unemployment and bearing the brunt of government policy will be Australia's future, Australia's youth. The Treasurer may well say that we are about to become a banana republic but a visitor to our country recently said that Australia is the only Third World country where you can still drink the water. That may well be so, but it does not assist our young people, many of whom under Labor have absolutely no prospect of ever finding productive employment.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Chisholm (Ms Mayer) may have been well-intentioned when she gave notice of her motion to the House on 22 February 1985 and it is interesting to note that that was the last day that this Government permitted private members to give notices of motions to be debated before the people of Australia. Vital matters were involved in many cases but the Government has prevented members from continuing publicly to give notices of motion and has prevented the broadcasting of them. In the light of current circumstances the motion of the honourable member for Chisholm becomes little better than a sick joke. She asks this House to approve the Government's commitment to developing policies and programs to improve certain opportunities for young Australians. No doubt the honourable member is wishing she did not give notice of that motion and she is regretting very much that it was necessary for her to stand up in the House and speak on her motion today.

We can all recall the fanfare of publicity just over 12 months ago on 18 August 1985 when Prime Minister Hawke announced, and I quote: `The welfare and encouragement of young Australians is my first priority as Prime Minister'. Certainly it is a laudable and commendable aim. Everyone on both sides of the House would agree, but once again, Mr Deputy Speaker, this outgoing Labor Government has been long on rhetoric and short on action. A central feature of Priority One was the 10,000 traineeships which were to be created in 1986 building up to a total of 75,000 traineeships by Australia's bicentennial year, 1988. Unfortunately, and our regret on this side of the House is genuine, for Australia's school leavers the Government's program has to date been an abject failure. I understand that fewer than 4,000 traineeships have so far been provided in 1986.

What is going to happen in the four months or so between now and the end of the year? Is the Government seriously going to tell us and those young people who may be listening to this broadcast that it is going to find another 6,000 traineeships in the next four months? I suspect, and indeed the people of Australia would appreciate, that the Government cannot meet its objective and that Priority One has been an expensive and abject failure.

Some people, however, reaped a bonanza from Mr Forty-Eight-he used to be Mr Seventy-Eight-when he ensured that the Australian Labor Party's Victorian advertising agency and media outlets obtained the sum of $500,000 through a glossy advertising campaign. Priority One, sadly, unfortunately, tragically for the youth of Australia, has been a flop. The printing of expensive publications and the production of expensive television advertisements have not achieved their aims. Priority One has failed and the youth of Australia, once again, have been cynically used by this Government as a scapegoat.

Let us not talk in generalities. I think we should look at the youth unemployment figures in Australia. August 1985 was the month last year when Priority One was introduced, and at that time 21.7 per cent-or 121,600 young people aged between 15 and 19-were unemployed. July 1986 saw the situation worsen to 22.7 per cent or, numerically, 128,300. That means that in the time of this so-called Priority One program the unemployment percentage for young people has risen by one per cent. The Government stands exposed. The situation has wor- sened. It proves what we in the Opposition say, namely, that Priority One has simply not been a success.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a failure.
—It is a failure.

—A failure, as the shadow Ministers mention. Let us look at what we did when we were the Government. We hear over and over again from the Labor Party that things have got better since it came to office. The average period of youth unemployment in March 1983-Mr Deputy Speaker, you would be aware that that was the fateful month when Labor crawled into office-was 33 weeks. The situation has blown out, has worsened, I suppose a bit like Treasurer Keating's Budget deficits, to 51.9 weeks in March 1986. It means an unemployment situation where the average young person was unemployed for 33 weeks before Labor came to office and now for 51.9 weeks after three years of Labor mismanagement and misrule.
—It is disgraceful.

—It is disgraceful, as my colleague the honourable member for Bass, Mr Smith, accurately points out to the House. The people of Australia will condemn this Government for what has not been done, for the way in which young people have, in effect, been ignored. Another tragedy is that the Treasurer's Budget guesstimates-he called them estimates but they are only guesstimates-for unemployment and employment over the next 12 months expose the soft underbelly of the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us go back and look particularly at my electorate of Fisher and the situation there over the past 12 months. We have a number of regional offices of the Commonwealth Employment Service and they do a marvellous job. We have Mr Reg Wheeler, who is the manager of the Caboolture Job Centre, and Mr Roy Hose, who is the manager of the Strathpine Job Centre. These two managers and their staff do a wonderful job getting young people into jobs. There are other regional offices which also cover certain parts of my electorate. These people, Mr Deputy Speaker, do a wonderful job and what this Government should be doing is bringing forward policies which are going to assist young people into employment.

In June 1985 in the age group 15-19 in the Caboolture area 395 young people were unemployed. In June 1986 this had increased to 584, an increase of 189 or 32.6 per cent. The age group 20-24 had 281 unemployed in June 1985 and 439 in June 1986, an increase of 158 or 35.99 per cent.
