TALK.START.PARA: —He deserves an extension; it is a great speech.

—I thank my colleague and I also thank the Minister for moving the motion. What is this Government saying to the young people of Caboolture, whose unemployment rate in the 15-19 age group has increased to 32.6 per cent and in the 20-24 age group to 35.99 per cent? This Government stands exposed for what it is. This is not a government interested in young people; it is a government interested in its own public perception; it is a government which is prepared to spend taxpayers' money to create an impression that it is doing something, when in fact it is not.

SPEECH.PARA: I have mainly concentrated on employment, and in the remaining few minutes available to me I would like to touch on some other areas. In education, up to 33,000 young Australians qualified to enter tertiary institutions have not been allocated places and yet, when Premier Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen at the Queensland National Party Conference this year announced the establishment of the Bond University of Applied Technology, the Minister for Education, Senator Ryan, and numerous other government figures criticised this new opportunity for young people. It simply is not good enough for the Government to rely on and to expound ideology when education opportunities of young people are lacking. We in the Opposition support the principle that young, able-bodied people should work for the dole. In fact, in a recent survey 92 per cent supported this principle, but the left wing of the Australian Labor Party will not permit this to occur and, consequently, this policy, which is supported by vast numbers of Australians, will not be implemented.

The motion of the honourable member for Chisholm also mentions what the Government has done for young people's health. Let us remember what the Prime Minister's promise was on Medicare prior to the 1984 election. He mentioned, in an effort to get back into government, that the Government would not increase in its next term of office the Medicare levy from the existing level of one per cent. What did the Treasurer announce in the Budget this year? He has increased the Medicare levy from 1 December 1986 from a level of one per cent to a level of 1.25 per cent, and young people-those who are fortunate enough to have a job-will, like those in the rest of the community, be paying this additional impost.

It is important to remember that the Labor Party, by bringing in Medicare, has utterly and completely destroyed Queensland's free hospitals. People used to be able to go to Queensland's free hospitals for medical or hospital treatment and not pay anything but, under this Labor Government, they will in fact pay 1.25 per cent after 1 December.

In housing, young people have suffered as a result of Labor's continuing high interest rate policy. Young people need to go to building societies, and recently building societies have been lending very much less than they were previously. Australia's future is its youth. We are going through the most difficult economic period in our history. We need statesmanship, we need leadership, we need positive policies to help young people. We do not need posturing, we do not need strutting across the world stage; what we must have is a definite, firm decisive commitment to assist young people. The people of Australia demand it. This Government will have to implement it, otherwise it will undoubtedly be defeated at the next election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened to the speeches of the two honourable members opposite in this debate and, apart from a passing reference by the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper), there was not one constructive suggestion from the Opposition on how it would tackle the youth unemployment problem. I will go back shortly to the suggestion of the honourable member for Fisher. The basic problem we have to understand not only in the youth area but within the Australian economy is the narrow range of our economy that we inherited from about 30 years of conservative governments. The fact is that Australian industry ceased to exist under them and if you trace the history you will find that the industry that we used to have was highly protected, highly subsidised, and in the words of the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones), who put it quite accurately: `If you ever wanted to see a working museum you only had to look at Australian industry'. Added to that, the overvalued dollar ensured that eventually it was going to collapse, and collapse it did in the early 1980s. I have figures here, which I will get to shortly, to support that.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us go back to the honourable member for Fisher's one suggestion, about making the unemployed work for the dole. Assuming the work is there-that is a fair enough assumption if you are going to proceed with this particular idea-and taking as a very generous allowance one full time supervisor for every 100 unemployed people, 6,000 full time supervisors would be necessary. Those 6,000 full time supervisors would be paid, say, $20,000 a year, without add-on costs. That is another $120m to be found in the Budget. Honourable members opposite always talk about fiscal restraint. That cost is just for the supervisors.

I am just throwing up a few of the practical problems to be faced if the honourable member ever wants to get that loony idea off the ground. So without the cost of materials, the tools that have to be used to undertake the work, the workers compensation and all those add-on costs, you soon arrive at the fact that it is going to cost a lot of money to get work of dubious value.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I would like to defend the Government's position on its youth policy and just point out some of the things that we have done since we have been in power. I know as a member of the Caucus education committee that one of the first things we did when we got into power was to conduct two reviews of the youth policy within Australia. One was conducted by a team from the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development and the other one was an internal study headed by Mr Peter Kirby, who is the Director of Technical and Further Education in Victoria. The Government received both of those reports and looked for areas of commonality. One thing to come out quite clearly was a gaping hole in the skills level of some of our young people. Trades training was looked after by apprenticeships; technician training, by and large, was looked after by the larger corporations; and the TAFE sector and the professions were well catered for in many respects by the universities and colleges of advanced education.

The areas that were not looked after, that were not receiving training, were those areas of potential growth-some in the semi-skills, some in the service industries-where youth suffered a severe disadvantage in relation to people with experience. One of the real imbalances in looking at the different rates of unemployment amongst our young people compared to the average work force is the fact that they do not have the skills to compete on an equitable basis. That compares quite starkly with West Germany and other countries in the OECD who do have a comprehensive policy, one that we have adopted now. The traineeships is an attempt to plug that hole.

I have heard honourable members opposite speak ill of the traineeships and castigate this Government for not reaching the targets that we wanted to reach. Admittedly we did not get to the 10,000 figure. We still have high hopes of reaching the 75,000 figure next year. But the fact is that this Government did have a go. It had to overcome all the in-built reservations that not only the trade union movement and employers had about the scheme, but also those of many other groups as well. I believe that the Government should be congratulated on tackling this particular area in the way that it has.

One of the most important initiatives and one that I checked on this morning is to do with youth services. I rang up the youth access centre in Gosnells and talked to the people there about the role that it is playing in the electorate of Canning. They told me that one of the most important aspects of their work is the outreach program, where they have workers who go into schools, doing what they call street work; that is, they go to areas where kids hang out, apart from schools or shopping centres. They try to make contact with the youth of Australia and point out to them the different aspects and the different government programs that are put in place to support the sorts of initiatives that this Government has undertaken. They have found that by doing this they have been very much more successful in reaching those young people who up until that time had been neglected.

One of the most important things that the young people ask the youth access centre in Gosnells about is jobs. They ask about careers and also about accommodation and food. Things like family crises are also mentioned when these young people come in to the youth access centres, which was and important initiative of the government. They find that the more informal atmosphere and the feedback, the follow-up from the youth access centres, are filling a need that was there for a long time and this Government is to be congratulated for identifying it.

We heard a lot from members of the Opposition about unemployment. They dwelt on recent figures covering a very short span of time. I would just like to expand that time to have a look at the unemployment rate under the former Government and bring it up to date. In non-seasonally adjusted terms, teenage unemployment in August 1975 when the Whitlam Government was still in power stood at 12.9 per cent. In March of 1982 it had risen to 17.3 per cent and in the final year the Liberal-Country Party Government it went from 17.3 per cent to 24.3 per cent. That reinforces, Madam Speaker, the fact that industry had collapsed in Australia and many of those opportunities that were there before no longer existed. As of March 1986 that figure had fallen from the 24.3 per cent that we inherited to 21.4 per cent. On the other hand, full time employment from August 1975 to 1982 actually fell by 47,800; that is, a drop of 9.2 per cent. In the year to March 1983-that is in the final year of the coalition Government-it fell by a massive 91,600, a fall of 17.3 per cent. By March of 1986 employment in that teenage category had risen by 10,600 or 2.4 per cent.

More telling also, Madam Speaker, is the number of persons proceeding to higher education between 1978 and 1984, a period including the final years of the Fraser Government. In 1978 the number proceeding to higher education stood at 45.8 per cent. By 1982 it had fallen to 41.9 per cent. In the first year of this Government it had risen to 43.1 per cent and in 1984, the last year for which figures are available, it had risen to 43 per cent. I anticipate that that figure will rise as the education policies of this Government start to work their way through the educational system.

The motion also refers to what the Government has done for housing for young people. The main avenue for the provision of public housing over which the Government has influence is the 1984 Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. The 1984 Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement specified for the first time that housing assistance would be available to all sections of the community, irrespective of age, sex, marital status, race, religion, disability or life situation with priority on the basis of need. That is the only area that the Government has direct control over. I turn to look at the amounts of money spent by the Federal Government on public housing. In the last year of the Fraser Government it stood at $552m. Under this Budget it will rise to $1,278m, a massive increase in public housing which will advantage the young people of Australia.

No government in the history of Australia has undertaken such a vast range of policy initiatives for the youth of Australia as has the Hawke Government. It has overhauled the areas of income support, opened new areas of vocational education and has begun the job of restructuring Australian industry which will not only be of economic benefit to Australia but will also offer new opportunities for the talents of our young people. It stands in stark contrast to the failure of successive conservative governments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 2 p.m., in accordance with standing order 104, as amended for this session, the time allotted for precedence to General Business has expired. The honourable member for Canning will have leave to continue his speech when the debate is resumed. The resumption of the debate will be an order of the day under General Business for the next sitting.

—My question is directed to the Attorney-General. Is there any precedent for providing by an Act of this Parliament that information before a commission of inquiry established by this Parliament, whose work has been conducted in private-including information which the Government itself is not privy to-should be denied forever examination by the public, by the Parliament, or by law enforcement agencies? Further, what possible public interest justification exists for, first, locking up forever material in the possession of the Commission, not examined by the Government or anyone else outside the Commission, such as fresh evidence which may have been discovered by the Commission of criminal activities of third persons and which has not already been passed by it to law enforcement authorities and, second, preventing material before the Commission being used in court proceedings other than proceedings against the person who provided the material?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us make it very clear that the honourable gentleman again raises matters which were the subject of debate yesterday, when it was clearly said that the real safeguard that we are anxious to protect concerns allegations that might have been made-not investigations about those allegations but just allegations.
—What about criminal prosecutions against others?
—Order! Honourable members on my left will cease interjecting.
—The matter raised in the honourable member's question was debated yesterday. In reply yesterday I said that he did not really understand the existing legislation, which enables-
—Dead right.
—Order! The honourable member for North Sydney has asked a question and he will await the answer.

—I repeat that the whole thrust of the honourable gentleman's argument yesterday was the same as his question today. In reply yesterday it was made clear to the honourable gentleman that the appropriate provisions of the existing Commission-first, the sections relating to being able to return documents to those who have given them; and, secondly, if there is any evidence of any crime, the Commission itself would, under section 34, be able to report that matter--
—What about the bulk of the material?
—Order! I warn the honourable member for North Sydney.

—The honourable gentleman knows that it is a matter of record to you, Madam Speaker, and the Presiding Officer in the Senate, that no evidence has been taken. Is that clear? The point is that no evidence has been taken. There were documents and they can be returned to anyone who gave them to the Commission, and that is provided for in the existing legislation. If in the course of looking at the documents the Commission feels that there was a matter that might affect a third party, or the question of a crime, it would be able to refer those documents under section 34 of the existing legislation.

ANSWER.PARA: What is left? The real issue is that someone might have made an allegation in a document, and that document is the subject of a question of protection. A document in which a person may have made an allegation with no evidence given might well affect Mr Justice Murphy in terms of what it might have said about him. However, bear in mind that there has been no evidence. I think that is very clear. I listened to the debate in the Senate, and even there everybody has been able to say: `Look, we do not really want to have the outrageous situation that if the medical evidence is such that his Honour has a very short--

TALK.START.PARA: —Never mind that. We are worried about others.
—I am glad that the right honourable gentleman said that because that is the only concern about the issue in the legislation.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Madam Speaker: Can I ask you to ask the honourable gentleman on the Labor benches who called me a criminal to withdraw that remark. I regard it as contemptible.
—I withdraw.

—I am making the point that the medical evidence shows clearly that there is a very serious illness and that the life expectancy of Mr Justice Murphy may well be short. On that basis, no fair-minded person would want the Press or someone to be commenting on the fact that someone made an allegation in a document with no opportunity for His Honour to rebut it. If there is a suggestion that there is evidence of crime or criminal conduct, at that point the Commission itself would automatically deal with the matter under section 34.

ANSWER.PARA: I think that the honourable member for Bruce is on record as saying that he gave certain material to the Commission. He can get it back.

TALK.START.PARA: —But can anybody publish it?
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will cease talking across the table.

—I am sure that the honourable gentleman would be able to take the risk of publishing it. That is the point. It has nothing to do with the allegation. The honour- able gentleman made the point yesterday that there was some question of national security being involved back in 1973. Let me also make it very clear that no person, including the honourable gentleman, who is able to walk around and talk, is prevented from so doing in any other inquiry, or in any other evidence that he wants to give.

ANSWER.PARA: Where do we get this nonsense that because this section talks about an allegation in a document, people are prevented from giving evidence? I have never heard the like of it. It is outrageous to be suggesting that people are prevented from doing so. Bear in mind that no evidence has been given and that is a matter of record. There has been an accumulation of documents which can be returned to those who have given them. If there were any suggestion of wrongdoing in the documents, I am sure that the Commission would have taken action under section 34.

I hope that for the first time the honourable member for North Sydney will at least read the legislation-it is there-and understand that the Commission would be able to do its duty, and perhaps would have done it in accordance with either section 18 or section 34. The suggestion that witnesses have been silenced when in fact there have been no witnesses is utterly ridiculous. If the honourable member for Bruce has some evidence, he can offer it wherever there is an opportunity to do so. The same applies to what he was anxious to do yesterday, to bring in the fact that some gentleman named Anderson had given evidence to a select committee in New South Wales. Anderson is not prevented from giving evidence anywhere else. In fact, I believe that one would be very busy finding Mr Anderson now. He is known to be a convicted criminal and, therefore, he has no credibility.

I return to the point. What does it do for a dying man and his family and children to have this sort of malicious innuendo available for publication? It is all very well for the Melbourne Age and the National Times to be saying that it is in the public interest. Even the Commission itself says: `Who wants to hound a dying man, whether in parliament or by the commission? Is it the privilege of the National Times and the Melbourne Age to hound a dying man? Of course it is not. That is the real issue behind this legislation. That is the protection. No suggestion of wrongdoing has been covered up. No document that can be returned would be refused to be returned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why did they want an extension of time?
—Order! The Leader of the National Party will cease interjecting.

—The National Crime Authority or anywhere else will have any document that they want. There is simply a need to prevent people such as we might have opposite, who are anxious to use the unctuous claim: `We do not want to hurt Mr Justice Murphy, but . . .'. When we get to the `but' we see suggestions that--
—They wanted more time.
—Order! I warn the Leader of the National Party.
—Don't worry about it.
—The right honourable gentleman says: `Don't worry about it'. It is a very serious matter for Mr Justice Murphy and his family.
—Of course it is, and that is the point.

—I am glad that that is appreciated. That is the point. That is what it is all about. It is about preventing a dying man being maligned, a man who is unable to answer any accusations. The right honourable gentleman does not want to face that.
—You are covering up.

—Covering up-nothing. How can one possibly cover up when the others who have given the evidence anywhere else are still able to give it? How can one cover up when they can have the documents that they have given returned to them? How can one cover up when the Commission itself, having examined documents concerning an offence against some other person, is entitled and able to give those documents to the appropriate law enforcement agency? Where is the cover up?
—You are the cover up.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I name the Leader of the National Party.

INTERJECT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Young) put:
That the right honourable member for New England be suspended from the service of the House.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The right honourable member is suspended from the service of the House for 24 hours.

INTERJECT.PARA: The right honourable member for New England thereupon withdrew from the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Prime Minister advise the House of this Government's record in meeting its Budget outlays targets? How does this record compare with that of previous governments' Budgets, particularly those prepared by the Leader of the Opposition, Honest John?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question and I am pleased to be able to report on the comparison of our three years with the last three years of our predecessors. In our Budget outlays forecasts the error has been 0.5 per cent, compared with an error of 2.1 per cent for the previous three years under the previous Government. So with a track record like that it is very difficult to take seriously at all the suggestions made by the Leader of the Opposition at his recent gathering in Adelaide that if he had three successive years of zero real growth he could finish up at the end of a hypothetical Howard government with a balanced Budget.

ANSWER.PARA: It is even more difficult to take the Leader of the Opposition seriously when he runs around the country trying to cobble a coalition of forces by on the one hand promising massive reductions in taxes, taking away tax imposts of this Government and at the same time having a pork barrel of promises. The simple question is: Where would he get the money; how would he do it?

Madam Speaker, you know I have a record of always sharing the goodies with this House, and there has come into my possession a memorandum from the then Deputy Leader of the Opposition, at 24 October 1984, written to the then Leader of the Opposition, Mr Peacock. This document came to our attention as a result of having been given to us by a Peacock supporter, of whom there are very many. Do not look worried, Andrew. I say here that it was not given to me by you. It was given to me by one of your supporters. You may look worried, but you have no need to worry. Johnny is more worried, and he should be. I can assure the Leader of the Opposition that there are more to come from where this one came. It will be the leak and trickle-down effect.

I share with the House and the Australian public what the then Deputy Leader of the Opposition said in the election campaign of 1984. He was trying to tell his leader to be honest and saying, by implication, that Mr Peacock was not being honest. The Deputy Leader, Mr Howard, said this to Mr Peacock:

As you are aware, I have been concerned for some time at the cost of many of our commitments. In particular you will recall my reservations about the consequences of many of our policy commitments as they were being made over recent months. I remain very concerned that in the election campaign in which we are alleging that the deficit is too high, that spending has run away underneath Labor, and in which there is a general perception of reasonable competent economic management under the Hawke Government--
hear, hear-

we will be extremely vulnerable if Labor can successfully put the tag of `where's the money coming from' on our election offerings. Our own research shows clearly that voters need to be convinced on this score.
Attacking Mr Peacock, he went on to say that he had examined costings done by Mr Peacock's worker in a number of areas. I shall not use his name, but simply call him X. He said:
I am worried that they understate the true position.

He is telling his Leader that he was not telling the truth. He went on to give examples of how he and that ever-reliable Michael Baume-we know his reputation for and history of absolute accuracy in matters financial and economic--

TALK.START.PARA: —We had a little contretemps a few months ago in this place about allegations relating to people's integrity. Therefore, I ask you, Madam Speaker, in the spirit of that admonition, to require the Prime Minister to withdraw that allegation against my friend and colleague Senator Michael Baume.
—The Prime Minister will withdraw the personal allegation.
—I withdraw, Madam Speaker.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members-Withdraw.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Prime Minister withdrew. If Opposition members had not been making so much noise, they would have heard him do so.
—I had withdrawn. The rest of this document will go to the integrity of the Leader of the Opposition. I am not making any withdrawal in regard to the question of the integrity--
—You are a swine-a despicable swine.
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition will withdraw.
—Yes, I withdraw and I am sorry.

—I am not making any withdrawal as to the integrity of the Leader of the Opposition, because this document goes to it. The then Deputy Leader of the Opposition said that he was worried that the costings understated the true position. He said that Mr Baume and himself had looked at the matter and did not agree with what the Leader of the Opposition had been doing. He goes on to say: `You have been putting out a dishonest figure. I, the honest Deputy Leader of the Opposition am telling you that, on the basis of my and Mr Baume's workings, the real figure is in excess of $1 billion in 1985-86 and closer to $1.5 billion in 1986-87'. He went on:

ANSWER.PARA: If it is assumed that our deficit would be at least $1 billion lower than Labor's, we have about $2-2.5 billion to `account for'.
He said, `You have been misleading the people. I am telling you what the honest figure is and we have between $2 billion and $2.5 billion to account for.' He went on to say:
I do not believe the costings issue can be avoided. The media is already pressing for our detailed costings.
Then he went on to say what should be done to be honest and accurate-not to do what the Leader of the Opposition was doing-and in conclusion he said:
Such an approach-
his approach-
is not only credible. It is also economically honest.

That was an attack by the Leader of the Opposition in his former capacity. He said that what Mr Peacock was doing was not honest and that he should be honest in his statements. Since the Leader of the Opposition has assumed that position, he has abandoned all pretence at honesty. He has not been prepared to do what he demanded of the then Leader of the Opposition. So that people can understand clearly the double standards, hypocrisy and dishonesty of the Leader of the Opposition, I table the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! A number of members of the House have referred to the statement that I made in regard to personal remarks in the House. I draw their attention to the rest of the statement and ask them to take note of it. I went on to say-it has not been highlighted by any member who has called a point of order-that all honourable members have an individual responsibility to the House to lift their standards of behaviour and observe the standards which are expected within the House. I further said that many of you have expressed respect for the institution of Parliament, for the Standing Orders and for the position of Speaker. I again suggest that you put those expressions of support into practice.

—On a point of order: In the spirit and the words of your statement to the House on 20 February, Madam Speaker, I would ask you to ask the Prime Minister to withdraw his comment at the end of the answer that the Leader of the Opposition was dishonest.
—I do not believe that the Prime Minister said that the Leader of the Opposition was dishonest. The honourable member is quite out of order.

—Before I ask a question of the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Madam Speaker, may I, with your indulgence, table the memorandum from which the Prime Minister quoted at length? He trailed his coat rather badly on it. We knew some days ago that he was going to raise it. It was in the National Times.
—Order! Is the Leader of the Opposition asking a question?

—Yes. Does the Minister for Foreign Affairs support the Budget announcement to lift the ban on uranium sales to France? Can the Minister assure the House that the criterion used by the Prime Minister to justify that decision namely that the ban was not being effective-will be applied in relation to the Government's policy of applying economic sanctions against South Africa? Or is the Government's moral outrage on the uranium issue more disposable than its moral outrage against apartheid?
—Order! Before I call the Minister for Foreign Affairs, I point out that the Leader of the Opposition needs leave to table his document. Is leave granted? Leave is granted.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I leave the Prime Minister to give his own explanations of arguments he may have put and to decide whether he wishes to put them. However I have no problems. My views about prohibitions on uranium are well-tested. I expressed myself quite clearly and publicly-
—Do you support the Budget decision?

—Let me run through it. If I do not answer a point which the honourable member raised with me he should remind me when I wind up and I shall be happy to respond. My views about prohibitions on uranium exports are well-known. I expressed my views publicly at the 1982 Federal Conference of the Labor Party and generated some controversy that caused changes to that policy. As for my personal view about whether the prohibitions on uranium exports to France were working, I believe that they were not working. That is a clear and unassailable statement. The Leader of the Opposition asked me to make some comparison-
—Will sanctions work? That is what we are interested in.
—Order! The honourable member for Maranoa will listen to the answer from the Minister for Foreign Affairs and not interject.
—The honourable member asked me to draw some parallel between sanctions against South Africa and the-
—The wheat trade.
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Maranoa. I will not put up with his ceaseless interruptions. He has been given a lot of latitude over a long time.
—Have the flowers wilted?
—Yes, they have. It is time for another bunch.

—The Leader of the Opposition asked me to draw some sort of parallel between the embargo against the export of uranium to France which was related to a particular difference we have had with it over nuclear testing and sanctions-I use different terminology between the embargo and the sanctions-which increasingly are being applied by this country and by other countries against South Africa. They are being applied against South Africa because it alone of all the countries in the world has institutionalised racism and practises the most odious and unacceptable forms of racial discrimination. No other country in the world has any parallel with what is happening in South Africa, so any proposition that there should be a comparison, that there is some sort of an analogy, immediately falls by the wayside.

ANSWER.PARA: The sanctions in the case of South Africa are working. The sporting sanctions which were applied by a conservative government and earlier by the Whitlam Labor Government and which have been continued by this Government do work and they do cause pain. The evidence to me from my Department and sources it has available to it is that the South Africans feel considerably distressed and disadvantaged because they are excluded from major competitive international sporting events in areas where they wish to participate and in areas where they excel. They do excel in rugby union, being quite formidable players, and in cricket. This has hurt them and has caused them, to some extent, to reassess their position. To the extent that comprehensive economic sanctions can be applied on a global basis, they will work. I am quite satisfied about that. There is a fundamental difference between us and the Opposition in this area, but I stress that this does not by any means include all members of the Opposition. Many people in the Opposition agree with our view.

We will not retreat from our commitment to try to encourage comprehensive economic sanctions being applied against South Africa by the rest of the global order. We believe that the oppression of that vast black majority, the cruelty which we see night by night on television screens, symbolised by the whipping of black people by white policemen with sjamboks, is a totally unacceptable symbol of what is supposed to be a Western democracy. As far as I am concerned, there will be no retreat from those policies and there is no parallel.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you support the Budget decision?

—The Leader of the Opposition asked me whether I supported the Budget decision. Of course I do; every member of Cabinet supports the decisions of the Cabinet. I will be working for all aspects of the Budget to uphold its integrity and its appropriateness for the conditions that this country faces at present.

—Is the Minister for Social Security aware of recent Opposition statements which advocate abolishing unemployment benefits for the long term unemployed and young first job seekers? Can the Minister enlighten the House as to the implications of such policies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. To put the question into context one needs to go back no further than yesterday and look at an interview that took place between the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Mackellar, and Haydn Sargent. In the interview the shadow Treasurer was asked, naturally enough, what his reaction was to the Budget. It was assumed by the interviewer that it would be negative and he was not disappointed. He was asked to indicate very early in the interview his attitude to the fringe benefits tax, which has effect within this Budget but of course is not a new measure. Of course, in all honesty he had to admit that the fringe benefits tax would be scrapped by the Opposition at a cost, I think, of $300m, and $600m in a full year. He was then asked how he would approach the question of achieving the level of deficit that had been achieved by the Government. He indicated that he would achieve that purely on the expenditure side. As I understand it, if he were to achieve a deficit of the order of $3 1/2 billion that would mean that over and above the cuts that have been announced-I think I know something about those cuts-he would need to find another $1.5 billion. The shadow Treasurer was then asked: `If you are going to have to find another $1 1/2 billion over and above $2 1/2 billion in cuts, where are you going to find it'? That seems to me to be a very good question. Interestingly enough, where does the shadow Treasurer go for his first attempt at that hard question? Of course, he goes to the young unemployed. He says: `We ought to knock off the 16- and 17-year-olds. The 16- and 17-year-olds who are on the unemployment benefit ought to be removed from it'. He was then asked, I think not unfairly: `What is that going to save'? He answered:

ANSWER.PARA: `Oh, I can't give it to you exactly . . . I have done those sums, I haven't got a brilliant memory for figures, I am on the run down in Melbourne on a list of post-Budget meetings and that's the only reason I can't give you the figures-but I have actually done those sums . . .'

It is pretty clear that this is one of a number of examples of the Opposition's creating figures. I guess we will get an exercise in this tonight. Members of the Opposition pluck figures out of the air and attach those figures to particular groups in the community where they have a prejudice or where there may be a prejudice in the community. In this particular case we have the example of the young unemployed. The Opposition has no idea of what the savings would be, but they are targeted.

The second group, is the supporting parents. It is suggested that this is an area where a great deal could be saved. I think everyone in this House knows that, as a whole, this is one of the poorest groups in the Australian community, but it is the second group targeted out. When we ask the Opposition how it would make a saving in that area, the shadow Treasurer says: `It is really a matter of simple management techniques. We are going to save hundreds of millions of dollars to get that extra $1.5 billion by simple management techniques'. I think this is an example of the level of integrity and the lack of thought that comes from members of the Opposition. They are simply on about stigmatising groups, not about doing an analysis, so we get no comment at all about the measures being taken.

TALK.START.PARA: —What rubbish!

—If the honourable member thinks that is unfair about the honourable member for Mackellar, let us look at the honourable member for Menzies. The honourable member for Menzies is not simply on about the young unemployed or even supporting parents; he says that all long term unemployment beneficiaries ought to be wiped off the books. That is what he said in Launceston.
—You do not know what you are talking about.

—He said: `Let us wipe off all the long term beneficiaries. That ought to be a pretty good saving; that ought to be a good way of making the figures add up'. That is what the honourable member is suggesting. Let me give an example. Let us ask: `Who are the long term unemployed'? When the honourable member for Menzies, or indeed the honourable member for Mackellar, make these kinds of statements, they are essentially statements about prejudice. They are not about people and they are not made with any clear analysis of who is likely to be affected. A total of 29,497 people aged between 45 and 65 years are unemployed, many of whom will not work again. It is these older unemployed people, who face the most difficult circumstances in the labour market, that the honourable member opposite singles out to achieve impossible savings.

ANSWER.PARA: The Opposition's response to this Budget is an impossible dream. It is a dream about cracking down on people in a way which bears no particular relationship to reality, but would simply target some of the groups that have suffered most severely within the community. It is not based on any economic logic. It is very clear indeed that the kinds of figures that have been talked about in terms of outcomes are quite unachievable. They have simply been plucked out of the air because the people on the Opposition side represent a particular section of the community. It is not surprising that the honourable member for Mackellar began that particular interview by admitting that he wants to remove a tax that effectively taxes business lunches, private use of motor vehicles and so on-effectively taxes those benefits that go to the people whom he represents, as a form of tax avoidance-while he singles out in a quite indiscriminate way people who are unemployed.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Treasurer. I remind the Treasurer that last year in Budget Statement No. 2 he published tables of Australia's external debt and its associated servicing payments, including Treasury estimates to the end of the 1984-85 financial year which showed a debt servicing ratio for interest and capital of 33.6 per cent, that is, that almost 34c in every dollar of export income was required to service our debt. Why have such tables not been included in this year's Budget Papers? Is the Government ashamed to publish them? What is the Treasury's estimate of the debt servicing ratio for the 1985-86 financial year? Also, what does he expect the ratio to be in 1986-87?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Budget Paper No. 1 is, of course, a very extensive document. I cannot off the top of my head reconcile what is in it this year compared with last year except that each year we have been providing more information-much more information than the previous Government ever provided-by way of outlays, changes to the macroeconomy and commentary on the various components of economic growth, receipts and outlays. I just make the point-I made it in the course of media presentations on Budget night-that the Australian Budget papers are the Rolls Royce of budget papers. I do not know whether members of the House are familiar with budget papers in Britain, the United States of America, Canada or anywhere else, but there is nothing to equal the quality, the comprehension or indeed the forecasts and the expatiation of the forecasts which underpin that work. I do not think they ought to be taken for granted by honourable members as though this is how everyone gets them. It is not how everyone gets them.
—Are you going to cut them off then?

—No. I believe that they ought to be provided. I believe that more information ought to be provided, which is why this Government has been totally open in providing economic information. The whole process of opening up economic policy-making through the Economic Planning Advisory Council mechanism, through the Advisory Committee on Prices and Incomes and through the Budget Papers is consistent with our approach. The point that the honourable gentleman raises is the size of Australia's external debt; of course, that has been rising. But the main point to make about it is that we have to have a policy to deal with it. The only policy to deal with it is coming from the Government side. We have heard not one policy prescription from the Opposition to deal with our terms of trade or the change in our trade-not one. Opposition members do not believe that the exchange rate will play any role. They say that there is no J-effect. They call it the L-curve. They do not believe that the exchange rate has a role. They do not think that budgetary policy has a role. I am yet to hear what role they believe any policy prescription that they have will play to meet the terms of trade, the external imbalance problems. After 18 months of this debate, we have yet to hear one positive constructive contribution about a major change; so much for the Opposition's bleatings!

ANSWER.PARA: I just make this point: Who got us onto the treadmill of debt?
Opposition members-You did!

TALK.START.PARA: —Who had 6 per cent? Who holds the record for the current account deficit? It is J. W. Howard, the champion of current account deficits with 6.1 per cent in 1981-82. Opposition members can look at the Budget Papers if they do not believe it. Even the Budget current account deficit in prospect at 5 3/4 per cent is well under that 6.1 per cent. The accumulation of debt started then. The current account imbalance was on the way then, only to subside in the recession of 1982-83. But what did the Leader of the Opposition do about it? Did he and all of his colleagues who supposedly represent the farmers try to get the exchange rate to a sensible value? No, they murdered the farmers. The Country Party murdered the farmers on international markets. Opposition members were running around to farm meetings crying crocodile tears while they were ripping to pieces the farmers' export earnings. They were tearing the factories to shreds with their overvalued exchange rate.

ANSWER.PARA: I notice that in Mr Kemp's latest book he has some lovely quotes from Malcolm Fraser saying that, yes, the previous Government did overvalue the exchange rate as an expressed anti-inflation weapon. In other words, he is saying `We had no wages policy; we had no incomes policy; so what we did was to keep pressure on local prices by bringing in cheap imports'. Thank you very much Mr Fraser and Mr Howard. What they did was to wipe out our manufacturing base. They wrecked our export markets. They destroyed farm incomes for years. They let the massive accumulation of foreign debt build up and now they are saying to a Labor government: `Here, you fix it. We wrecked the manufacturing sector'. We have said: `Okay. We have the guts to float the exchange rate. We will let it come down. We will pull the inflationary surge out of wages.' Yet Opposition members ask me puny questions about the size of the external debt.

TALK.START.PARA: —Puny questions?

—They are puny questions because the previous Government did nothing about the external debt. Those humbugs on the other side did nothing about it. It is not enough for the honourable member for Carlton to ask a question; he was a Minister in that Government. What did he say then to the honourable member for Bennelong and the then right honourable member for Wannon? Did he say then: `Look, the industries of this country are being cut to pieces; our external imbalance is something that Australia cannot afford. We must rebalance the economy. Wage increases of 16 per cent are intolerable. We must have an incomes policy. We cannot do this with the exchange rate'? No, he did not do that. He dropped the ball of his public responsibilities. So he should not ask us questions about the build-up of external debt. He is the cause of the problem.

—I also direct my question to the Treasurer. I refer to the promises of the Liberal-National Party Opposition which on the one hand is promising large increases in government spending in certain areas yet on the other hand is advocating a massive reduction in the Commonwealth's revenue base. I ask: How would these policies affect the goal of achieving higher and lasting economic growth in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In short, they would be disastrous. They would derail four years of painstaking effort to make the economy competitive again. They would derail four years of trying to get Australia right. I repeat from the memorandum which the Prime Minister released, and which I have just seen, the views of the honourable member for Bennelong. He states:

ANSWER.PARA: I do not believe the costings issues can be avoided.
He also states:
Such an approach is not only credible. It is also economically honest.

He refers there to publishing estimates of changes in policy. Let us go through the changes in policy forecast by the Leader of the Opposition and their impact upon the real economy of this country. These are the changes in receipts: Abolition of the fringe benefits tax, which he has recently recommitted himself to-$325m; abolition of the capital gains tax-$5m; abolition of the tax on lump sum superannuation-$80m; reinstitution of entertainment expenses-$310m; reinstitution of negative gearing-$50m; full flow-on of world oil price reductions-$400m; abolition of sales tax on oils and lubricants-$66m; abolition of tax on new oil-$165m; the provision of child care rebates-$108m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who made this up?
—They are made from your statements, my friend.
—Ha, ha, ha!

—That silly little giggle will get the Leader of the Opposition into trouble if he keeps it up. Other Opposition changes would be the restoration of income equalisation deposits, averaging $23m and abolition of the wine tax-$107m. In all that makes $1.6 billion of receipts. Other measures forecast by the Opposition include the repeal of the assets test-$150m; abolition of export inspection charges-$46m; and a wage freeze-$400m. That amounts to a further $600m on top of the $1.6 billion. On top of that, he has also committed the Opposition to income splitting-family taxation-which would cost $2.7 billion. He and the honourable member for Mackellar say that they will have a flatter tax system. They will have a top rate of 40c, not 49c, for companies and individuals, which would cost a further $1.6 billion. So there would be a cost of $1.6 billion for the 40 per cent rate, $2.7 billion for income splitting, $600m for the repeal of the assets test and $1.6 billion for the tax changes, totalling $7.5 billion. But he then says: `In three years we will completely remove the Budget deficit'. That means he would have to find another $3.5 billion on top of the $7.5 billion, which totals $11 billion. He wanders around the country making these statements. He says: `I affirm again that we will abolish the fringe benefits tax'. Such statements are issued every week. The list can be ticked off every week. But there is an $11 billion gap. So let us hear again statements such as, `I do not believe the costing issues can be avoided', and `such an approach is not only creditable, given the costings; it is also economically honest'. Let us hear from Honest John tonight about the $11 billion.

—My question is also directed to the Treasurer. Is it a fact that officers of the Treasury and/or the Treasurer's own office briefed overseas financial institutions some time before the presentation of the Budget? What form did that briefing take?
—That is not true.

—Has the attention of the Special Minister of State been drawn to the Queensland Government's pamphlet entitled `Once it was a fight to vote!'? Does he intend to issue a similar publication to assist Commonwealth electors?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —As someone who has taken a long term interest in the facilities made available to Australian voters, I was somewhat attracted to the pamphlet entitled `Once it was a fight to vote!', which has been issued in Queensland by the National Party Government. It is very colourful. It cost $350,000, so the Queensland Government obviously has a lot of money. It tells us a lot. It states that people in Queensland have a lot of freedom and a lot of integrity in their electoral system. The other attractive part of the pamphlet is the following statement:

ANSWER.PARA: In Queensland, there has always been a strong sense of the freedom of the individual.
It also states:

The Americans fought their War of Independence in 1776, the French stormed the Bastille in 1789. This determination to secure our early freedom was echoed in Australia during the Eureka Stockade in 1854 and the Suffragette movements of the 1890s.

Such blood-letting in Queensland! I wonder what would be the attitude of the Queensland Government if someone were to get violent about getting one vote one value in that State. The pamphlet contains many other attractive parts. For instance, I was attracted to the help it gives to each individual electorate. I know that many back benchers have not seen it and I am anxious for them to come to my office and tell me whether they think it would be a good idea for it to be published for use in the next Federal election. Each copy of the pamphlet contains a photo of my old friend Neville Harper. I do not intend to put my photo in five million copies of a pamphlet to be sent around Australia.
Government members-Oh!

TALK.START.PARA: —I will think about it, if the honourable members feel like that. The pamphlet gives a lot of information. It states:

ANSWER.PARA: There are already mobile polling booths which are taken to hospital wards and such like, and if you're unable to leave home, let us know and we'll send someone who's called an Electoral Visitor . . .
And listen to this-Pat Kennelly would have loved this:
You can even vote from your car . . .

Do honourable members remember the old way of voting when one kept changing one's badge? I must say that it is a very attractive pamphlet. We will give very serious consideration to assisting all voters throughout Australia before the next election on the basis of what we have achieved.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is riding the horse?

—I am not too sure what is the association between the light horseman and the right to vote in Australia. Obviously, the one thing that the Queensland Government has overlooked, of course, is to tell the people about the electoral system itself. A closer examination of what is happening in Queensland shows that there are four zones. A voter in zone 2 lives in an electorate of almost 20,000 people but the numbers of voters in zone 3 and zone 4 drop as low as 8,000 or 10,000. So there is not much democracy in the electoral system in Queensland.

ANSWER.PARA: I would have thought-I have been waiting a few days, because the pamphlet has now been issued for a while-that the special committee set up by the Leader of the Opposition should look at this matter. The Coalition Waste Watch Committee should look at the States. No statement has been issued by the Committee, so I take it that its members approve of it. I think the membership of the Waste Watch Committee ought to be changed because at the weekend I heard about a Press statement issued by the honourable member for Mayo which claimed that it was not right for money to be spent on the Prime Minister's Lodge for the purpose of receiving heads of governments. Perhaps he thinks we should get Paul Hogan to put on a barbecue in the backyard for anybody who visits Australia. Let me say this about the honourable member for Mayo-I do not say it unfairly, because he comes from a very distinguished establishment home in South Australia: The Lodge is about a quarter of the size of the Downer household. I was sent to their property in 1965 when I was working for the Australian Labor Party. For 100 years there had been a fight between the mate of the honourable member for Boothby, the late Sir Thomas Playford-another great South Australian-and the Downers. Sir Thomas won it because he put a big highway right through the Downers' property. The Downers decided they could not keep the property if there was a big freeway going through their meadows where their deer used to graze. I went to the property and I was told that the Education Department was going to buy the Downer establishment. I got out of the car and said: `Well, it is not a bad looking place but it is not as big as I thought it would be'. I was told: `That is not the place'. I said: `What is it?'. They said: `That's the dolls house'. The property contained a two-storeyed dolls house. I do not know whether the honourable member for Mayo used to play in it. Anyhow, the Education Department bought it and got the Downers out of trouble. They have since bought another property, and I am told that the Lodge is not as big as the gamekeeper's house on that property. All I can say is that, if the Opposition is to have a Waste Watch Committee, it should get the honourable member for Franklin or someone else from Tasmania to be a member of it.
