TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to report on the meeting in London from 3 to 5 August of heads of government of seven Commonwealth countries on the issue of South Africa. I table the communique of the meeting. The meeting brought together the Heads of Government of Australia, the Bahamas, Britain, Canada, India, Zambia and Zimbabwe. It was a crucial meeting from three points of view. First, it came against the background of a rapidly deteriorating situation in South Africa. That country has been experiencing the most widespread and destructive unrest in its post-war history. In the past two years more than 2,200 people have lost their lives, many in clashes with the security forces. Thousands have been injured. Since the Government declared a new state of emergency in June at least 8,551 people have been detained on a long term basis, according to the Government's own figures. These include leaders of political parties, trade unions, student groups, human rights organisations, churches and many others opposed to apartheid. Our meeting in London was therefore required to formulate a firm response to the deepening tragedy.

SPEECH.PARA: Second, the meeting came at a time of heightened tensions within the Commonwealth, tensions potentially capable of fracturing this longstanding organisation. The boycott of the Commonwealth Games and threats to leave the Commonwealth were symptoms of deep concern and frustration. The London meeting therefore had an important role in preserving the credibility and integrity of the Commonwealth. Southern African issues have been a dominant theme in the Commonwealth over the years and we should not forget that South Africa was a founding member of the Commonwealth and that its departure was decided by the white minority Government.

Third, the meeting was timely in terms of consideration of South Africa under way in other major countries. In June the leaders of the European Community agreed to consider measures against South Africa in three months time if South Africa failed to take certain political steps. In London we were therefore conscious of the important decisions the European Community would be taking in September. We were also conscious of the development in the United States Congress of new measures against South Africa. The London meeting provided the opportunity to give an important international lead.

This was no ad hoc gathering, hastily convened as some knee-jerk response to the appalling situation in South Africa. It was a step in a process already delineated with great care by all Commonwealth heads of government. The Commonwealth Accord on Southern Africa agreed at Nassau in 1985 embodied a clear strategy. This involved the Australian initiative to establish a Group of Eminent Persons, EPG, to try to achieve negotiation and peaceful change. It involved the definition of clear benchmarks against which to judge the South African Government's willingness or otherwise to initiate change. It involved a graduated approach to measures against South Africa comprising a first tranche of measures to be taken immediately, consideration of a second tranche six months after Nassau if adequate progress had not been made, and possible further measures should the first and second tranches fail to produce results in a reasonable period. It involved the pursuit of this program jointly.

What we had here, then, was not a strategy which gave the South African Government no chance to change. It was not a strategy of lashing out at South Africa in a fit of pique. It was a strategy which very deliberately gave South Africa time to show that it was prepared to move towards a non-racial and representative government; which would take advantage of the opportunity offered by the EPG to facilitate negotiations with black South African leaders; and which made the adoption of sanctions totally contingent on the decisions of the South African Government itself.

The Nassau Accord established the mandate for the meeting in London. The first part of our mandate was to review the situation in South Africa and provide an opinion whether adequate progress had been made towards the objectives stated in the Accord. We conducted this review in London at length and in detail. We had the benefit not only of the report of the EPG but of first hand accounts by the two co-chairmen of the group-Mr Malcolm Fraser of Australia and General Obasanjo of Nigeria-and by the British Foreign Secretary, Sir Geoffrey Howe, who had undertaken a mission to South Africa on behalf of the European Community.

The report of the EPG was crucial to our review. I wish to repeat here that the group performed a very difficult task with great determination and integrity. The role played by Mr Fraser reflects great credit upon him. All honourable members have access to the report and I suggest that no objective reader could find it other than a powerful and compelling account of the daily agony of apartheid for the majority of South Africans.

The EPG put forward a creative negotiating concept but this was rejected by the South African Government. The response revealed an unwillingness on the part of the Government to make fundamental changes and to negotiate the creation of a genuinely democratic system. The Government remained wedded to the concept of political rights being granted on a group rather than an individual basis, which implies that race classification will remain in place, and to the retention of the so-called independent homelands. The Government has flatly ruled out a political system based on one person, one vote in a unitary state. The EPG was left no alternative but to conclude;
The Government of South Africa at the end made it impossible for us to proceed any further

This was its unanimous view. It was striking at the London meeting that the impressions conveyed by Sir Geoffrey Howe coincided in essential respects with those of the two co-chairmen of the EPG. Moreover, in terms of the benchmarks specified in the Commonwealth Accord, the facts spoke for themselves. Not one of the benchmarks had been reached by the South African Government. Specific and meaningful action has not been taken to dismantle apartheid. A new State of Emergency has been introduced. Nelson Mandela and other detainees are still in gaol. Political freedom does not exist and the bans on the African National Congress and other political parties have not been lifted. No process of dialogue for non-racial and representative government is underway. Worse than this, spiralling violence and repression in South Africa, and military attacks by South Africa on Harare, Lusaka and Gaborone in May, demonstrated to us in London that the situation in South Africa had gone backwards. As the communique attests this was the unanimous judgment of the seven Heads of Government.

The second part of our mandate under the Nassau Accord was to consider further measures against South Africa. Here there was a division of opinion between Britain and the other six participants. Perfectly properly, we did not seek to camouflage or disguise this in the communique. Australia, the Bahamas, Canada, India, Zambia and Zimbabwe adopted a range of further measures, including those defined in the second tranche of the Nassau Accord. Britain was unwilling to take all these steps and the six regarded this, in the language of the communique, with both concern and regret. That having been said, the three undertakings the British Prime Minister gave were, of course, welcome as far as they went and will help the prospects of action by the European Community as a whole. As I said to my colleagues in London, I wanted us if possible to be united, but above all I wanted us to be credible and effective. Better that those of us ready to act should do so than that we should settle for some transparently ineffectual compromise. We can thank the willingness of the six to adopt strong measures for the fact that the Commonwealth and its international leadership role on southern African issues have been preserved.
I shall now briefly address the measures which Australia has accepted and which are listed in the communique. These measures will be brought into effect as soon as possible:

(a) A ban on air links with South Africa. For Australia this principally involves terminating South African Airways services. The Government is now giving further consideration to the means of implementing this measure taking into account the provisions of the Australia-South Africa Air Services Agreement.

(b) A ban on new investment or reinvestment of profits earned in South Africa. The reference to reinvestment concerns reinvestment of repatriated profits, given the problems of applying extraterritorially a ban on reinvestment of profits which remain in South Africa. The Government has decided that in the first instance this measure will be effected through a call on Australian investors to refrain from such investment.

(c) A ban on the import of agricultural products from South Africa. The Government has decided that provision will be made for prospective implementation of this measure 180 days after the necessary customs negotiations have been promulgated. This will obviate problems for importers who have existing commitments. The Government will shortly be considering certain definitional matters related to this measure.
(d) The termination of double taxation agreements with South Africa. Australia has no such agreement with South Africa, so no action is required on this matter.

(e) The termination of all Government assistance to investment in, and trade with, South Africa. The Government has already taken substantial action in this area. It has now decided to terminate all remaining Commonwealth Government assistance through the export market development grants scheme, the Export Finance Insurance Group and the Overseas Projects Unit of Austrade to Australian firms dealing with South Africa. This will be done consistent with legislative requirements and the honouring of insurance contracts entered into prior to the date of implementation.
(f) A ban on all Government procurement in South Africa. Australia has already introduced this measure save for the procurement necessary to maintain our diplomatic missions.
(g) A ban on Government contracts with majority-owned South African companies. This measure has also already been introduced.

(h) A ban on the promotion of tourism to South Africa. The Government will terminate the temporary residence authority of South Africa based officials of the South African Tourist Commission in Sydney. The Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism will be bring forward proposals concerning other means of implementing this ban.

These eight measures comprise the second tranche identified in the Nassau Accord. The following three additional measures decided upon in London take into account the movement which has occurred on sanctions in both the United States and the European Community since Nassau.
(i) A ban on all new bank loans to South Africa, whether to the public or private sectors. The Government has already called on banks to refrain from such loans.

(j) A ban on the import of uranium, coal, iron and steel from South Africa. Again this will be introduced prospectively 180 days after introduction of regulations. The Government will shortly be considering certain definitional matters related to this measure.

(k) The withdrawal of all consular facilities in South Africa except for our own nationals and nationals of those countries to whom we render consular services. This relates principally to visa issuing in South Africa. The Government is considering how broadly the withdrawal of visa issuing facilities should be applied and this matter will be the subject of a separate announcement.

I wish to announce also that the Government has decided to reduce South African representation in Australia through withdrawal of temporary residence authority for South African Trade Officers at the South African Trade Commissioner's office in Melbourne and for the Commercial Vice-Consul in Sydney. Australia withdrew its Trade Commissioner from South Africa in 1985. In addition I draw attention to the provision that has been made in the Budget for a new $5m assistance program for southern Africa over a five-year period. This will, in particular, provide humanitarian assistance for black South Africans, Namibians and black South African refugees in the areas of education and training.

It is my purpose today to report on the London meeting rather than engage in broad debate on the issue of sanctions. But I do wish to reiterate several points which are absolutely central. First, it is a characteristic of the debate about sanctions that those opposed to them prefer to set up straw men rather than address the real rationale for such measures. One such straw man is that negotiation and dialogue are to be preferred to sanctions. In fact it is a fundamental fallacy to see negotiation and dialogue on the one hand and sanctions on the other as somehow contradictory. The purpose of sanctions is precisely to bring home to the South African Government that its present posture, a repressive defence of the status quo, entails costs and that a change of course would bring benefits. The London communique is explicit that if Pretoria responds positively we all stand ready to review the situation and to rescind the measures which have been adopted.

Those who oppose sanctions do so frequently on the purported grounds that they will hurt the black community. I reject this as patronising and offensive to those representative black leaders such as Bishop Tutu, leaders of the African National Congress and the United Democratic Front, leaders of the front-line states, and black trade union leaders such as those I met in London, who have all made it clear that the black community of South Africa is already suffering immeasurably under apartheid and believes the price of sanctions is one it is prepared to pay.

Another straw man is that sanctions are ineffective because they will not destroy the South African economy or bring down the South African Government. Neither of these things is the real rationale for sanctions and people who argue this way are either too obtuse or lacking the intellectual honesty to address the much more complex calculations involved. The object, as my Foreign Minister (Mr Hayden), has eloquently said, is not to bring South Africa to its knees but to bring it to its senses. The object is not to bring down a government but to change the political dynamics of South Africa in a more progressive direction. The key point is that history shows that, to the extent South Africa has changed, it has done so in response to a changing internal dynamic which has drawn support and encouragement from external pressure. History also shows that in the absence of such pressures South Africa will prevaricate and delay indefinitely. Since inaction means delay and delay means a downwards spiral into violence those opposed to action bear a grave responsibility.

Third, concrete measures are the only way to fulfil our moral obligation as liberal democracies serious about the values of individual liberty and democratic rights. Apartheid is universally deplored but repugnance alone is not sufficient for its elimination. Vocal opposition without tangible measures is hollow.

Fourth, and very importantly, the self-interest of the West requires action. Make no mistake, change will come about one day in South Africa and it is a question of vital importance how it comes. The political, economic and strategic interests of the West will be dealt a tremendous blow if the process is a violent one which throws up a radical successor regime which regards the West as hostile. The purpose of sanctions is to bring home to the South African Government and its domestic constituency the need for peaceful change, and to send a signal to those moderate black leaders striving for change by non-violent means that they are not alone.

In fact, the cost of adopting measures now-whether to Australia, Britain, Canada, the United States of America, the European Community or Japan-will be nothing compared to the cost if South Africa plunges into conflict. It is for this reason, and also because a great moral issue is involved, that Western countries cannot afford to take decisions about sanctions on the basis of some narrow short term calculation in dollars and cents. I did not do so in associating Australia with the measures agreed at London. Nor do I shirk from, or apologise for, the fact that the measures could be at some cost to Australia. This depends upon many imponderables, including the extent to which the measures are adopted by other countries, including particularly, South Africa's major economic partners. No definitive tally can be given. Certainly, there is a potential cost given that our policy deliberately constrains us from developing lucrative commercial relations with the largest economy on the African continent. Any costs would be harder to bear should others stand by and perhaps benefit from the principled stand now being taken by an ever-growing section of the world's community. The point, as stated in the communique, is that such measures have become a moral and political imperative which can no longer be deferred.

The London decisions do not constitute only a recommendation to the Commonwealth as a whole. They usher in a period of intensive consultations within the international community with emphasis on those countries that presently sustain a significant level of economic relations with South Africa. I have sent messages to the heads of government of the European Community countries conveying the Government's views and urging that action be taken. I have written in the same terms to President Reagan and to Prime Minister Nakasone. The visit to Australia next week of the Chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee of the United States Senate, Richard Lugar, will provide a further valuable opportunity to follow up the London decisions.

The Western World is beginning to move on this vital international issue. On 15 August the United States Senate voted 84 to 14 in favour of strong measures, further evidence that there is solid bipartisan support for action in the United States. As noted earlier, the European Community will consider measures in September and movement by Britain at the London meeting should facilitate agreement. The indications are that Japan would be prepared to be part of a position concerted with other major Western powers.

The Government, in taking the decisions it has, has therefore aligned Australia with the emerging international consensus. But we have done more. We have played a major part in helping to shape that consensus. This is a role of which Australians can be proud. I present the following paper:
South Africa-Commonwealth Heads of Government review meeting, London, 3-5 August 1986-Ministerial statement, 21 August 1986.
Motion (by Mr Young) proposed:
That the House take note of the papers.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Young) agreed to:
That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition from speaking for a period not exceeding 23 minutes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on the issue of sanctions against South Africa and particularly on the London meeting on that very troubled country. I state at the outset that there is a great deal of what was contained in the Prime Minister's statement with which the Opposition would wish to associate itself. The Opposition certainly shares all the concern held and all the regret expressed by the Prime Minister about the deteriorating internal situation in South Africa. The Opposition parties, both formerly in government and now in opposition, have been in the forefront of democratic parties around the world in condemning the repressive nature of the present Government of South Africa and the lack of liberal democracy within that country. To the extent that there are differences between us on this issue, they are differences relating not to goals and objectives but to how we achieve those goals and objectives.

SPEECH.PARA: I say on behalf of the Opposition that we will continue to condemn strongly a regime which enshrines in its legal system inequalities based on the colour of a man's or woman's skin. We find repugnant, as does the Government, the policy of racism which has denied and continued to deny political, social and economic freedoms to the majority of people who live in South Africa. We want to see the dismantling of apartheid not only because it is inherently wrong but also because we recognise that the emergence of a truly democratic South Africa as a full member in the community of nations would enhance regional and global peace. Never have we entertained the illusion that such an objective is easy to achieve, but we recognise the responsibility which rests on those of us whose basic human rights are preserved-and there are precious few-in a democracy to seek such rights for others. I continue to believe, as do all members of the Opposition that the Commonwealth, being one of the most successful multiracial organisations in the history of the world, is uniquely placed to bring about the appropriate level of pressure for change and reform inside South Africa.

I would say on behalf of the Opposition that we on this side of the House have always entertained a very positive view towards the Commonwealth. We have not changed our view as we have moved from one side of the House to the other. When we hear the Prime Minister and the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) invoking the moral authority of the Commonwealth it would serve all honourable members well to remember what the present Foreign Minister had to say about the Commonwealth in September 1981 when he was Leader of the Opposition. He said:
I regard it as an extravagant indulgence of little relevance to international affairs or Australia's role in the world.

They were the words of the present Foreign Minister, the man who would now, with his Prime Minister, invoke the moral authority of the Commonwealth to condemn those who may disagree with him and the Prime Minister about how we should deal with South Africa. I would have thought that in the weeks that led up to the meeting in London, the Minister for Foreign Affairs would have served the interests of the Commonwealth better if, instead of his mock wringing of hands, he had showed a little leadership by pointing out to all Commonwealth countries that the pressures that were then being placed on the Commonwealth would reduce the world-wide diplomatic pressure that was then being applied to the apartheid system in South Africa.

The crux of the debate is not whether one side or the other is against apartheid. I would hope that all honourable members accept that the anti-racist credentials of those on the Opposition side of the House are as impeccable as those on the other side. I would hope also that the question of racism and of our bona fide opposition to a political regime that is erected on racism is not seriously in dispute in the House. The record of those on this side of the House when in government in liberating and extending the humanitarian reach of our migration policy, the attitude that we displayed towards taking refugees from Indo-China, and the fact that a former Liberal Prime Minister pioneered the abandonment of the White Australia policy in 1967, will surely stamp for all time the reputation of the Liberal and National parties as being parties that are opposed to racism. Let us not here in this debate-

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Brown's statement on South Africa?

—If the honourable gentleman wants to take that line, let me remind him of some of the intolerant remarks made not only by the former Prime Minister but by the present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), when he was the leader of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, about Vietnamese refugees. Let us have an intelligent debate.
—Yes, let us have that sen- sible debate.
—The honourable member for Calwell will cease interjecting.

—I accept the bona fides of the Prime Minister when he says that he is utterly repelled by and opposed to the apartheid regime in South Africa. I ask him as a precondition of the debate to accept the bona fides of the Opposition when it says likewise. On that basis we can then have an intelligent debate about the issue and not one that is stamped by expressions of moral rectitude and moral outrage. There is not a monopoly of morality or of moral outrage on this issue on either side of the House. There is a genuine argument about the usefulness of economic sanctions. There is a proper and legitimate argument that can be held by those of liberal and democratic instincts to the effect that economic sanctions do not work. There are many people within South Africa whose liberal credentials are unimpeachable. People such as Helen Suzman have said repeatedly that economic sanctions would be a disaster for the country she loves as much as any other South African. They regard economic sanctions as a disaster in the cause of getting rid of apartheid.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us start the debate by accepting that people of goodwill can oppose apartheid and economic sanctions. That is currently a view that is widely held among many Australians. It certainly is and has been the view of the Opposition on the imposition of punitive economic sanctions that are designed inevitably, whatever may be the stated goal, to cripple the South African economy unless there is a change to the satisfaction of those imposing the sanctions. We have been, we remain, and I dare say that we shall always remain, opposed to the imposition of sanctions of that sort.
The claim that is made with such moral certainty that the majority of the black people in South Africa want economic sanctions is not one which can be empirically verified.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish-absolute rubbish.
—It is not a claim that we can say--
—Rubbish!
—Order!
—I do not mind if the honourable gentleman interjects. I know that he has had to cop it sweet on uranium. I do not mind if he intervenes on this occasion.
—Order! It is not up to the Leader of the Opposition to decide whether he wants interventions. I ask the honourable member for Calwell to cease interjecting or I will deal with him.

—The arguments that are advanced on the imposition of economic sanctions are not straw-man arguments. There is a long history over this century of economic sanctions proving to be futile. They were futile in the 1930s. Many people believe that they were futile when they were imposed on what was formerly Rhodesia, now Zimbabwe. There are many who believe that they will be futile in relation to South Africa.

SPEECH.PARA: There was one argument which the Prime Minister did not address in his speech-I do not believe that it is a straw-man argument-which I consider to be relevant to whether we ought to support economic sanctions. We must understand that once the world invokes moral authority to start down the path of sanctions, we shall have started a journey that we must be willing to finish. I ask those who support the imposition of economic sanctions to tell the world and the House what they intend to do if the sanctions embraced by the Prime Minister's statement do not work. Today I invited the Foreign Minister to say whether the criterion of effectiveness would be applied, as it has apparently been applied, to uranium sales to France. The honourable gentleman declined to give an answer. So I ask the question again: What happens if the sanctions that are listed in the statement do not work? Do we go further? What happens if the further sanctions do not work? Do we commit ourselves at the end of the day to a course of action that involves the imposition of punitive economic sanctions of a comprehensive sort right across the board?

One of the fundamental reasons why I and many others have opposed the march towards sanctions that has been joined by the Government is a concern that, as inevitably will be the case, the sanctions will not bring about a change. The question has to be asked: `What do we do after that?'. Have we considered seriously the impact on the countries that are supporting sanctions if the front-line African states, economies are damaged by South African retaliation?

Have we considered whether we shall be asked to foot the bill? The Prime Minister says that he does not know what the cost to Australia will be. His statement envisaged a cost in terms of lost trade, but does his statement and his Government's understanding of this issue envisage the possibility that the front-line states will look to Australia for financial compensation for the South African Government's retaliation against them? That is an issue that I do not think has been addressed.

Even more important than that, there is the fundamental question of the impact of the sanctions on the very regime whose mind they are designed to change. I put it to the Prime Minister and the House as a serious proposition that the imposition of the sanctions is at least as likely to strengthen the hand of the present South African Government as it is to weaken it. So many who talk about South Africa never acknowledge the very unpalatable fact, but nonetheless the reality, that the army and the internal security forces of South Africa are without question the most powerful in the African continent. The proposition that the white regime can be removed by the imposition of economic sanctions or that the imposition of sanctions will bring about a major change in the attitude of that regime, is a very questionable one.

I put it to the Prime Minister and to those who so zealously support sanctions, based on moral outrage and moral grounds, that it is as possible as not that the imposition of sanctions will strengthen President Botha's stand. It is at least as possible that the laager mentality of those who know South Africa a little better than some who give moral lectures on the subject will in fact be strengthened in that country. I cannot for the life of me understand why that argument is never addressed. But let us assume that the sanctions start to bite and the morale of the white population is changed. Is it not at least as possible that the extremist elements within the white population will in fact become more entrenched in their views? Is it not possible that that element of the South African population commanding the support of the security and defence forces could turn them to a more violent suppression of the unrest of the black population? Does the Government really believe that the internal stress and strain that a deteriorating and collapsing South African economy would impose upon the poor people in that country would give them a better South Africa than they now have? Does the Government really believe that potentially crippling the South African economy will improve the lot?

The Prime Minister says that it is patronising of me to use that argument. I say to the Prime Minister that it is patronising of him to assume that he knows what is best for the millions of black people in South Africa. I say to the Prime Minister and to others who urge the imposition of economic sanctions: What moral right has a group of countries to decide that they will go down the path of destroying the economy of another country? Of course the situation inside South Africa is deplorable. But I put it to the Prime Minister that it can be made even more deplorable if the wrong action is taken by the outside world. I put it to the Prime Minister that the position inside many countries is deplorable. Suppression of liberty, whether it is based on race, political belief or religious or sectarian belief, still is suppression of liberty. But we hear the idea that there is one special category of suppression of liberty. I have read the argument somewhere that if one is put in gaol and one's human rights are denied, one is supposed to feel better if that denial of human rights does not occur on racial grounds but on some other ground. All I can say to that argument is that suppression of liberty occurs all around the world. Yet for some reason a large part of the world has decided that we have selectively to apply severe measures against South Africa.

I say to the House and to the Prime Minister that I believe that the imposition of punitive economic sanctions is an unwise course of action and one that is not supported by the Opposition. We believe that, with this announcement and with these decisions, the Government has started down a path which will lead inevitably to a situation that could create a worse South Africa than we presently have. I do not believe that economically isolating South Africa will bring about a change of heart in that country. I believe that it has been altogether too easy for those members of the Commonwealth, including Australia, which lined up on this issue, by implication, against the United Kingdom, to demand of the United Kingdom something which we may not necessarily have appreciated being demanded of us. It is very easy to say to a country that has enormous economic links with South Africa that it should be in the vanguard of crippling the South African economy. The reality is that if air links between Britain and South Africa were terminated the financial consequences for British Airways and for the privatisation and other plans of British Airways would be quite enormous.

I say to the House that if we were lectured to, moralised at and required to do what the British Government was required to do by many other members of the Commonwealth we would have reacted in precisely the same way. If our economic links with a totalitarian government were as extensive as the economic links of the United Kingdom with South Africa, I dare say that a Labor government as well as a Liberal-National Party government would take the same stand that the British Government took in relation to South Africa. I think this is an example of hypocrisy.

On the very day that this Parliament sits the Australian Labor Party is torn apart on an issue related to uranium. What is the Prime Minister's rationale for terminating the decision of his Party about uranium sales to France?
Opposition members-Money.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is money; it is as simple as that. What the Treasurer (Mr Keating) said the other night was that at the end of the day the Government has decided to take the money, and his explanation was that the Government did not think that the ban would be effective. The Government says: `Forget the morality; forget the symbolic gesture; forget about the moral outrage'. At the end of the day it decided to take the money and run.

SPEECH.PARA: All I can say is that I have no trouble at all in supporting the Prime Minister's decision, announced on Tuesday night, on uranium, because I thought that his original position was absolutely crazy and indefensible. But I do have trouble with the selective morality of this Government. We have just been treated to a 23-minute speech, a large part of which defended the imposition of economic sanctions against South Africa, and all of it was very finely balanced on questions of morality. The whole thrust of the speech was that if one did not support economic sanctions one did not have the required level of moral outrage. I think that demonstrates the situation, particularly coming today when the Labor Party has, it seems, made the inevitable decision to ditch its great moral opposition to uranium sales to France because of the few million dollars involved. That is the essence of it. The Government has decided to junk it. The policy on uranium sales to France was reaffirmed four weeks ago with a burst of evangelism, but now, because the Government needs the money, it has decided to junk that policy. Yet the Leader of the Labor Party still has the gall to presume, by implication, to lecture me about the depth of my moral outrage about apartheid in South Africa.

I can only say to the Prime Minister that that sort of double standard does not wash with me, it will not wash with the House and it will not wash with the Australian people. The Australian people are smart enough to understand that the foreign policy priorities of this country go beyond a disproportionate level of concern about the affairs of southern Africa, and one of the on-going criticisms of this Government's foreign policy is of the way in which it has devoted a disproportionate amount of its time to its concern with the affairs of southern Africa. If the Prime Minister and the Foreign Minister had spent as much time worrying about our relationships with Indonesia and with the countries of the Association of South East Asian Nations region as they have worrying about our relationship with southern Africa, the foreign policy concerns and priorities of this country and this Government would have been better served.

I say again on behalf of the Opposition that our opposition to what is occurring in South Africa, our desire for peaceful change and our recognition that that can really be brought about only by a better understanding between the more liberal elements of the white population and the more rational elements of the black population are second to none amongst the political parties in this country. We do not believe that as a demonstration of our moral rejection of apartheid it is necessary for us to align ourselves with the attitude of the Government on the sanctions issues, and I say on behalf of the Opposition that we certainly do not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am particularly pleased to be able to speak in support of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Government regarding the report on meetings in London discussing the imposition of sanctions and other measures against the white racist South African Government. I was rather offended and disappointed by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) who, after saying that the Prime Minister had no moral right to speak on behalf of those 23 million black people who are being oppressed by a government elected by 4.5 million whites, proceeded to put forward arguments which are repeated time and time again by those who are misinformed and who do not hear, or wish to hear, what the black people in South Africa are saying. He offered the same sops for inaction as are being offered time and again by those who do not wish to move themselves to speak or act in support of those beleaguered people.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I make any further comments, I wish to quote directly from a young, black South African man, Mziwonke Jack, aged about 30 years, living in the township of Nyanga on the outskirts of Cape Town. Mziwonke has watched hundreds of his friends being killed by black vigilantes in the pay of the white South African Government and by white plainclothes South African security police. On 23 July, I said to that young man that other people were saying that sanctions should not be imposed because they would hurt the black people in the area. I asked him:
What do you think about that argument?
Mziwonke answered:

I dismiss that as nonsense, because we are dying today in the presence of their investment. They're investing in the country and I believe that's not helping. But I will tell you about my own feelings. I believe that as long as there are people who are investing in this country, they will in fact be strengthening apartheid: because this Government will flourish. They will have money to buy whatever they want to do. They will have money to buy other people from other countries. So my feeling is that as long as people are investing here, these Boers are not going to change. Instead, they will buy arms and continue killing us.

I would not be quoting the views of just one South African. Mziwonke has been assisting hundreds of people whose homes were burnt down at the end of May and the beginning of June during the violence in South Africa. That view was also put forward by Reverend Sidney Luckett, an Anglican priest and director of the Board of Social Responsibilities in Cape Town. I assure the House that he is an entirely apolitical man who was educated in England. He said that although sanctions may not be the answer against a Government which will not change its oppressive measures, they must still be introduced. Most importantly, he said that black Africans in South Africa want this. That view was also held by Buelah Rollnick, a consultant of the Black Sash organisation, a highly respected organisation in South Africa which started as a grouping of white women and spread to people of all races and both sexes in South Africa, and which has been conducting mopping-up operations for decades as black people who have been disinherited come in to speak to them. The important point to make is that there is not just racial discrimination in South Africa. There is physical and mental oppression into which black people have been tied from the time they were born, when they were categorised into one of four colour groups. Those colour groups are based on privilege. They are given a number on a card at birth. The majority-23 million blacks-are the ones who have to carry a pass containing that information from the age of 16 onwards. I have spoken to people in South Africa whose families have been divided by law. The difference between oppression in South Africa and in any other nation that one cares to mention, as the Prime Minister pointed out, is that in South Africa the oppression is by law. The Westminster system that is used in countries such as Australia to obtain justice for people is used in South Africa to oppress.

The people of Australia, and that includes the Leader of the Opposition, cannot really be aware of the extent of the oppression in South Africa and are obviously unaware of the requirements of the black people, who say that they need sanctions and other such moves by the Western nations. They are not listening to the words of the black bishops who came to Australia a couple of weeks ago. They spoke to many people in Canberra and expressed the opinion that if the West did not stir itself up, make some definite and strong gestures and take strong action now, we should be embroiled in global conflict. At that stage, of course, the West will be over there in South Africa. Although President Reagan is a little reluctant now to give black South Africans the support that they require from the West, he knows that they will turn quickly for that support to the Communist bloc. This is a serious projection of what is likely to happen in South Africa if we do not move, as Mr Fraser has also said. Should that occur, we shall be embroiled. We shall have to look after our backyard and President Reagan will be over in South Africa protecting the anti-communist interests. Why not act now?

In 1983, table conversation in Australian dining rooms and potted wisdom over the back fences focused on whether Australia should play sport with South Africa. Those who opposed sporting bans said that sport and politics should not be mixed or that we should keep our noses out of South African politics. The middle ground decided that Australia should look after its own backyard and pointed to the plight of the Australian Aboriginal. The South African Embassy in Canberra insisted, as dogmatically then as it does now, that its Government was trying to dismantle the apartheid system.

In 1986, South Africa confronts us again-now almost daily-through the media. Unlike in 1983, the reported violence and comments of the Eminent Persons Group have given an added insight into the tribulations of the beleaguered blacks in that war-torn country. Australians no longer see the crucial question as being, should sport and politics be mixed, but will economic sanctions help to solve the problem? Yet even given the enlightened reporting and, consequently, broadened understanding of the South African position, large sections of our society, by their comments, often directed to members of parliament, display a reluctance to accept that the explosive situation which exists there has anything to do with Australia. It is up to all people and people on both sides of this Parliament to support the Government and the Eminent Persons Group in their actions, which are designed to enlighten people about what is really happening.

In 1983 as in 1986, argument based on the inhumanity of the apartheid system was invariably countered with the statement: `You can hardly judge the system when you have not been there to see how it works'. I was honoured to be part of a delegation which went to South Africa in 1983, and I have kept up contacts with people over there. I am therefore very proud of the part Australia played in shaping up the Eminent Persons Group. I am particularly interested in the comments made by that Group. I would like to quote a couple of those comments from the report, which all honourable members should read if they have not already done so, entitled `Mission to South Africa'. In chapter one the group commented:
None of us was prepared for the full reality of apartheid.
As a contrivance of social engineering, it is awesome in its cruelty. It is achieved and sustained only through force, creating human misery and deprivation and blighting the lives of millions.

The degree to which apartheid has divided and compartmentalized South African society is nothing short of astounding. We understood why many visitors to South Africa could leave the country enchanted by its natural beauty and impressed by its economic achievement, yet oblivious of the scale of the human tragedy behind the facade of progress.

The living standards of South Africa's white cities and towns must rank with the highest anywhere; those of the black townships which surround them defy description in terms of `living standards'. Apartheid creates and separates them; black and white live as strangers in the same land.

There have been comments made today that there are other nations in which people are suffering, other nations in which they are oppressed. I think we should have grown beyond the stage at which in any given situation we should say `Don't act in this particular way, because there are others whom we are not moving to assist' at the same time not moving to rectify the inequities which are being felt and experienced by those people.
I will finish on the comments of the Reverend Sidney Luckett regarding the effectiveness of the Eminent Persons Group when in South Africa. On 28 July he said:

. . . I think that . . . when the Eminent Persons Group came out here, I think there was an ideal opportunity presented to the Government to actually begin to undertake some significant reforms: and the opportunity to . . . a very rare opportunity to start getting meetings with government and African National Congress.
It seems that the EPG had made significant progress with the ANC and the Government just in a sense discarded that EPG process. The very fact that they-
that is, the Government-
raided neighbouring states and Botswana, Zimbabwe and Zambia while the EPG was still around was just incredible.
It said to me that at least there's a significant section of government that is not interested in the peace negotiations process.
. . . I found it very depressing, because a lot of us really had hoped that the EPG would bring about something. We were quite impressed by what they had managed to achieve.

. . . initially people, say executive members of the UDF inside the country, were a little sceptical of yet another peace initiative: but then found that these people had actually done a lot of hard work and were meeting a wide cross section of the population and they weren't just rushing in and out . . . I think they'd made significant progress, in opening up at least opposition parties-extra-parliamentary opposition parties-to the possibility of negotiations with the government.

While Reverend Luckett feels that those hopes have been dashed by the continued militant actions of the South African Government, he still persists in his statement that there is a need for the West not just to stand by and allow what is virtual genocide to take place. This is a reality and if people react in an adverse way to that truth and see it as sensational, it really only indicates that they need to look word for word at the EPG report, a report of reasonable people from different Commonwealth nations, people who had as their aim paving the way for negotiations to stop the oppression of black people in South Africa.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to be joining with the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) to address the House on this matter today. Those who have been listening would have heard once again the sanctimonious nonsense that comes from members of the Government on this issue. I am on the younger side of 50. I have served a long time in this Parliament. When I first stood for Parliament those sitting opposite had in their platform the belief in the maintenance of the white Australia policy. They did not change it; we brought about the change when in government. I have sat here year after year and witnessed this antiseptic air of moral superiority coming from a bunch of dodos, who have never had a plan of action for the ending of racism in this world but who, when they eventually have one thrust upon them through the responsibility of government, assume that their alleged plan is the only one then existent.

SPEECH.PARA: It was members on this side of the House when in government who forged the nation state of Zimbabwe. It was the work of the then Prime Minister and, dare I mention it, the Foreign Minister at the time, at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in London in 1977-

TALK.START.PARA: —In London in 1977?
—In London in 1977, you dill-that is how much the honourable member knows about it-who set down the plan which was followed at the Lusaka meeting and implemented in 1979.
—Order! The honourable member for Kooyong in that remark appeared to be addressing an honourable member in particular. I ask him to withdraw the personal reflection.

—I will withdraw it, but it shows the lack of comprehension on this issue. There is not a comprehension by instinct or by intellect. If ever there was a foreign policy matter on which the motivations all lead to the one conclusion it is this one. It is at once moral, political, strategic and economic to be opposing apartheid. I am not going to listen to this selective morality that says that, because we prefer a line of action involving eight matters and the Government wants to implement only four, the Government is both right and morally superior. It is not, and I will argue every day of the week that our consistency on this matter will outweigh the Government's at any time. I have to say that because I am sick of the hectoring, the lecturing and the innuendoes contained in the remarks of the honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling) about matters addressed by the Leader of the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: We do not embrace all the methods the Government is suggesting. It does not mean that we do not share the same aspirations. We want to end apartheid and to replace it with a system based on justice. We have made it clear time and again that we are calling for an end to the state of emergency, an end to detention without trial, the unconditional release of political leaders, the abolition of all forms of discriminatory legislation, a common commitment to a common form of citizenship for all South Africans, an end to forced removals and equality of educational opportunity. I spell those principles out as a schedule that we put to the South African Government, but I do not think I have ever heard honourable members opposite put that sort of plan of action. Week after week members of the Government tell us that they hate apart- heid and that they are the only ones who are effective because they like measures 1 to 8 in the CHOGM Bahamas communique. I want to know whether they are in favour of equality of opportunity-I have never heard them say it-a common form of citizenship, an end to forced removals, the unconditional release of political leaders or an end to detention without trial. I have not heard them say these things. They come in with this antiseptic air of moral superiority and the humbug and nonsense which reveals a lack of comprehension of both what is transpiring there and what ought to be done. They ought to be nailed. The fact that they come in here with hand-wringing rhetoric does not place them on the side of the angels nor, more particularly, on the side of those who can really see a goal to be worked for and an end in sight. I reiterate that it was those on our side of politics, after all those years, who were the major participants in bringing about the state of Zimbabwe. It resulted from our effective work in the Commonwealth. I put that down now because of the selectivity that creeps into this debate, both here and in the media, and the assumption that, because we do not embrace comprehensive economic sanctions, we are at one with apartheid. Well, we are not. The debate here today and in the Western world generally is not about defending apartheid. I hope we all agree that apartheid is indefensible and is a crime against humanity. Nations have every right-indeed, a duty-to communicate their sense of values, particularly when the issue at hand is racism.

We are all too aware of the abuses practised in South Africa. We know too well its many forms of institutionalised racism. It shames all mankind to know that skin colour is the sole determinant of political and legal rights in that country. The South African Government violates the fundamental principles of liberalism; and it does so while claiming to adhere to Western values. Our condemnation of apartheid in South Africa is unequivocal and it is long standing. It is rightly a subject that on occasions excites high emotion and widespread censure. But it does so for the one fundamental reason that it discriminates against non-whites on the ground of race.

The central issue in South African affairs is how to achieve radical forms with the minimum of violence and disruption within the Souh African community. The reforms required are essentially twofold: First, the abolition of apartheid, with equal treatment before the law of all South Africans; and, secondly, power sharing among all members of the South African community. We believe that it is of critical importance that there be a genuine and continuing dialogue, initiated by the South African Government, between it and black leaders genuinely representative of the black community and together with representatives of other groups in the South African community, so that confidence and understanding can be promoted and so that the means of achieving the objectives that the coalition believes to be essential can be examined.

Honourable members have referred to the report of the Eminent Persons Group which was co-chaired by Malcolm Fraser. As a descriptive document, leaving to one side for a moment its prescriptive element, it is a dramatic account of the institutionalised discrimination in South African life. It is very powerful in its account of apartheid and the effect of it on South African society. It is profoundly disturbing in its implications for the future of a government intractable in its opposition to genuine reform and blind to a vision of equal humanity. The prospects for South Africa obviously are not good. I regret that the South African Government ignored the opportunity provided by the Eminent Persons Group to accelerate reform and peaceful change. Any fair reading of the report of the Eminent Persons Group shows that its `concept for negotiations' presented to the South African Government was not overly ambitious. It was geared to creating a peaceful atmosphere in South Africa to allow genuine talks to begin.

I said that the debate is not about defending apartheid. It is about how most effectively now to influence the South African Government to change its racist policies. I have said here-the Leader of the Opposition and others have said it too-that we do not believe that walking the route of comprehensive punitive economic sanctions is the answer. The debate is about only the method of achieving that change. As Foreing Minister I have sat in Cabinet and weighed up whether we should impose sanctions on countries. If one was wanting to impose economic sanctions, the element that one had in mind was that one wanted to damage or punish by economic means the country being targeted. In this case at this moment the South African economy is in a parlous state. Many of the reforms that have been made have been within the private sector. There have been agreements between employers and unions, the union movement having played a very significant role. If this Government is to damage further and to cripple that economy, it will unquestionably impose the most unreasonable hardships on the majority of the population which is black and unquestionably, in the case of so many of them, that will cause them to lose their jobs.

I find it an absurdity, and a rather cruel absurdity, that the Government would choose that sort of route to bring about change. Having said that, we do not say: `Do not continue to bring pressure to bear on the South African regime'. Of course, we believe that that should be done. But we do say that to impose comprehensive punitive economic sanctions, leading to a breakdown in the economy, which could lead to further social unrest and lead to civil war, is hardly the route of peaceful negotiations. Furthermore, it is fair to say that, albeit that I recognise the role of sanctions-I have previously looked at and sought to impose them elsewhere and I do not deny that-I do not believe that the correct route is via punitive sanctions. The record of such sanctions is not good. The Institute of International Economics has cited 103 episodes of such sanctions since the First World War and has concluded that sanctions are seldom successful, except against small countries, and of course only when the goals are modest.

I accept the argument that such comprehensive punitive economic sanctions would serve only to reinforce the conservative elements that are opposed to reform in South Africa. As South Africa becomes more and more self-sufficient and its dependence on any one country goes, the international lever goes. The Leader of the Opposition is quite right to say: `Will you please tell me: If you impose these comprehensive economic sanctions and they do not work, what will you do next?'. There is a lack of looking down the line, taking the longer view. In terms of diplomacy and foreign policy, if one takes one step one should always know what that will lead to and what the next step will be.

It seems to me that the better approach is to wind the pressure up. The British Government and the United States Government have implemented some measures, and I think they will go further. As this year unfolds the United States Administration will be forced to follow the lead of the Congress and to implement more measures. I think the United Kingdom Government will go a little further, in conjunction with the European Community. We can see that being played out. For that reason it seems to me that the correct approach is to gradually wind these matters up. I have no problem in saying that I think the European Community is approaching the matter, in many ways, more effectively than is the Commonwealth in agreeing to these matters.

I end, as I began, by saying that honourable members on this side of the House feel indignant when they are painted into a corner; when, because they do not embrace comprehensive punitive economic sanctions, it is alleged that they are in favour of apartheid. I trust that the sort of schedule that I have set out, as what we expect the South African regime to implement, will indicate that that is not so and that we believe that a constant winding up of pressure will achieve more than dumping on the South African Government the range of matters suggested in London at the meeting upon which the Prime Minister has reported.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you speak for the National Party?

—I speak for the coalition. Coalition policy is embraced by what I said. Neither the National Party of Australia nor the Liberal Party of Australia will endorse comprehensive economic sanctions. But we all endorse the range of matters as a schedule of action that I set out in the earlier part of my remarks. As I have said, I will conclude on the note on which I started: This is an issue on which the economic imperatives, the political strategic motivations, all lead one to condemn apartheid. But, having condemned it, please bring forward a course of action that will work.
— Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hand Mr G.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me say at the outset that I am particularly proud to be able to take part in this debate and to be supportive of the statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). Since this Government has been in office it has been at the forefront on this issue. I would like the previous speaker, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), to listen to what I am about to say-he may appreciate it. I have never moralised that I have been purer on any issue than anybody else. I let people judge other people on their performances. I listened with interest to what the honourable member said and I acknowledge that purity is not the property of members on this side of the chamber. Many people in other parties, both in this place and in the Senate, feel very strongly and have an excellent record on this issue. I make that point because the honourable member made play of the fact that he thought that some honourable members in this place were claiming sole right to the issue. I reject that, if that is what he was implying, because I acknowledge the roles played by other people. I will address that point later in my comments.

SPEECH.PARA: I have a substantial number of notes on the issue that is before the House. As is the case with other issues that are of a moral nature, it is probably sometimes better not to use a lot of one's notes and to say how one feels in less polished terms. This issue has come before the public of Australia in a fairly dramatic way in recent times. It has come to our attention while this Government has been in office. It appears on television screens every night during news programs. Perhaps when the honourable member for Kooyong was Foreign Minister he was labouring against public opinion. Perhaps the public then was not as conscious of the situation in South Africa. I think that that comment ought to be made.

In the newspapers every day and on television every night we see people being clubbed to death, being burnt, being whipped, being arrested and crying out for help. I will put to the honourable member for Kooyong what I think and hope the Government is trying to do. If one wants to be successful in any struggle, one must mobilise the masses-in this case, other nations-to take action. It is a question of what sort of action one considers to be best. We must ask ourselves whether continual diplomatic discussions with people is the best way to resolve this matter. Has it been successful to this point? In my view, with all humility, I suggest that it has not been as successful as, I am sure, the previous speaker and other members on the other side who have spoken on this issue in recent times would have liked.

What are we left with? I think we are left with having to respond to the pleas and cries of people who are most affected by the issue. I think the time has come when we must listen to Bishop Tutu, Mandela and all of those other people who are crying out to the world to take action, and who are saying that the diplomatic response is not working. I have spoken in this context in regard to Aboriginal affairs. I do not want to divert the debate, but I think this is an interesting comparison. Sometimes people who are not Aborigines are inclined to pretend that they know what is best for Aborigines. I think there is a parallel in terms of South Africa.

If there were no cries by black South Africans for the sorts of actions that are proposed in the decisions outlined in the communique, I would accept that perhaps the honourable member for Kooyong's argument in favour of the diplomatic approach has more strength. I have discussed this matter with the honourable member privately. But the people who we say could be most effective-people such as Margaret Thatcher, speaking on behalf of her country, and the American Government, through its President-have said that sanctions will hurt black South Africans. It is interesting to note that numerous South African black leaders have said that they understand that. But the point is that if sanctions or harsher actions than those that have been applied in the past-I am in no way condemning the performance of people-are not adopted, the present situation will continue. Repression is becoming worse every day. More people are being arrested. The black South Africans have said: `You people have to help us'. Any former member of any government will say that the only way people can be helped is when the hip pocket nerve is affected. It seems to me that countries respond in a similar way.

I have come to the position, after a lot of thought and a lot of discussion with representatives of black people of the southern region of Africa, that what we are engaged in here is just and proper. I do not say that the previous speaker or any other member in this place is not as pure on the issue as I, because that is irrelevant. I am proud to support the Government's stance on this issue. Just as honourable members opposite have said that they do not have sole rights in relation to this issue, I ask them to consider the fact that perhaps we have moved beyond 1983. I acknowledge the diplomatic role played by previous Liberal governments. I acknowledge the role that the previous Government played in regard to Zimbabwe. I acknowledge the role of Malcolm Fraser. For many years I was a constituent of the electorate of Wannon and I suffered from the back of Malcolm Fraser's tongue at many public meetings. I had an altercation with him in 1975, which he seemed to remember at the time of the next election when he refused to shake my hand. So I acknowledge that we have been political opponents over a long period. But I am the first to say that I think he has played a magnificent role in this issue.

Some of my friends and supporters might think that is a strange thing to say. But I have followed his movements in recent times on this issue. I do not think that prior to 1975 I would have associated a person like Malcolm Fraser with this issue. Probably for a few years after 1975 I maintained my rage and did not take much notice of what he said. But now I read with interest what he is doing in relation to this issue. Here is a man who has gone to the region, looked and, as the previous speaker said, has been part of a group that has written a truly magnificent report. It is truly an interesting report because of the detail of the extent to which the group visited areas, the questions they asked and the information they provided. This truly interesting report will serve the world as a reference document for many years.

The sanctions which we are discussing take us beyond the issues that the former Foreign Minister said he was involved in. They take us into a new era. Members of all parties feel strongly about this matter. Although I intended to do so, I will not now go into the issue of who feels more or less strongly about this matter. I do not want to score a cheap political point. I will be generous. In speaking in a debate such as this I think that one cannot afford to engage in some of the normal point scoring in which we often engage.

A young community youth support scheme group, who had been engaged in a workshop course during the day, visited my office. My electorate is not very large geographically, but honourable members from the Melbourne area will know that, as small as it is, in peak hour traffic it takes some time to get from one side of it to the other. About eight or nine kids burst through my office door at about five minutes to five one afternoon. They had been dealing with the subject of race relations and had discussed the matter during the day. They had decided to come to talk to their local member. They had to ask what could they do and how could they help the black people of South Africa who were suffering under this system. I thought it was a wonderful example of enthusiasm. When these people sat down and talked about this issue, they felt they had to do something about the situation and wanted to be part of changing the dirty, rotten, unfair system that operates in the southern region of Africa where a child comes into the world and spends the rest of its time on this earth being denied any chance of equality. We in this country often talk about equality of opportunity and we feel strongly about these matters. Indeed, we see people in our electorates who do not have the sort of equality that we would like to see in terms of opportunity. It is beyond our imagination, as white people in this society, even to begin to understand the problems that non-whites in South Africa are experi encing in a general sense.

I again plead with the Opposition to understand that the Prime Minister's statement should be regarded as a valuable contribution to the debate. This country can be proud of its past performance, as I said earlier, in regard for example to the Rhodesian struggle. People at the time said that the situation there was hopeless and that change would never occur. Honourable members on this side of the House were supportive of honourable members opposite in that struggle from time to time. I make the plea that one should question whether diplomatic approaches will work. I plead with the Opposition to consider whether or not it needs to move on this matter. In a recent Evatt memorial lecture one of the spokespersons opposite, who was on the Opposition front bench but who has now joined me on the back benches, made an excellent speech on this topic. I refer to the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) who expressed surprise when he received that invitation. In his contribution he was raising the question that his Party-perhaps he was referring to the coalition, I am not sure-was approaching the time when the sanction approach had to be seriously considered. I think he was saying that. Certainly the honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee) has been saying that. I do not want to enter into an argument based on the approach `You are there in a seat you have not been in for a while', because obviously there are differences in the Liberal Party on this topic. However, discussion and debate are taking place in that Party. I hope we shall see the birth of a process to take that discussion a step further. The honourable member for Kooyong referred to looking down the tunnel. I suggest that, if one looks down that tunnel, one sees that sanctions may be the next approach that honourable members opposite should consider.

I agree that sanctions on their own applied by Australia and other Commonwealth countries will not necessarily achieve the dramatic changes that we all want to see, but they are a step on the long road towards bringing about justice, fairness and equality within South Africa. We have to join with those people. I have some notes that I discussed with the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) that I wanted to incorporate relating to the question of trade, which is an important issue. We have to be fair dinkum and look at companies from South Africa moving in here with subsidiaries, setting up and operating here.
