Those people will now find that they face a significant extra bed-day cost of between $20 and $40. Those who are insured with the health funds will be called upon to meet these increased charges. The health funds obviously will be called upon to meet the increased charges and that will inevitably lead to an increase in contribution rates. One fund said this morning that it would have to increase rates by $1.50 a week.

TALK.START.PARA: —And it goes into the CPI.

—As the Deputy Leader of the Opposition quite rightly says, that will also increase the consumer price index. In addition, the fund this morning estimated that the overall cost of the Budget for the privately insured family would be around $5.50 a week, or $286 a year.

SPEECH.PARA: The removal of the private hospital subsidy is not the only way in which the Government has attacked the private health sector. By taking another $4m out of the Reinsurance Trust Fund, the Government will also be moving to force up private health fund premiums. Since the introduction of Medicare, this Government has taken $99m of a $100m Reinsurance Trust Fund; it has left in the fund only $1m. The increase in the gap from $10 to $20 for medical services in hospitals will cost the funds $29m. The increase in the Medicare levy will also mean that people are put under even greater pressure to give up their private health insurance. In pushing up both tax and health fund contribution rates, the government has really put the squeeze on the community. Inevitably the result will be that some of those people who currently have private insurance will be forced to give it up. We all know that the long term goal of the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) is to run the private health sector out of business.

TALK.START.PARA: —And put all doctors on the payroll as well.

—The honourable member is quite right, and there is no doubt that this Budget is another step down that track. The greater the number of people who are forced out of private insurance, and thereby become totally reliant on the public hospital system, the greater will be the growth in the already long queues for public hospital beds. There are already 100,000 Australians waiting, many in pain and distress, for public hospital beds around this country, and the Government's action has ensured that those 100,000 people will be joined by many more Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has, of course, put forward positive alternatives which would allow people to opt out of Medicare and take up private health insurance. They would thereby be able to utilise the empty private hospital beds, which would reduce public hospital queues and Government expenditure. It is no good for the Minister to say that there are no empty private hospital beds. There are. The head of his Department said so on the record in a Senate Estimates committee hearing. We have a situation in which more than 100,000 people will be waiting for public hospital beds and we have empty private hospital beds, and this Government has forced people out of those private hospital beds by forcing up the cost of private insurance.

The Government's health budget totally lacks credibility. The credibility of the Prime Minister has again been shattered by the breach of his Medicare levy promises, the government has cooked the health budget books and has again understated health expenditure, and, finally, the consequences of the changes that the Government has made to the costs of the delivery of private health services will aggravate the health crisis and public hospital queues will grow. The Government and this Minister for Health have committed Australians to a course of increased suffering and despair. No Budget since the introduction of Medicare in February 1984 has been so clearly designed to meet Labor's long term health goals. Those goals are, of course, to nationalise medicine, abolish private practice, close private hospitals and destroy private health insurance.

In today's matter of public importance I make three fundamental points: The Medicare levy is not only a breach of a fundamental promise made by the Prime Minister, but a breach of the accord; the Budget Papers themselves reveal a possible $120m understatement of health expenditure and the deficit; and, finally, the increase in private health costs resulting from the Budget will aggravate the health crisis in this country and public hospital queues will grow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker--
—Resign, you murderer.
— Order! The honourable member for Denison will withdraw that remark.
—I will, but two people from Denison have died.
—Order! The honourable member for Denison will withdraw the remark unreservedly.
—I withdraw.

—Apart from the strong support of the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter) for the accord, which I welcome, again we had no original comment in what he said today about the health challenges facing this country. One might have thought, given the Government's responsible, constructive, even creative response to the difficulties faced in the whole health area, that we might at last have got some original, even constructive, comment from the honourable member for Barker.
—You cannot keep changing the truth.
—Order! Honour- able members on my left will cease interjecting. The honourable member for Barker was heard in silence; the Minister should be heard in silence.

—But of course we get the same old misconceptions, the quite misleading refusal to admit that $1.3 billion of the medical benefit costs have always been paid by governments to pensioners and the disadvantaged without any levy whatsoever. There was also a refusal to acknowledge that the removal of a tax rebate for health insurance has made major savings to the Government on the revenue side.

SPEECH.PARA: Those misconceptions continue. They refuse to face such issues. They refuse to face the facts in health, including the problem of the supply of doctors and their influence on increasing health costs. They refuse to deal with the issue of excess hospital beds and their contribution to increasing costs. They say nothing at all about the problems of high technology in health.

Indeed, the honourable member for Barker is notorious among health professionals for having been in the job of shadow Minister for almost two years and made not a single constructive suggestion about the health challenges facing this country. That statement needs one qualification. The honourable member for Barker has been obsessed with one issue-direct billing. I shall not deal at length with that today, but I will make two points about direct billing. It is mainly of benefit to the less well-off in society, and 70 per cent of all direct-billed services go to pensioners and the disadvantaged. The remaining 30 per cent are mainly in working-class areas, and the evidence suggests that it helps the poor and larger families. The direct billing provision is primarily of benefit to the poor, the less well-off and the disadvantaged. Secondly-this is the chief reason why the honourable member for Barker-

TALK.START.PARA: —And you do absolutely nothing about it.
-Order! The honourable member for Barker will cease interjecting.

—I am happy to hear his noises, because the chief reason for his objection is that he knows that direct billing introduces the one effective competitive element to help to keep down doctors' fees. As a representative of some of the groups which do not want that control, this is his one suggestion as to how we should tackle our health challenges.

SPEECH.PARA: What the Government has managed to achieve in this Budget, particularly in health, is the meeting of twin goals-a contribution to cost containment, which has been the object of the Budget, while maintaining and in some cases improving the equitable nature of health arrangements. In addition, although this was not acknowledged by the honourable member for Barker, we have been able to bring extra assistance to some groups in the community which, for many years, have had special health care problems that were unaddressed by previous Liberal governments.

I shall come to those points later, but I should note that the matter of public importance itself argues that the health budget has resulted in higher Government and higher personal health costs. If we look at Budget Paper No. 1, we can see that health outlays as a proportion of the total Budget are the same this year as they were last year in a zero growth budget in terms of outlays. The increase in health expenditure is 7.7 per cent, which is roughly in line with inflation. When one takes into account the extra contribution of the increased medicare levy, one sees that it is nonsense to talk about this Budget increasing Government health costs.

Indeed, I would hope for some support from the Opposition-if it is possible for them to contemplate the problems seriously rather than demagogically-for the efforts that we have made this year to reduce overall health costs. I hope that the Opposition will support the deferral of uniformity and fee increases until 1 November, which saves $85m this year. In the climate of restraint in the community, all sections, not just ordinary working men and women, must bear their share of restraint. I hope that the deferral of those fee increases until 1 November will attract support from both sides of the houses.

Secondly, we have saved costs by the abolition of the private hospital day bed subsidy. I shall deal with that in detail in a moment. Thirdly, there has been an increase in the patient gap from $10 to $20. This figure has not been increased since 1978. It will not affect most services-for instance, consultations-only those high-cost services which are mostly covered by basic health insurance tables when the services relate to private patients. Of course, those charges are not made on public patients in public hospitals.

We have passed through this Parliament major changes to the pathology arrangements, including a 25 per cent reduction in fees for 18 items, which saves $50m this year. Anyone who has read the reports of the Public Accounts Committee and followed the debates in the country will know that this is a major way of tackling the growth in costs in medical benefits. Again, we would hope that such actions would be supported by all people who think, and do not just talk, about the problems of health. We have saved $67m in the pharmaceutical area by restructuring the pharmaceutical benefits scheme but in a way that protects pensioners and provides support for the chronically ill. Cost attainment has been an essential part of the overall Government strategy. Restraint has been exercised in health as it has across the board. But in health, as in other areas, the restraint has been exercised with equity. Indeed, there have been some achievements in health that were completely ignored by the honourable member for Barker.

Let me first deal with the equity features. The new pharmaceutical benefits scheme will provide sufferers of chronic illnesses and other high-volume users with increased protection against the high cost of pharmaceuticals. A safety net of 25 prescriptions will apply to general and concessional users which is a long-overdue reform. Of course, pensioners will still get pharmaceuticals free. We have introduced this scheme to protect the chronically ill by imposing a limit on what they must pay for their pharmaceuticals. It is true that there will be some increase for general users. All pharmaceuticals costing between $5 and $10 will be charged for at their retail price, and we estimate that the average price will be $7.30. But those with chronic conditions and those in need of heavy medication will be protected as they have never been protected in the past. The rest of us who, on the whole, use less medication, will accept our contribution to containing health costs and to better protection for the chronically ill. The new scheme was worked out not just by the Government but in close collaboration with the Pharmacy Guild of Australia, which has been highly supportive of the Government's actions.

In addition, concerned as we are with the chronically ill, we shall be making an annual grant of $7.5m to the Australian Diabetes Foundation to provide diabetics with essential supplies, especially syringes. This program will commence in April 1987. In addition, there will be funding for free hepatitis B vaccine for babies of mothers in high risk groups to augment state programs in this area. That will cost $2.8m in a full year.

We shall provide $700,000 for the national campaign against measles and an additional $1m for family planning, whose funding will increase to $7.8m in 1986-87. There will be a $26m contribution to a bicentennial public health initiative over the next three years. There will be a $7.7m-15 per cent-increase for medical research, whose budget will be increased to $59m. In the life of this Government, in four budgets, we have almost doubled the moneys paid for medical research. There will be a $10m program for AIDS, which is again a significant increase on last year. All Australian governments will pay $34.2m in total towards the national campaign against drug abuse, including funding for more than 120 cost-shared projects. We shall provide $7.7m for the transfer of nurse education, and 6500 students have so far transferred. In a very difficult climate-and no one pretends that it is not-we have taken appropriate new initiatives in major public health areas.

The Government believes that the increase in the Medicare levy is the most equitable way of dealing with costs in health, because low income-earners and the disadvantaged pay no levy. Indeed, the cutoff points below which no levy is payable will be increased from 1 December. For a single person, it will now be $8030 a year. For a married couple, it will be $13,370 a year, with an additional allowance of $1,660 for each child. By using the levy arrangements, we have dealt with health costs in the most equitable way. Additional contributions to health care costs are most fairly shared throughout the community by a levy increase. This is in line with the fundamental principle that lies behind Medicare that all Australians should contribute to the cost of health insurance according to their means of paying.

I want finally to deal with the private hospital issue. I suppose more nonsense has been talked on this issue than any other in the Press and by the honourable member for Barker. The abolition of the Commonwealth private hospital subsidy is not of itself expected to have a major impact on private health insurance premiums, despite what has been said. I will explain the reasons for this. Likewise, there will be no loss of revenue for private hospitals treating insured patients. What will happen is that the benefits payable on the basic insurance table will be increased on 1 October by $20, $30 or $40, depending on the type of hospital, to make up for the removal of the Commonwealth subsidy. What will be the impact of those changes on the health insurance contribution rates?

First of all, let me say that when the Government imposed restraint on itself and asked for restraint from ordinary Australians it was also asking for restraint in prices from the great commercial organisations in this society. The private health funds have done very well indeed out of Medicare. In fact, the health insurance funds' financial reserves have increased dramatically under Medicare. Indeed, the latest available figures show that the fund reserves now total $570m. The funds are commercial organisations well able to exercise restraint in relation to their contribution rates.

On the basis of the decision that has been made; that is, to remove the private hospital subsidy, Australia's largest health fund has informed me that its increase will be only 50c a week for family membership. It is expected that most other funds in a competitive situation and with large reserves will follow the lead of that major fund. Additionally, the private hospitals are in a relatively healthy state. Their bed numbers have grown at 3.38 per cent annually since the introduction of Medicare, their bed utilisation rate is on the increase and large corporations and chains are being formed to operate groups of hospitals. Indeed, honourable members opposite need only to read their business journals to see how profitable an area private hospitals have become. We have current market prices in the private hospital area as high as $150,000 per hospital bed. In this climate of restraint, the hospitals are another group that should be expected to exercise restraint in relation to their fees. I also note that in special cases a number of major private charitable hospitals, mostly of a religious kind, have historically provided hospital care for needy uninsured patients, and we have evidence of that. If the viability of those hospitals has been reliant on that charitable work, they will be looked at and assistance arrangements will be worked out between the hospitals and the Government. In the detailed examination of what this Government has done in the Budget, I believe that in the health area we have honoured completely and utterly the commitment by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that we must have restraint, but that that restraint must be with equity.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —One is always interested in listening to the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) because he sounds such a reasonable man. He stands up in the Parliament and other places and goes through the catalogue of the so-called achievements of the Hawke socialist Government in terms of health care, and it all sounds so reasonable. He says that we have honoured the objective of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and his statements of restraint. He does not say, of course, that he has totally dishonoured a promise that both he and the Prime Minister made during the last election campaign. He does not say anything about that.

SPEECH.PARA: When we strip away all the apparent reasonableness of the Minister for Health, what do we find? What does the average Australian find when he or she is confronted with the health administration system presently operating in Australia? We find an increase in costs for the many thousands of Australians who rely on the health care system for medical treatment and attention. We find hundreds of thousands of Australians queueing for elective surgery. No reasonable statement by the Minister for Health will get away from the reality of those people who queue and wait in pain and suffering for elective surgery. No reasonable statement from the Minister will help alleviate the sadness which affects the families of those people who wait in queues with no apparent thought given by the Government for the suffering that they are going through.

What about the many thousands of pensioners throughout Australia who will pay more for necessary and commonly used pharmaceuticals as a result of this Government's and this Minister's administration of the health care system? Reasonableness will not get them anywhere; they will have to pay more. What about the millions of Australians who will pay more through the Medicare levy? They are not too concerned about having a reasonable Minister for Health; they are concerned about the extra money they will have to pay out for the Medicare levy. What about those other millions of Australians who not only pay extra for the Medicare levy, but also will be faced with extra health insurances premiums coming from this Government's attack on Australian hospitals?

I take the House back to those halcyon days of the Australian Labor Party's election promises of 1983. The Minister in the House today was for some years before then advocating Medicare as being the panacea for all the problems which beset the health administration systems in this country. This was going to be the system which brought in the best medical and hospital attention at an affordable price. It was portrayed, as so many of these things were portrayed at the time, as a socialist paradise beginning to emerge in the health area. Now we face the reality, as so many other countries have faced it, of the imposition of a socialist ideal on a system which simply does not fit it. As I have already mentioned, we have queues of people seeking treatment.

Let us look at some other aspects of the health administration system which this Minister and this Government have forced on our country. For the first time in Australia's medical history we have nursing staff leaving their profession because they are sick and tired of the difficulties and the problems that have been forced on them by the imposition of this stupid scheme. Public administrators right throughout Australia are making it absolutely plain both publicly and privately that the public hospitals simply are unable to meet the pressures and the needs being forced upon them. Quite frankly, the system has been tried and found wanting. A similar system was tried and found wanting overseas. We have and we see in the imposition of this system a manifestation of a socialist ideal proving to be detrimental to the ordinary man and woman throughout Australia. It is a system that does not care for people. It is a socialist ideal which simply does not fit in with the way people want their health to be looked after. How much extra will the average wage earner have to pay on the Medicare levy? It will be about $52 a year. That is because the levy has gone up from one per cent to 1.25 per cent.

I just mention again, because it bears repeating and I want more people to understand it, that this is yet another broken election promise. The Prime Minister is always talking about integrity. He mentions integrity more than just about any other member of this House. I worry about that, because when somebody talks about a subject constantly-and he talks about his own integrity constantly-it makes one wonder what he has to hide, what he has to worry about. If his integrity were so sound he would not have to keep protesting it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be obvious.

—It would be obvious. But what is obvious is that his integrity and the integrity of his Government is very much open to question. Here we have another prime example. In 1984 the Prime Minister said: `We will not lift the Medicare levy'. What happens in 1986? It goes up by 25 per cent. The Minister does not even apologise for it. He says quite proudly: `We have met the Prime Minister's requirements'. Let us not forget that this is yet another broken prime ministerial promise, and it is a promise that the Minister for Health has reiterated throughout Australia time and again.

SPEECH.PARA: But, as my colleague the Shadow Minister for Health has pointed out, even this increase of 25 per cent does not pay the full cost of Medicare. So what is being done? As taxpayers, we are paying twice for a failed system. What will the rate go up to in the future if the cost containment exercise that the Minister keeps talking about simply does not work? As the shadow Minister said, there was a blow-out last year of $166m in the total medical and hospital costs-and that despite fudging on the payments to the doctors during the last month of the financial year. What is it likely to go up to this year? It was mentioned today that a figure of $120m is on the cards for the blow-out. If the Budget does not work, what will we be looking at in extra costs under this socialised system which was to be the panacea and to bring such a tremendous system of health care to every man and woman in Australia? What a lot of nonsense! There is suffering; there are queues; people are actually dying because they cannot get into hospital. Doctors are going on strike; nurses are going on strike. That is the sort of system that this Government has brought into this country.

Subsidies to private hospitals are to be abolished, representing $129m in a full year. What a stupid thing to do. It is being done on the apology of saving money. What will it do? It will have the immediate impact and effect of increasing health insurance premiums by $1 to $2 a week. What will that cause? Does the Government think that that will encourage people to join the health insurance funds? What a lot of nonsense! Of course, it will force more and more people out of the health insurance funds. What will they do if they are forced out of the health insurance funds? They will line up at the public hospitals. How much does it cost them to go to the public hospitals? It costs the Government $40 a day bed subsidy in private hospitals. But how much does it cost the Government for a person who goes to a public hospital? It costs $280 per bed day in a public hospital. What extraordinary economics from the Minister at the table. This is supposed to be a so-called cost saving. But what will the effect of it be? It will force up insurance costs. It will force people out of the insurance organisations and onto the public hospital system which, as we all know, is already totally overstrained. Over 100,00 Australians are queuing up to go into public hospitals for elective surgery.

The simple fact is that Medicare has failed, It looks good on paper. It looks terrific on paper. But it does not work; that is its main problem. It simply does not work. We will have an imposition of economics onto something on which one cannot use the usual impact of economic theory. Medical costs do not fit into the economic theories. Queues will increase. Costs will increase. Strikes will increase. It will further diminish the morale of the health service professionals. Whether they be doctors, paramedics, nurses or those in other fields of medicine, their morale will be further diminished. Finally, the Government will achieve that great success of which I do not think it will really be proud. It will achieve a two-tiered system-one for the rich and one for the poor. For the first time in Australia's history we will have a system of medicine for the rich and a lesser system of medicine for the poor because the poor simply will not be able to afford the cost of medicine--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition talks about gall yet its history in health policy is a saga of twists and turns that had everyone confused for the entire term that it was in office. It is fair to look at the Opposition's proposals and to see what it would like to do. It would not surprise me if what Opposition members are really telling us is that they want to go back in time. They are really caught in a time warp-and not only in health policy. If we look at their policy on taxes, we see that they want to go back and to get rid of the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax and all of the reforms relating to retirement incomes, the assets test and lump sum superannuation that have fixed up the taxation system and made it fairer. As for industry, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) says that he can dig up another couple of mines and revive Australian industry. The Opposition has no policy but just wants to go back to the 1970s and early 1980s. As for wages, he wants the old free for all system that existed under his Government. The Opposition's health policy of going back to the failed and unfair scheme of the Fraser years means that the rich can opt out while low and middle income earners get hit with a levy well in excess of what they pay under the universal scheme of this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the House that this Government's scheme, Medicare, is based on income, on the ability to pay, which is how it should be. It will be a poor day in Australian history when the quality of health care that one receives is dependent on one's income. Under the universal Medicare system, everyone contributes equitably, that is, according to one's means. It is based on a percentage of income. In contrast, health insurance is based on a flat rate. It does not matter whether one earns $100,000 a year or $10,000 a year, one pays the same rate. There is no fairness or equity in that. Health care is a basic requirement for everybody in this community regardless of income. It is much fairer to have a system based on the ability to pay rather than on a flat rate of payment.

The proposal put up by the Opposition without government subsidies means that the cheapest private health insurance would cost about $25 a week. I will look a little later at the impact of that on the different ranges of income and what it will mean to people on low and high incomes. It would not surprise anybody here to know that what the Opposition really wants is what the previous speaker, the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar), spoke about-two schemes, one for the rich and one for the poor. Thus the rich would be able to opt out of contributing through the tax system to the health care of those people less well off. Middle and low income earners would have to pay more. That is a reversal of our scheme. Under our scheme, people on higher incomes pay a higher amount, as the Medicare levy is based on a percentage of wages, and lower income earners pay less. That is very much more equitable. The Medicare system recognises that there are people on very low incomes who cannot afford the Medicare levy. Those people are exempt from the levy. The cut off rate is indexed so that as inflation takes earnings higher, the cut off rate is increased. Income tax creep does not result in those people paying the levy. We have protected those people in that way.

The question has to be asked: If the Opposition has so much faith in the unfair arrangement that I spoke of previously, why did it abandon it the first time round and go on to experiment with one mishmash of a health scheme after another? There were five or six different changes in five or six years. Nobody really knew where they were. I suppose it kept many printers busy printing all of the different forms. But it did little else. It just had everybody confused. The Opposition does not want to face the facts about the virtues of Medicare as it now is. Opposition members will not be honest about the facts implicit in their alternative scheme.

As I have said, under Opposition Policy, it will cost $25 a week for private health insurance. As I have said, we will look at the impact that that will have on people with different incomes. Someone with an income of $20,000 a year currently pays $299 a year by way of levy for basic hospital and medical cover. Even if that person wishes to add private hospital cover to this, the cost is still only $579 a year.

Under the proposals put forward by the Opposition the payments would be increased by $14 a week. The amount would go from $579 to $1,300 a year, which is the flat rate. The comparison is that, under Medicare, for the same hospital cover one pays $579 a year instead of $1,300 under the Opposition's proposal.

A family on a taxable income of $50,000 a year will also be better off under Medicare. The Medicare levy for such a family currently is $572 a year. If that family wishes to have private hospital cover, it would still pay only $920 a year. That means that that family pays $920 a year, being the Medicare levy plus the private additional cost for hospital cover. That $920 a year compares with the Opposition's proposal which would cost $1,300 a year. Once again, such a family would pay more under the Opposition's proposal-in fact, $7 a week more. The Opposition did not say much about that.

Let us look at people earning $100,000 a year. These are the people whom the Opposition wants to help. The only person who might consider himself better off under the Opposition's scheme is a person earning $100,000 a year or more. At present that person must pay a levy of $1,145, or $1,495 for the levy and private hospital cover. The Opposition's scheme provides for a flat rate of $1,300 a year, compared with the present levy of $1,495. Therefore, people earning $100,000 a year or more would be much better off under the Opposition's policy.

I spoke earlier about the fact that the Opposition's policies are backward-looking. Under those policies the rich would get their own health scheme. They would be protected from having to pay a fringe benefits tax. They would be able to dine at restaurants and have their meals subsidised by the taxpayers. The rich were always better off before the imposition of the capital gains tax. We know of at least 12 millionaires who received the pension before the imposition of the assets tax. Many more had the nous not to fill out the form. Lump sum superannuation arrangements, once again, were usually the preserve of the more affluent. The Opposition would revoke all of those measures. It prefers to help those who are better off in our society at the expense of those who are less well off. That is a measure of Liberal fairness.

What about the unanswered questions in regard to the Opposition's scheme? Would a Howard government-were it to be elected-pay a Commonwealth benefit of any sort to people who take out private insurance? Would it use taxpayers' money to prop up that private hospital insurance, as is the case in regard to the education system? Would it allow the funds to offer gap insurance, recognising that that gives the incentive to doctors to charge more than the schedule fee? This is a very subtle way of allowing doctors to put up their fees, to pirate the patients, if one likes, and to charge exorbitant rates. I make the distinction between general practitioners and surgeons, who are usually the people who charge such rates. Does the Opposition propose to keep bulk billing pensioners? The Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) raised this question; it is a question that must be answered.

Does the Opposition intend to offer tax rebates for health fund contributions? We all remember that that practice was allowed in the infamous family Budget of the Fraser Government. The previous Government might have philosophically believed that people should receive some tax relief if health insurance helped to ease the burden on the public purse. However, it never applied that belief until the family Budget was brought down. Of course, the previous Government could not sustain the cost-not that the cost was a worry to it, because it framed that Budget so that it could win the 1983 election. However, this speaks volumes about its integrity in regard to the issue of bulk billing.

Opposition members have contradicted each other. The honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter) said that health care costs are rising because unscrupulous doctors are overservicing and direct billing. Some members of his Party would agree with the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron), who said that doctors are so intimidated by the Government's fraud and overservicing surveillance mechanisms that they are underservicing. They are two extreme positions. On the one hand, the honourable member for Barker says that doctors are making piles and piles of money out of the system; on the other hand, the honourable member for Moreton, who is a member of the same Party, the Liberal Party, says that they are not doing that. He says that doctors are being intimidated and, in fact, are not providing as many services as they could. I do not know who in the Liberal Party we should believe. We can take our pick or maybe take a central position. I do not know which of their utterances to believe.

In closing, I think it is important to look at what may be one of the causes of increased health care in this country. In terms of the medical market we cannot and should not continue to think solely in terms of policies aimed at reducing patient demand. We should look at the number of doctors in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allocated for this debate has now expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Millar Mr P.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, I present the fifth report for 1986 of the Committee, relating to the provision of 50 replacement houses at Woomera, and I ask leave of the House to make a short statement in connection with the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee found this inquiry both unique and challenging-unique because Woomera is located in an isolated part of South Australia, with a climate that would tax even the most equable temperament; challenging because of Woomera's retreat from its halcyon, days when it enjoyed a population of 6,000 resulting from the activities of the United Kingdom-Australia joint project, to a population presently of about 1,900 people. This circumstance has generated a view in some places that Woomera is in a state of continuing decline and, as a consequence further investment by way of housing would be unsustainable.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee paid particular attention to this aspect and was thoroughly satisfied by cross-examination of witnesses that there would be a defence commitment for at least the next 15 years and therefore it would be financially prudent and socially responsible for the existing houses at Woomera to be replaced. They are old and have reached the end of their economic life. Refurbishment of the housing to an acceptable level would not be cost-effective; indeed, refurbishment would exceed the cost of replacement houses.

Against this background, and in the context of negotiations between the Commonwealth and the South Australian Government about normalising Woomera, the Committee has concluded there is a need to provide 50 replacement houses. The Committee has recommended, however, that the houses should be of a higher standard than that proposed. The Committee further proposes that other instrumentalities or bodies obliged to provide accommodation for their employees or personnel should seek on the score of cost benefit to incorporate their housing needs with the defence proposal contained within this reference.

The Committee's report contains recommendations about the process of normalisation, the need for other Commonwealth departments and statutory authorities to rectify housing allocated to their employees and a number of other matters relating to construction of the houses. The Committee believes these recommendations should be examined carefully by the Government before any decisions are taken about proceeding with the work. I thank the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present the 252nd report of the Committee entitled `Job Seeker-Computer Acquisition by the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations'. I seek leave to make a short statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report contains the findings of the Committee's inquiry into the Job Seeker computer acquisition and related aspects of the automatic data processing operations of the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations. It was tabled in the Senate on 13 June 1986 by Senator Georges, the Committee chairman. This inquiry resulted from advice to the Committee of an unusual level of disquiet in the computer vendor industry about the conduct of the Job Seeker tender and from serious criticisms made by the Auditor-General in his September 1985 report about the adequacy of planning, cost-benefit justification and management supporting a previous ADP contract in the Department, Job Bank.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee's principal concerns about the Job Seeker computer acquisition were reported to the Parliament in a statement made by the chairman of the Public Accounts Committee, Senator Georges, to the Senate on 3 December 1985. I propose to seek leave to incorporate a copy of the statement. The Committee took the unusual step of making such a statement, prior to the completion of its inquiry and the tabling of its full report, because of the Committee's concern not to delay unnecessarily the implementation of the Job Seeker project and several other computer-based projects in the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations.

The Committee's principal concerns stated at that time were that, proper planning and evaluation had not been undertaken to support the particular implementation strategy chosen for the Job Seeker project. There were documented instances during the tender evaluation where proper tendering procedures were not followed. In consequence, the impartiality of the tender result could not be guaranteed. Furthermore, certain features of the original contract with the successful tenderer, Wang Computer Pty Ltd, were improper.

The Committee, having given careful consideration to the costs resulting from the cancellation of the Job Seeker tender, recommended that the Job Seeker purchase proceed, subject to important amendments being made to the proposed contract with the recommended supplier, Wang Computer Pty Ltd. Subsequent advice from the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations and the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services indicated that most of these amendments were made before the contract was signed with Wang on 31 January 1986.

The Committee had some outstanding concerns about the inadequate level of compensation provided for in the contract with Wang in the event that Wang was unable to deliver by 30 June 1986 certain crucial and critical outstanding performance requirements of the request for tender. This was viewed by the Committee to be of paramount importance because Wang's commitment to deliver this performance by 30 June 1986 had been a deciding factor in the company winning the contract. Additionally, this performance was a mandatory requirement of the tender specification and crucial to the successful implementation of the Job Seeker system. The Committee was therefore greatly concerned when it subsequently learnt that Wang had in fact been unable to deliver this performance by the due date and had lodged a claim for excusable delay. The Committee was informed yesterday that the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services has, after seeking legal advice from the Attorney-General's Department, refused Wang's claim for excusable delay. Wang has been advised that it has 30 days in which to deliver the outstanding performance or the contract will be terminated. If Wang fails to deliver, as appears likely, and this contract is cancelled, the consequence will be that the Job Seeker project and a range of other labour force and youth programs in the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations which are dependent on computer support will be delayed by as much as 18 months. The Job Seeker project is already well behind schedule and it may be a further 12 months before a re-tender is completed and alternative equipment delivered.

The Committee stands by the view that it expressed when this report was tabled in the Senate in June, that should this contract be cancelled, the Commonwealth should seek full compensation from Wang for the major delay and dislocation to the Commonwealth's employment and labour force programs which have resulted from Wang's failure to deliver as it had contracted. The Committee recommends that all equipment purchased or loaned by the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations should be returned. It also endorses the stand taken by the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services that no further equipment purchases be made until a new contract has been awarded and the Department is in a position to standardise on new equipment. The Committee believes that, notwithstanding the urgency of the Job Seeker project and other projects in that Department, it would be indefensible for the Department to purchase equipment which is not part of a standardised computing environment in the Department.

In summary, these recent developments fully vindicate the findings contained in the Committee's report and fully confirm the concerns which Senator Georges stated on 3 December 1985 to the Parliament. As a personal aside, I would add that it also vindicates the view of those of us in all parties who strongly support an effective committee system operating in the Parliament.

The Committee has concluded that the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations, and in particular the Secretary to that Department, must carry principal responsibility for the improper manner in which this tender was conducted and its consequences. The Department of Local Government and Administrative Services and its Secretary, given the clear responsibilities of that Department for ensuring that procurement proceeds in line with government purchasing practices and policies, must also carry responsibility in this matter. The Department of Employment and Industrial Relations has undoubtedly moved with great speed over the past few years in implementing computer-based information systems to support and expand the services it provides to its clients. However, in the case of the Job Seeker project the Committee believes that this speed and the Department's disregard for proper planning and procurement procedures have undoubtedly now resulted in much greater delay and cost than would have occurred had planning and procurement proceeded in the proper manner.

I commend the report to honourable members. I am informed by the officers of the Parliament that Senator Georges's statement which I sought to incorporate does not conform to the guidelines of the House, as I had been led to believe by officers of the Committee. I do not believe it necessary to read that rather lengthy statement into the record of the House of Representatives, but I would refer all honourable members to the statement made in the Senate by the Chairman of the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member's comments are noted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the interruption at lunchtime of this debate on the Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities I was mentioning the fact that the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) had claimed that the Dibb report is an intellectually complex and rigorous analysis, a significant intellectual achievement. I commented that complexity, clarity and consistency are not as important as the substance of the rationale and the final recommendations.

SPEECH.PARA: Quite simply, the rationale is flawed, I believe, and the recommendations subsequently as a result of that rationale are inadequate. The Opposition said so when the report was first released, and we have now been joined in our concern over fundamental aspects of the report by such notable people as Admiral Sir Anthony Synnot, the former Chief of Defence Force Staff; Air Marshal David Evans, the former Chief of Air Staff; Vice Admiral Leach, the former Chief of Naval Staff; Major General Stevenson, the former Chief of Logistics; the United States Commander in the Pacific, as I have already mentioned, and Drs Ball and Babbage from the Strategic and Defence Studies Centres. Overall, the report would ultimately lead to a situation where our adversary would have the initiative and be able to force disproportionate responses on us without offering our commanders any similar capacity-an intolerable situation for us to be in.

I wish finally to challenge the generally optomistic strategic assessment that the Dibb report presents and the Government appears to accept. Not all the plausible scenarios for Australian security and its strategic environment at the turn of the century are, to use the words of the 1982 report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, `cautiously reassuring'. It is not unjustified, I believe, to describe peace and stability in Australia's region as precarious. There are a number of existent and latent sources of conflict and instability, including economic development problems such as food, resource, energy and employment shortages; internal ethnic and religious conflicts; problems of leadership succession; conflicting off-shore territorial claims; long standing national enmities and border conflicts; resource and market competition; massive increases in military competition and the introduction of advanced military technologies; and, finally, the expansion of the presence and influence of the Soviet Union and its proxies, Vietnam, Cuba and Libya.

It has been said that an army is a body of men assembled to rectify the mistakes of diplomats. I believe that this report is dangerously optimistic and flawed. It needs critical amendment and supplementation. If the Government wishes to proceed to questions of force structure, it should develop a more realistic and prudent set of strategic assumptions and rationale and review, as we have heard in the last couple of days since the Budget was brought down, its pitiful recent Budget handouts to Defence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mayer Ms H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was most interested in the final remarks of the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster), I really was. I am still a little puzzled about the aggression that Vietnam, Cuba and Libya could offer us. However, I think there are some interesting quotes in the report of the Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities and it may be that the honourable member has not read them. Mr Dibb says quite clearly that no country has ever blockaded another country which is surrounded by sea, such as Australia. That is a pretty reasonable and rational sort of statement. It is rather hard to think of a country which would have the capacity, the desire and the need to blockade a country with our coastline. However, given that we have the odd person around here who sees that as a possibility, we need to ask ourselves whether we should use that as the basis of our national defence and equipment policy. I would suggest that it would certainly be very expensive.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to remind honourable members of the policy of the Opposition as recently as 19 November 1982. I shall read some extracts from a speech made then by the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) who was then the Minister for Defence. He made these comments when he was speaking to the Australian Defence Association. They may enlighten us about the basis of criticism by the Opposition of Mr Dibb's propositions. The right honourable member said:

In selecting those defence force elements that we need to produce an independent defence capability, it is essential to clarify as far as possible the nature of our future defence needs. The starting point for this is our examination of the range of credible circumstances that could arise to threaten Australia and particularly those circumstances in which substantial allied assistance may not be available.
He went on to say, for example:

Three threat situations are identifiable-operations by small raiding parties against important national installations, challenges to the sovereignty of our off-shore maritime resources and harassment of our coastal shipping.
We do not seem to be terribly far from the comments of Mr Dibb, do we? The right honourable member continued:

Rational thinking dictates that there would need to be a serious deterioration in our security outlook before we could justify the maintenance of all operational capabilities necessary to defend Australia against major attack.

I remind honourable members that that is not a statement by Mr Dibb, Mr Scholes or Mr Beazley. That was a statement by the right honourable member for New England, made not quite four years ago. I wonder what has changed in our environment to make it so impossible for Opposition members to accept Mr Dibbs analysis of the likely threat to our sovereignty. Let me quote from Mr Dibb who said:
An important and recurring theme of the Review is the need to concentrate force structure priorities on our area of direct military interest, where we should seek to exert independent military power.
I think that that statement sounds similar to the one I read a few moments ago.

I wish to take up some of the issues in the Dibb Report which I found extremely interesting. I must say that it was refreshing and exciting to be able to read a review of our defence capabilities and needs which had the clarity, the logical assumptions and the logical arguments and which covered the whole picture. It did not concentrate on one thing or another, leaving important bits out; it took the whole of our defence capabilities and needs and put them into a global context. In a recent speech the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) said:
A self reliant Australia is an expectation both of the Australian people and of our allies.

This has been required by our principal ally, the United States of America, since the early 1970s. Self reliance includes two very important areas addressed by Mr Dibb in his excellent report. These are the development of a proper infrastructure supporting our forces where we want them to be and the industrial development which allows us, as far as possible, to supply equipment and to support that equipment bought overseas. To deal with the industrial implications first, I wish to quote Mr Dibb who said:

The industrial capacity to maintain, repair, modify and adapt defence equipment to the Australian environment is of fundamental importance for our combat effectiveness and credible contingencies. Every effort should be made to limit our dependence on overseas sources of repair and maintenance support. Civil industry should contribute to maintenance, adaptation and through-life support of defence equipment.

That is a statement with which I wholeheartedly concur. We have to realise that industry capable of supplying our defence forces and defence industries and a specifically created defence industry are distinctions made by Mr Dibb in his analysis of the industrial needs of our defence forces. The problem with the defence industries as such is that they are limited to finite contracts or series of contracts for defence that are budget driven and this is probably the most expensive and wasteful way to go. It is really fascinating to find out who is responsible for all of that. The enormous subsidies required to keep our defence factories going and the capital investment in tooling and equipment, demands a totally different premise from that which has existed. Traditionally defence factories and facilities are limited to the supply of equipment or parts directly for the defence forces. Once the contract for equipment is fulfilled we have that `go-stop' situation which leaves facilities and skills unused and work forces depleted or doing far less than they are able to do.

Mr Dibb has recommended the introduction of commercial cost accounting and a start is being made at Williamstown Naval Dockyard and in a number of other areas where we have major projects. It is ironic that the disciples of privatisation for years resisted both effective commercial cost accounting and the freedom of these institutions to complete in the private sector for non-defence contracts. It is extraordinary to think that the taxpayer has set up many highly technical facilities with highly skilled work forces and has not been able to use those facilities or skills once the defence contracts have been fulfilled. The cost to the nation of the lack of commercial discipline and the subsidies and premiums paid is enormous.

These same prophets of efficiency, the privatisation disciples, failed to examine the efficiency and effectiveness of the management, both in defence and in the manufacturing facilities and allowed practices to continue which culminated in a finding by the Public Accounts Committee that of 16 projects examined by that Committee, 11 had failed or might fail to be completed on time to budget or to technical requirements. Yet all these projects were initiated by the previous Government and the control of those projects was determined by the previous Government, if it was interest at all, which I very much doubt.

Mr Dibb says that self reliance is not a prescription for Australia to have the full range of defence industrial capacities. I think that any rational person would agree with that. Inevitably there will be some reliance on overseas sources for components and for major parts of capital equipment. However, although defence purchasing is not the answer to Australia's industrial difficulties, the expenditure being only half a per cent of gross domestic product, it does have a high technological component which, properly used, can assist in the transfer of skills to our workforce for a much wider use. The great value of the Dibb Review in the industrial context is that given the sound and logical strategic basis, equipment purchasing planning can be undertaken in a way which would be of maximum benefit to Australian industry.

One phrase that one hears fairly frequently when talking to people about the way in which things are being managed in defence is `in hindsight'. The review allows us perhaps to replace that phrase with the word `foresight'. The Government, for example, in its handling of the submarine buy is exercising the very careful definition of needs and capabilities which, once they are put into operation, will be of permanent value to Australian industry. Rather than having competition between arms of the defence forces for preferred equipments and budget-driven decisions about whether some or all of those equipments will be bought, whether purchases will be started, slowed down or adjusted and whether manufacturing programs will be brought to a halt and then re-started, the propositions in the report would allow much more sensibly planned acquisition and build projects.
In the report a number of principles are identified in this area. They are worth quoting in full. The report states:

Every effort should be made to limit our dependence on overseas sources of repair and maintenance support. A critical area is electronics, particularly the software needed to support modern weapons systems. Australian private industry is increasingly developing high-grade and competitive expertise in this advanced-technology area.

Our requirements for design capacities are limited to those areas where we have unique Australian needs, but a skill base in the design area can be useful for the selection and adaptation of the most suitable overseas equipment. Much of our design skill base will, for this reason, need to be maintained within the Defence Science and Technology Organisation and Defence engineering staffs. But where unique Australian requirements exist, for example, mine countermeasures forces, every effort should be made to involve local industry at the design stage so that innovation is fostered and design requirements maximise local production opportunities.

Those are words of hope to Australian industry and particularly those industries that are interested in defence projects. They are words that bring about the understanding that, given the quality of this review, it is likely that Australian industry will not be in the situation of hoping, with its fingers crossed, that it will be allowed to partake in the manufacturing of our defence equipment.

There is no doubt that changing political theories have long distorted defence equipment provision. We have had the domino theory, the `great and powerful friends will look after us' theory, the forward defence theory and so forth, each formulation requiring a different mix of equipment and training. Given the long lead times in acquiring major capital equipment, it is not surprising that the innocent onlooker might be a bit confused on observing the variety of defence equipment. Mr Dibb identifies a number of areas requiring more attention. They include the testing of the logistics of operations in the north supported from the south, the developments of a comprehensive infrastructure to support our forces in the north and the examination of the use of civil assets in times of need.

Another facet of the infrastructure need not considered by Mr Dibb as it is not in his terms of reference but which was paid some attention by the Minister and which I think will need more close attention in the future is the social needs of the families of military personnel posted to northern bases. The social implication of a greater use of northern bases has considerable implications for the support and provision of facilities for the spouses and children of service personnel posted there whose housing, educational, career and recreational needs have been paid insufficient attention in the past.

Mr Dibb's report is a substantial basis for a much better level of debate on the needs of Australian defence. I must say that I have been extremely disappointed in the contributions of some of our retired military personnel, who seem to believe that they do not have to read the report in order to discuss it. If they do read the report, they read it with closed minds and hope that their favourite theory when they were young, whatever it was, will continue to be the prevailing theory. One finds all too often as one travels around Australia's major defence bases and industrial facilities the feeling that our service personnel and their families have been the victims of planning not based on sound, long term principles. The global considerations of Australian defence needs provided by this report offers just that. For the first time we have as a public document a statement of strategic principles and their implications for the development of defence bases, supporting infrastructure, equipment needs, personnel needs and the industrial and logistic support for Australian defence. Public debate and comment can address itself sensible to the propositions advanced.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the course of history many nations have made some fairly fatal errors in the determinations of their defence strategy. The statement made by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Chisholm (Ms Mayer), that Australia could never be blockaded is equal to any of those previous fatal errors in strategic determinations. Anything is possible in this world. Australia could quite easily be blockaded. In the course of the year hundreds of pieces of business come before the Parliament. As a result of all this business we tend, on an individual basis, not to see the significance of each piece of business as it comes through. The piece of business before the House tonight is probably the most significant thing that any government in any country can engage in; that is, determining proper and adequate defences for our nation. The defence of a nation is important because without it we can have no nation.

SPEECH.PARA: As a result of the last few months of economic ills the need for trade and the importance of trade in terms of how it affects our economy, our society and our Government has been borne out. I think it is fair to say that, if we cannot protect our trade, our society will be destabilised, our country's economy will collapse and our Government may fall. Indeed, our system of government may be put at peril. I am quite sure that the words of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) over the last few months exemplify that very statement. The Treasurer, of course, has said that because of our trading situation at the moment, with our huge current account deficit, Australia is becoming a banana republic. The Prime Minister has said that, because of our trading problems, we face the most serious economic time since the Great Depression. He has said that we are back to the time of the Second World War and our nation has to pull together in order to fight for itself and to maintain the sort of society and the sort of country that we want to live in. This has all come about because of our poor trading situation.

Let us just imagine what would happen if Australia's sea lanes were blockaded. The honourable member for Chisholm believes that it could not happen. If our sea lanes were blockaded our trade would be cut off. Eighty-six per cent of Australia's trade, in terms of value, comes via our sea lanes. That is worth $27 1/2 billion. If our trade were cut off the economic crisis of today would look like nothing. The political problems of today would fade into obscurity. Australia's problems would be massive. In fact, anybody who wanted to attack us could do so without having to fire a shot, purely and simply by blocking off our sea lanes and strangling our trade. That is one of the very flaws in the report of the Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities.

There are two flaws in the Dibb report that I believe are worth mentioning tonight. Whilst the report is a most comprehensive and detailed summary of Australia's strategy for the years ahead and has many good parts, I believe that the fact that it devotes only one of its 176 pages to discussing the protection of our sea lanes is in itself one of its great flaws. On the one page that the Dibb report devotes to talking about the protection of our sea lanes it argues that trade as a matter of defence is over-estimated; that because Australia has since the Second World War built up a manufacturing industry and a lower percentage of its gross domestic product depends upon trade, there really is no need to worry if trade is blocked off. It argues that on the one and only page devoted to the protection of our sea lanes. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: (Budget Debate)
Debate resumed from 19 August, on motion by Mr Keating:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The challenge now facing Australia goes far beyond one of immediate economic crisis. It is also a challenge to many of the attitudes and institutions of our past. The right response to this challenge will require not only Budget decisions of a radically different order than that proposed by the Government, but also some fundamental changes of attitude and direction on the part of the Australian people. All of us will utterly delude and deceive ourselves if we accept for a moment the Government's claim that the only problem we have now is a temporary reversal of our terms of trade. The problem goes far deeper and much further than that. It is in the context of that broader challenge that this year's Budget must be assessed.

SPEECH.PARA: The fundamental failure of this Budget is that it offers not a flicker of hope that the Hawke Government has the will, the vision or the commitment to promote those basic changes to attitudes and institutions which are so clearly needed. Tonight I propose to give some of the directions that the coalition will follow after the next election. In doing so, I shall indicate the areas of greatest disagreement between the Opposition and the Government.

There are six major reforms and changes of direction that are needed if there is to be any hope that the Australian economy can be turned around from its present malaise for the long-term good of us all. These reforms must include reduced government spending, reduced levels of taxation, reduced levels of militant union power, the provision of greater incentives for both employers and employees, the encouragement of further overseas investment and a major improvement in our transport and communications systems.

The profound scepticism already demonstrated by financial markets reflects not only a rejection of the arithmetic of the Budget but also a belief that it is too little, too late. It also reflects the fact that the Budget is essentially negative. The Budget does not point the way for the future. It does not even indicate how the Government will overcome its horrendous budgetary problems next year.

The Treasurer (Mr Keating) says that it is a tough Budget. Yet strangely for a tough Budget, it does not provide for the abolition of a single ongoing function of the Federal Government. The level of spending under this Budget is greater than that under each of the seven Budgets of the former coalition Government. Moreover, the Government is extraordinarily complacent about inflation, our balance of payments crisis and our national debt. This year, Australia's inflation rate will be at least 8 per cent. That is four times that of our major trading partners and 16 times that of Japan, our best customer. Our current account deficit is predicted to amount to a staggering $15 billion this year. On these Budget estimates, Australia is going into debt at the rate of $30,000 a minute. Our international debt on a gross basis will reach at least $100 billion by next year.

The so-called `World's Greatest Treasurer' has the great distinction of out-spending, out-taxing and out-borrowing any of his predecessors on either side of politics. The Hawke Government has smashed to pieces, for the second year in a row, its much proclaimed trilogy promise not to increase taxation as a percentage of gross domestic product. This has been in every sense a taxing and not an axing Budget. The much vaunted deficit of $3.5 billion has largely been achieved through a tax hike of $1.4 billion and absurdly optimistic forecasts of economic and employment growth. The promised and much-heralded personal tax cuts were not only delayed three months. They have been effectively wiped out by the new tax rises announced by the Treasurer in the Budget.

Australia faces an economic crisis unmatched since the Great Depression of over 50 years ago. It is to the everlasting shame of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer that they both misled and deceived the Australian public for so long about the true state of our economic plight. Only three months ago, the Treasurer said that the Australian economy was `entirely healthy' and that we had the strongest growing economy in the Western world. The Prime Minister joined the chorus, describing our economy as `entirely robust'. For over 18 months this Labor Government ignored all warnings about the State of our economy and rejected all responsible plans for responding to the looming problems. Instead, Labor maintained that all was well and waited Macawber-like for something to turn up, while interest rates went through the ceiling, the dollar went through the floor, inflation continued to rise, our balance of payments deficit reached crisis levels and our international debt continued to grow at an alarming rate.

By failing to introduce a mini-Budget to cut spending, by failing to ensure that there was full discounting for the price effects of the devaluation, by supporting the 3 per cent productivity rise under the accord mark 2, and by refusing to abandon the anti-business taxes, the Treasurer responded abysmally to Australia's looming economic crisis. All of these actions were pressed upon the Government month after month by the Opposition. Time and time again our entreaties were rejected. Then, unable to defy reality any longer, the Prime Minister suddenly discovered that we had a crisis after all. This was to be repentance with a real difference. Everyone else was wrong except for the Prime Minister. Having maliciously sat by and done nothing while the economy burned, the Prime Minister now seeks respectability as a latter-day apostle of budget rectitude. He must really think that the Australian disease is amnesia.

Now that our economic crisis has finally been recognised, the Government has been unable to come up with policies to overcome our deeper-seated economic problems. Australia needed a tough, responsible and, above all, believable Budget last Tuesday night. We did not get such a Budget. Australia also needed a grand plan for turning the Australian economy around. Such a plan, and the vision of how to obtain a more prosperous and productive Australia, was totally missing from the Budget. This Budget was short on hope but long on presentation. Hope, as the Government will learn, is an essential element in successfully implementing any economic or political philosophy. Sacrifice, restraint, reduced expectation and all the other rhetoric of economic recession are not, and cannot be, ends in themselves. They can be given meaning and draw support only if they are part of a strategy and philosophy which offers the hope over time of a better, more prosperous future with rising living standards.

Government in Australia has grown far too big. It must be permanently and not temporarily reduced. This will mean lower government spending and will make possible lower levels of taxation. The basic malaise facing this country is that governments-Federal, State and local-have been spending too much, taxing too much, borrowing too much and interfering too much. This trend must be dramatically reversed if Australia is to be set firmly on the path to economic recovery.

Australia's taxation system must be radically reformed and simplified. There must be a substantial reduction in the marginal rates of tax which have such a major disincentive effect. The coalition's taxation policy will reflect a number of basic principles. Firstly, the total taxation burden will fall. Taxation reform without tax- ation reduction is no reform at all. Secondly, there will be less reliance on personal tax, made possible by reduced spending and some broadening of the indirect tax base. Thirdly, our taxation policy will also positively favour families with dependent children. I believe very strongly that a taxation system which does not favour those with the responsibility of bringing up dependent children is a taxation system without a social vision. These basic principles are guiding the final determination of our new taxation charter which I will announce at an appropriate time before the next election. That policy will be simpler, less intrusive, more productive and, above all, will liberate the latent energies of Australians and encourage greater productivity and hard work.

The great economic reform needed for this country is a radical overhaul of our outdated, anti-productive and archaic industrial relations system. This change will involve a major reduction in the unreasonable power held by trade union bosses. It will also require that unions and union officials alike, like the rest of us, be made subject to the ordinary courts of this country. Australia needs a lot more Mudginberris. Our rigid, centralised wage fixation system must be changed. If we have been taught any economic lesson over the past 18 months, it is that there is a fundamental conflict between a deregulated exchange rate and a highly regulated labour market. The Government remains committed to the existing inflexible system. In view of the disturbing evidence that unemployment will rise significantly this year, the Government should attempt to initiate a 12 months wages pause under the system. This will be the best way of preventing significant rises in unemployment, especially in those industries and enterprises which will suffer most from the recession.

A major goal of our industrial relations policy is to encourage greater incentive at an enterprise level between workers and their employers. We will provide incentives to encourage profit sharing and employee share acquisition schemes. We want workers and employers to get together and agree to get rid of restrictive work practices. The great lesson of Mudginberri was that if that occurs the productivity can rise, real wages can rise and the country can benefit overall. We want an environment in which the work ethic becomes again a mark of honour, rather than a term of mock derision. If this can happen we can create an environment in which Australian workers believe that their pockets will benefit and that they will have more at stake in the prosperity of the firm that employs them than they do in the industrial success of the union to which they might belong. Then Australia once again can be a country of rising rather than falling living standards.

The time has come for Australia to abandon totally all foreign investment restrictions and to abolish the Foreign Investment Review Board. Put simply, we now need all the equity investment we can get. The enormous complex of regulations which shackles our transport and communications systems must also be dismantled. For example, for too long Australia has suffered from a union dominated coastal shipping trade which has grievously inhibited our external and internal trade. It is absolutely indefensible that in 1986 it costs less to ship goods from the Tasmanian port of Burnie to Hong Kong than it does from that same port to the port of Sydney. This deadening disincentive ought to be removed.

What is central to this six-point plan is to require a dramatically reduced role for government and a dramatically increased role for the private sector. We have committed ourselves to a spending freeze for the entirety of our first three years in government. This commitment, when achieved, will make possible the removal of the deficit, reductions in our overseas debt and some reductions in the total taxation burden. Over the last few weeks the coalition has reassessed all its existing commitments in light of the economic crisis facing Australia and the urgent need to cut back on government spending and taxation. Whilst it is not possible to provide in its entirety an alternative Budget, I now intend to provide some of the details of our changed approach.

As a result of this review, the Opposition remains, on the spending side, committed only to the abolition of the iniquitous assets test. That remains the only current expenditure commitment on our return to government. On the tax side, we remain committed to the scrapping of the Hawke capital gains tax, the throwing out of the Hawke Government's fringe benefits tax and the repeal of the Hawke Government's tax on lump sum superannuation. All of these taxes hit hardest at the productive element of the Australian economy and are excessively harsh on small businesses, the self-employed and the battling Australian farmer. Also, if there is any life left in the concept of a Bill of Rights when we are elected to office, that will also be abolished.

The next Liberal-National Party Government will operate far fewer government departments than currently exist. As policy statements are made there will be no commitments to the maintenance of existing departments so as to enable greater flexibility when assuming office. Many statutory authorities and bodies will be abolished. These will include the Human Rights Commission, the Constitutional Commission, the Commission for the Future, the Prices Surveillance Authority, the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission, the Economic Planning Advisory Council, the Advisory Council on Prices and Incomes and the Foreign Investment Review Board.

Major savings can be made if we overhaul the Medicare system. We will put choice back into Medicare by a number of steps. Firstly, we will allow individual Australians to opt out of Medicare; that is, not pay the levy provided they take out private insurance. Secondly, bulk billing will be abolished except for such people as pensioners who really need it.
