Finally, the health insurance market will be freed up by allowing it to operate in a variety of ways to offer a variety of packages to health consumers. A coalition government will substantially reduce the ever-burgeoning cost of Medicare and improve private health insurance choice in the process.

A Liberal-National Party government will attack welfare fraud by enshrining the principle that the unemployed should be required to work in return for receiving unemployment benefit. The Prime Minister has gone to water on this issue in the Budget. Welfare fraud is imposing considerable burdens on Australian taxpayers. Its elimination will be a top priority for the next coalition Government. We will also remove existing abuses of the sole parent benefit by ensuring that parents are compelled to accept some financial responsibility for the upkeep of their children. As well, we will amend that absurd provision of the Family Law Act so that available welfare benefits are not taken into account by the Family Court when deciding whether or not a maintenance order will be made.

These measures-more will be announced before the next election-are in no sense symbolic gestures. They represent a major attack on government over-regulation, duplication and waste. Our attack on government spending will not end there but will be expanded as we move over the next 18 months. Australia simply cannot afford more and more spending. Additional spending can lead only to higher taxes and more national debt. At the moment, we have too much of both. The clear message that I have received as I have moved around the cities and the provincial areas of Australia is overwhelmingly that, for too long, governments have been taxing too much, spending too much, borrowing too much and interfering too much. It will be a major goal of the next coalition Government to put an end to that fundamental malaise of the Australian economy.

As I said at the commencement of my remarks, the key flaw of this Budget is that it is a big-taxing but a small-axing Budget. That is precisely the wrong remedy for Australia's economic ills. As well, the Government has failed once again to come to grips with the problems for the Australian economy caused by our rigid, inflexible, centralised wage fixation system. After all the huffing and puffing, all the crisis talk about a banana republic and all the wartime analogies, almost nothing has been done permanently to reduce the level of government spending in this Budget. In fact, outlays have increased in this Budget by 6.9 per cent in money terms and by a very slight amount in real terms.

Two of the seven Budgets of the previous coalition Government achieved a better result on expenditure restraint, with falls in real outlays in 1976 and 1979. Yet there was no suggestion then that Australia was in the midst of an unparalleled economic crisis. In fact, last Tuesday, Mr Keating delivered the fourth largest-spending Budget in Australia's history-surpassed only by his drunken sailor approach to spending exhibited in his first three Budgets. The Government has achieved this much-vaunted deficit of $3.5 billion by lifting taxes, by dubious accounting methods and by heroic forecasts for economic growth, the strength of the world economy and unemployment levels. It is no wonder that it has so far received a resounding thumbs down from the Australian financial market.

The bringing forward of company tax instalments and provisional tax payments from 1987-88 into 1986-87 have also worked to lower this year's deficit in a one-off fashion. Many of the cuts in outlays have resulted from delays and postponements in expenditure. They are therefore, largely one-off cuts and do not seriously tackle the fundamental problem of the excessive size of government. This is clearly revealed on page 71 of Budget Paper No. 1, which shows that the full-year ongoing expenditure savings are considerably less than the anticipated savings in 1986-87. Of the $2 billion taken from the forward estimates, no less than $1.1 billion is accounted for by deferrals, changes in timing or so-called improved efficiencies. In other words, the only real reduction from the forward estimates amounts to from $800m to $900m.

At the beginning of this expenditure restraint exercise, the Government said that it would cut $1.4 billion from the forward estimates. That was when we were still doing brilliantly. That was before the banana republic. That was before the great prime ministerial repentance. After all the huffing and puffing and all those weeks during which the Prime Minister never tired of telling us that he was tied up with the Budget and could not get out to meet the people-anyone would think that no one had ever been tied up on a Budget process before-all that the Government brought forth was another $500m off the forward estimates. That is the measure of what happens when the Prime Minister gets bailed up working on the Budget over a period of two to three months.

The Reserve Bank's profits-this is a very interesting figure-have primarily resulted from its sales of foreign exchange at the heavily devalued exchange rate of the Australian dollar. In other words, it is very important that the Treasurer understands this, the additional amount of revenue would not have been obtained had not the dollar been devalued so sharply over the last year. Consequently, the alleged Budget deficit of $3.5 billion would have been significantly higher. Clearly it will not be possible to assume that this source of revenue in such large amounts will be available in the future.

The Budget projections on unemployment beneficiaries, medicare and debt repayments also look far too optimistic. In other words, the Budget deficit figure looks very shaky indeed. But this is not all. The Budget forecast of GDP growth of 2.25 per cent for this year is overly optimistic, requiring as it does June-on-June growth of over 5 per cent. Most of the economic growth is expected to come from net exports of 1.75 per cent. However, it is clear that this will result more from driving the economy into recession and reducing imports than by the J-curve working.

The Australian economy has now experienced three successive quarters of negative economic growth. We are technically in recession. Yet the Government expects the world to believe that our economy will grow by over 2 per cent this financial year. The assumption of continued economic growth overseas also seems very optimistic. To the extent that world growth is lower, particularly in the United States and Japan, the demand for Australia's exports and hence our economic growth rate will be lower.

Unemployment is forecast by the Treasurer to rise only moderately. This is totally unrealistic given the expected low level of domestic demand growth. Unemployment is likely to rise well above the current level of 8.3 per cent. Business fixed investment, already relatively weak in the recovery period, is forecast to fall in 1986-87. This will undermine any export growth and import replacement coming from any operation of the J-curve. Despite the fall in imports associated with the recession, the current account deficit is forecast to be worse than this year's $13.7 billion record and around the same as a percentage of GDP-namely, $14.6 billion.

Overall, on current policy, the recession is likely to continue for longer than anticipated by the Government, unemployment will rise considerably and the Budget deficit will blow out above the estimated figure of $3.5 billion.

The Government's economic strategy involves the tightening of fiscal and wages policies in such a manner as to allow an easing of monetary policy-that is, a lowering of interest rates-without a further fall in the value of the Australian dollar. However, with the continued large external imbalance and the forecast high inflation rate, the Australian dollar still remains vulnerable to periods of chronic weakness which will limit any substantive fall in interest rates during the year ahead. The reliance on sustained lower interest rates is a very high risk strategy indeed. Overall, the Government has not done enough and it has waited too long before acting. The 2 per cent discount figure is nowhere near enough, particularly in view of the worsening unemployment situation, and applies only to the next national wage case.

The Treasurer failed to deliver the promise he made in last year's Budget that there would be full discounting for the price effects of the devaluation. The Treasurer's stance on wages once again has been distinctly wimpish. Under the existing industrial relations system, Australia needs a 12-month wages pause. Yet the Treasurer in his Budget Speech complacently predicted that wages will increase by over 6 per cent this year.

Budget Paper No. 2 admits that wages in Australia in 1986 will increase at a faster rate than that of our eight major trading partners. And yet we are told that we are in a wartime situation when extreme measures are required. Well, they were not contained in the Budget. Wages policy involves a 2 per cent discount from the expected 4 per cent wage claim due at the next national wage case. This of itself is an inadequate response to the continued impact of the depreciation on the consumer price index and the deterioration in our terms of trade. The last wage case did not incorporate adequate discounting and neither will the next one.

With our inflation rate still far too high and substantial depreciation effects still to flow through, no wage increase can be justified if we are to minimise the impact of the current recession on unemployment. There is no clear commitment to wage discounting beyond the next national wage case. If discounting is not undertaken, the inflation outcomes expected in the September and December quarters this year will lead to a 4 to 5 per cent wage increase at the 1987 April national wage case. In the current economic climate, such an across the board wage increase would drive thousands of Australians on to the dole queues.

The Budget makes it abundantly clear that Australia desperately needs more investment. But in fact the Government has actually discouraged investment by mugging business with new anti-investment taxes such as the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax. The Treasurer is constantly running around saying that the corporate profit share figures are running high at the moment. That may be so in the First French Empire clock business but, as any businessman will tell us, it is the after-tax real rate of return that is the relevant indicator in investment decisions. Australia's real rate of return on investment, which is calculated after interest rates and taxation are taken into account, is far too low.

At a time when the United States of America is reducing its corporate tax rate to 34 per cent, Britain has a 35 per cent rate, Singapore has announced a reduction to 33 per cent and there is a general international trend towards lower corporate tax rates, the Treasurer has increased Australia's corporate tax rate to 49 per cent with effect from 1 July this year. This will further decrease the rate of return to Australian businesses. It will dampen the desire of overseas companies making direct equity investment into Australia. Not only did the Treasurer slug business with massive new taxes last year, but he is also now changing long established practices to bring forward the payment of $220m in taxes by certain companies.

At a time when the Treasurer wants companies to invest, he is making business pay $220m in tax earlier than it normally would have done. This is hardly the way to encourage business in the current depressed economic climate. It once again underlines the Government's obsession with tax collection as the solution to its economic problems. The basic problem with this Government, as illustrated by that and many other decisions, is that it does not understand that unless the rate of return is sufficient business will not start new projects. Risks will not be taken unless adequate returns are made and new jobs will not be created unless investors have the incentive to take risks.

The Hawke Government has wasted three years of economic opportunity. It came to office at the end of the world recession and the worst drought in Australia's modern history. As well, it benefited enormously from the former Government's wages pause which the Prime Minister not only opposed but also did his level best to destroy. Yet three and a half years later Australia's economic plight is the worst it has been for 50 years-and that is not my claim but the Prime Minister's own admission.

The coalition believes that there is a way to restore Australia's position and to restore the living standards of all our citizens, but this can happen only if there are substantial changes to existing institutions and attitudes in the Australian community. That is the hope that all of us have as Australians. We can offer hope through a greater commitment to individual freedom, through a greater commitment to greater individual choice and through a greater commitment to greater individual incentive.

The Hawke Government is essentially backward looking. It wants to make the system of the past work better, but it has failed to realise that many elements of that old system have totally failed. We need a new economic system in Australia, and one which places much greater stress on initiative, productivity and incentive. Only a coalition government can provide this new economic system. Only a coalition government can bring about a long term restoration in Australian prosperity and living standards.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Staples Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can see that the speech from the world's worst Opposition leader, formerly the world's worst Treasurer, has sent his colleagues running from the chamber in total despair and that the legs of those remaining have gone to jelly. Those who are sitting here cannot move. They are either riveted to or lost in their seats. I do not know why they cannot move; perhaps we need some first aid assistance for these people.

SPEECH.PARA: I am concerned for the Opposition, but I am also concerned for the people of Australia. What the people of Australia have heard tonight and what we have witnessed in this chamber is a demonstration of the fact that there are no alternative policies coming from this Opposition. It has failed again-in the fourth Budget in a row-as it failed in the Budgets it brought down in the past. It has failed totally. The world's worst Leader of the Opposition has failed to recognise his own failure as Treasurer in the way he left this country. He did not even have the simple grace to show the people of Australia what this Government has achieved. He did not talk about the growth or the jobs that this Government has achieved in only 41 months. That is what the people of Australia are stuck with; that is what they are left with. Any Government could be returned to office with an Opposition such as that. Tonight, as in the days and months before and I am sure in the months and years ahead, members of the Opposition will continue to confound the people of Australia with their ineptitude.

The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) has failed, along with all his supporters, to indicate in any real, specific way, in figures-dollars and cents-what the Opposition would do. He said that he would give presents to everyone, that he would hand out presents to the pensioners, the farmers and everyone else. But when would he send them the bill? What would the bill be? Would it be another $9.6 billion? Is that what we would face if those opposite ever got back into power? The people of Australia will judge the Leader of the Opposition and members of the Opposition-they will be in opposition for a long time-on their past performance and on what has been offered here tonight, if one can call that an offering worth looking at.

On Tuesday this Hawke Government brought down its fourth Budget. Effectively, this is only the sixth Labor Budget in 37 years. This is particularly relevant because it draws Australia's current economic and industrial circumstances into a more vivid and realistic perspective than is being understood by the vast majority of Australians today. As we all know, Australia does face very severe economic and industrial structural problems. Only the most churlish fool, the most churlish idiot, would suggest that they are the fault entirely of this Government. It does not take much to realise what has been going on. But Opposition members persist in degrading the integrity and the intelligence of the Australian public with their churlish assertions.

It is no secret that we have a balance of payments problem. Before we as a nation can realistically and rationally address this, we have to look at our economic and political history to understand the correct path that we have to take in the future. History shows quite conclusively that we have been sold down the river by the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia. We have been sold off at bargain basement rates, sold into economic slavery by Opposition members such as the honourable member for Bennelong who was the Treasurer in the previous Government. The country was sold off by John McEwen and his protectionist policies. When an industry was going bad, he subsidised it. The attitude was: `To hell with the future; we will subsidise it'.

We are now paying the price of that. Farmers, exporters, manufacturers, every person in Australia is paying the price, but particularly the poor people. That was the answer of the Liberal and National parties which brought down at least 31 of the last 37 Budgets. Their answer year after year, decade after decade, was to avoid the hard decisions and to offer to people the easy ones. I hope that the people of Australia have woken up to that easy sell, to the stuff that we have been handed here tonight. It was a ridiculous and absurd insult to the intelligence and the integrity of all Australians.

Today all of us, but especially those three million people and those 800,000 children in poverty, are paying the price for that betrayal of this country, the incompetence of the people opposite when they were in government and what they pretend they will do when they get back into government. Let us face the fact that people get the government that they deserve. Over the years the people of Australia have voted for those economic men of clay. So, as Australians we must now collectively take the blame for the incompetence with which we allowed them to govern over the four decades since World War II. But it has been the poor people, now numbering three million and including 800,000 children, who have paid the greatest price of all. They have never been fooled by the Liberal and National parties. For generations they have seen from the faces of their hungry children the effects that the Liberal and National parties and their successive Budgets have had upon them. It is those people who have always turned to the Australian Labor Party for help. It is the poor and the powerless people of this country who have always stood by the ALP when it needed support and when it deserved it. I hope that the Government of this country will recognise that and think of those poor people when it looks at the finance marketeers, at the money market operators and at the dollar.

The dollar is worth 61c on the international money exchanges. It is with 61c that a poor supporting mother or father has to feed her or his children every meal. Could anyone here feed his kids on 61c a meal? Honourable members should try to feed themselves on 61c a meal. All of the 12 million people in Australia who live on much more than 61c a meal should try to feed themselves, look after themselves and keep healthy on 61c a meal. That is what poor people are expected to do. I can understand their anger and confusion now. There are people in my electorate who wonder what is going on, with all of the confusing things that are being thrown up at them.

The middle income earners are the people who change governments in this country. We have seen governments come and go and members of parliament in this place come and go. But on average the middle income earners have failed to recognise the plight of the poor. They have failed to realise that they, with their middle income taxes, and the escalating tax rates and inflated incomes of the Howard-Fraser years in particular, have paid the price of poverty in this country, as well as the poor people. They have paid for the social security, health and everything else that goes with the cost of poverty.

What have the wealthy been doing? They have been welshing on the people of this country. They have been welshing on the poor and on the middle income earners. For generations they have avoided taxes and avoided their responsibility to this country. It is the nature of poverty to be powerless in society. This powerlessness has encouraged the wealthy to blame the poor for this country's problems. We have seen it here again tonight. It is fashionable and easy to criticise supporting mothers and dole bludgers rather than the wealthy tax evaders. Whatever happened to Australians' care for the underdog? It is a myth to make us feel good when we denigrate and attack the powerless.

I am afraid that this Budget has been framed to appeal not to voters but to the international money markets. Those who are influenced by the yo-yoing of the dollar are so easily fooled. When we listen to radio reports we hear on one hand the weather report and on the other hand the price of the dollar. But it is irrelevant to what is happening in this country today. The sooner we wake up to it, the better we will be and the better off the country will be. We are being manipulated by the international financiers around the world and the people sitting in their leather-lined boardrooms in this country. We are being manipulated by undemocratic corporate and international financial forces which have no allegiance to this country, its well-being or the well-being of its 15 million people.

In this Budget Government spending has been cut. The poor will have to wait longer for any benefits. We have had drastic Government cuts in vital social areas in an attempt to create an environment for the much vaunted private sector to drive this country forward. That is what the money markets, private enterprise and the media have all been calling for. I hope that they are now writing that into their reports on the Leader of the Opposition.

The media, the money markets and those in private enterprise have everything they need, but they want more. They have everything they need, but they want more blood, they want more from the 800,000 children. They want to take the food out of the mouths of the 800,000 Australian children because they want more. But the obligation is now on them. They have everything they need, but the obligation is now fairly and squarely on their shoulders. No longer can the public sector and the poor people in this country pay the price for that incompetence. The poor, the low paid workers and anyone but those in the money market, in private enterprise and in the media are being asked to pay. The poor are being asked to have their pensions and wages cut. But those in the money market, in private enterprise and in the media do not look at themselves in the mirror and see what they are doing. If this situation continues, this country will go further into ruin and into economic and social decay. This attack on the poor has happened in the past and will happen in the future just as it is happening in the present.

Australia's private enterprise is basically lazy and incompetent, just as the Opposition is lazy and incompetent. Those people in private enterprise and those with money in this country are selling us into economic slavery. Let us look at some examples of this incompetence. The Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, the `Big Australian', made $1,000m profit last year. At a time when the country has current account deficit and balance of payment problems, BHP is reported to be agonising over spending $100m on expansion of its Port Kembla steelworks to increase its export potential. It is agonising over that decision. There are people tonight who are agonising because they do not have shelter. If it were a government that was agonising, it would be hauled up in the newspapers. But, no, the BHP decision merited only a little piece in the Australian Financial Review. The company, the `Big Australian', the epitome of private enterprise, is incompetent and is allowed to get away with it.

I have another example of incompetence in the private sector with financiers. A business in my electorate has 99 per cent of the Australian market with a very sophisticated high technology product. It is a state of the art product and the business is a world leader in this area. That business could not get $10m from the big financiers of this country to set up operations in China, whose market for the product is 100 times larger than the market in Australia. The Chinese Government provided it, and we lost. Where are the big foreign and private enterprise risk takers in the Australian financial system? They are lost; they are hopeless. Let us look at some of the things that we do well in regard to design. The best Australian design that has come out of this country for ages is the boomerang. That is probably our most original design. We have creative young people; we have creative talent. We have tremendous designers. But, instead, we play around with silly little things and unoriginal designs. It is no wonder the world will not buy our products.

I have just been to Japan. The Japanese have signs in their shops stating: `We like imported goods'. They want to buy our goods, When representatives of our big companies go to Japan, they are told: `This is what we sell in this country and this is the way we sell it. Why won't you send your goods over here?'. Private enterprise in this country is not interested in changing. It is not interested in growing. It wants to sit back and be protected by the taxpayer and the poor people in this country.

The AMP Society and other big assurance companies are involved with superannuation. An amount of $7,000m of superannuation funds-workers' money-has gone out of this country in the last year or so and has been invested in the economies of other countries. Does that not ring a bell with anyone here? It is a double loss. What could we do if $7,000m were invested in Australia? If nothing else, where is the patriotism of these companies that send Australian workers' money to the tune of $7,000m a year out of this country to be invested in other people's economies? This puts more Australians out of work. Why is this story not portrayed on the front pages of newspapers? Why do we not hear that story every hour in news reports, instead of hearing about the minor fluctuations in the value of the dollar? That is causing a double loss and it is a criminal waste of this country's resources. This money is supporting the economies of our direct competitors, and we have to pay interest on the foreign capital that we bring into this country. The corporate bludgers-not the dole bludgers, not the supporting mothers, but the corporate bludgers-and private enterprise are destroying this country.

I turn to the subject of competitiveness. We hear so much about Australian wage costs. The Opposition's solution to all the problems is to cut wages and pensions. It is ridiculous. We are competitive in our wage costs. We do have some higher on-costs than many other countries. Much of that is due to our distance from markets both internally and externally, our small population and our economies of scale. The fact is that 70 per cent of our imports-the things that we bring in, sell and use in this country-come from countries that have higher wage cost structures than Australia. Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table that clearly shows that that is so.
