TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. Let us face it: If long working hours and low pay were the key to economic success, Bangladesh would be an economic super-power. But it is not. If low pay and long working hours were the key to economic success, Sweden would be a banana republic. But it is not. There is something fundamentally wrong in the logic of honourable members opposite, the logic of the media and the logic of those who control the value of our dollar. A few years ago when this country revalued its currency, the cry went out: `You have to cut wage costs so that you will be competitive with the rest of the world'. Today our dollar has been devalued to a point which is probably lower than it has ever been. Our currency could not be more competitive. What is the cry? We must cut wage costs. Does something not click in the minds of people that this is totally inconsistent?

SPEECH.PARA: The call of the Business Council of Australia, the Liberal and National parties, the Leader of the Opposition here tonight, and the finance markets is a hollow facade of deceit and a vicious assault on the poor of this country. If people in this country have any national pride, if this country means more to them than a bit of red, white and blue coloured cloth-I think that is all it means to many people-if they have any belief in that great Australian idea of mateship, they would not attack the poor. We should protect the poor, but we do not. We should thumb our noses at the finance markets and the people who have pushed this country around, but we do not. We suck up to them and we enslave ourselves to them day after day. Mr Lightfoot, a member of the Liberal Party in Western Australia has written an ignominious letter to the United States Administration. As was the case with Pig Iron Bob, this letter will go down in Australian history. What elected representative of the people of Australia would say to the United States Secretary of State, Mr Shultz: `You keep up your policies of destroying our economy because we will be re-elected if you do'. That is what it is all about.

Two million to three million people in this country live in poverty. Tonight, 800,000 children will go to bed in poverty, many of them without food. Many will go to school tomorrow without food. The Leader of the Opposition talks about choice and hope. He has offered these people, and the rest of us in the long run, no choice and no hope. That is the political reality-no choice and no hope. Tonight we are faced with the fact that two million to three million Australians, including 800,000 children, are living in poverty. If the Opposition is re-elected, the rest of the country will face that prospect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aldred Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset one must express some admiration for the tenacity and vigorousness with which the honourable member for Jagajaga (Mr Staples) delivered his speech on the Budget tonight. But one cannot express the same degree of admiration for his common sense and judgment about the real facts of the world. He made a number of allusions to minor adjustments to the dollar and related to that all sorts of internal problems in this country. What he has failed to understand properly is, of course, that the valuation given to the dollar at any particular time is the measure of international credibility of the economy of the country in question. Over a long period, if one traces the valuation of various currencies, one can see mirrored the strength of the economy concerned. From the remarks of the honourable member for Jagajaga tonight, one could have been forgiven for thinking that he was a member of an opposition talking about another government. I remind him that, of course, he is a member of the current Government and that our current difficulties have been brought about by that Government. If the dollar deteriorates substantially over a period, this Government must bear the complete responsibility for what has happened.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to look at what has happened to the Australian dollar since this Government was elected to office. To give the Government due credit, during 1983 and 1984 the dollar did hold its value reasonably well. Of course, we know that the reason was that the Government was able to inherit the good fortune of the benefits of the wages pause that we had put in place prior to our going out of government. It had the benefit of the breaking of the drought very early in its period of office and that set off, of course, a mini-rural boom which left it in a very good position for a short period. Of course, as the reality of its policies set in and it could no longer live off the previous Government savings account and policies and it had to start to write out its own cheques, the reality of what it was really doing to the Australian dollar started to sink in.

If one looks at what has happened to the dollar since the Hawke Government was elected, one finds some very disturbing figures-not the minor adjustments to the dollar of which the honourable member for Jagajaga spoke. If one looks at the value of the Australian dollar set against the United States dollar, the Japanese yen and the trade-weighted index since the Hawke Government was first elected on 5 March 1983, one sees some very disturbing figures. Set against the United States dollar, the Australian dollar has fallen from that time until now by 36 per cent; set against the Japanese yen, the Australian dollar has fallen by 58 per cent, and, on the trade-weighted index, it has fallen by 38 per cent. It is particularly interesting to note that the bulk of that fall has been concentrated in the period since the last Federal election, that is, since 5 December 1984.

If one looks again at those measurements one sees that in that 20-month period since the last Federal election the Australian dollar has fallen by 29 per cent against the United States dollar, 55 per cent against the Japanese yen, and 39 per cent against the trade-weighted index. The bulk of the fall has been concentrated in the last 20 months since the last Federal election. That is the period in which the Government's policies have started to impact most heavily on the Australian economy, because in the first 18 months of government the Labor Government was able to live off our policies, off our wages freeze and off other of our policies. That carried the Labor Government through the first 18 months.

Now the reality has started to set in. The figures I have given show quite clearly that one cannot dismiss the movements in the dollar as being minor or inconsequential. They are quite major and a measurement of the way in which national governments, international financial institutions, banks overseas and the world at large measure the worth and credibility of the Australian economy. It is interesting to note also in that regard that even in the short period since the Budget was brought down the dollar, after an initial surge, went down again and as at yesterday had reached 60c against the United States dollar.

Over the past year and a half the Government has attempted to explain all this away by saying that this was all pre-ordained, all part of a general economic strategy, and that great benefits are being derived for the Australian economy, particularly our export sector, from the fact that the dollar has fallen so dramatically. That is not necessarily the case. If one turns to a report by the Economic Planning Advisory Council put down in January of this year and its judgment on various sectors of the economy and the extent to which they were affected adversely or positively by depreciation of the dollar, one comes up with some very disturbing conclusions. I quote from an article in the Australian Financial Review on 3 February this year commenting on the EPAC report in some detail as it related to particular sectors of industry. The article was entitled `EPAC doubts depreciation gains' and was written by Richard Hubbard. It begins:

The Federal Government's Economic Planning Advisory Council has cast doubts on the predictions by ministers of an economic windfall accruing from the depreciation of the dollar by being unable to identify many areas of significant net benefits.
The exception is probably tourism.

In a report, entitled `A Note on the Sectoral Effects of the Depreciation' released yesterday, EPAC reviewed the outlook for four major sectors of the economy-agriculture, minerals and energy, manufacturing, and services-but found each had its own constraints.
The article continues:

For the agricultural and the mining sectors, it said the major benefits which could be expected from a depreciation, including increased Australian dollar returns for the same level of exports, could be largely offset by falling world commodity prices.

While in the critical area of manufacturing, increased input costs from the use of overseas components in production, combined with general cost increases, were expected to diminish the overall benefit to the sector.

In the services sector, a considerable boost was expected for the tourist industry but any major stimulus would depend on the other sectors increasing their competitiveness on domestic and export markets.
In line with the general economic theory of a depreciation, the report noted that there were many potential long term benefits for each of these sectors if the fall in the dollar was sustained.
But the prospects for the so called J-curve effect which was expected to turn around the poor balance of payments position remained, in the words of EPAC, `mixed'.

That is a fair judgment because, in the ultimate, a falling dollar does not mean increased export opportunities. A falling dollar means that the credibility of the economy in the judgment of the world at large is declining.

I turn now from some of those macroeconomic considerations to the specific effects of a falling dollar on particular industries and to a few case studies relating to individual firms. I want to give the House some idea of the dramatic effects of the falling dollar on industry planning, on budgets, on marketing strategy and on the attempts of small to medium business in particular simply to stay in the black and to survive in these difficult times. Let us look at one particular industry, and I quote again from the Australian Financial Review of Thursday, 24 July 1986, just under a month ago. The report is entitled `Forwarder's computer system wards off the dollar woes' and deals later with the effect of computers on the freight forwarding industry before it leads in on the dollar. The article is written by Kay Barney and the introduction reads:

The freight forwarding industry has fallen victim to the Australian dollar's depreciation which has reduced import volumes with a consequent cut into margins as the market competes for the reduced business.
The managing director of freight forwarder and customs clearance agency, WTC Stephenson, Mr Paul Stephenson, said that, overall volume in the industry had fallen about 20 per cent.
The depreciation had not boosted exports sufficiently to offset the decrease in imports, Mr Stephenson said.
So much for the J-curve. The article continued:
This was forcing forwarders to attempt to increase market share to maintain volumes in a diminishing market.
So much for the benefits of the falling Australian dollar to individual industries.

In the time available I turn to a few individual case studies which give some indication of the effect of the falling dollar on particular individual enterprises. I draw attention to figures provided to me by a local firm not far from my electorate office, a firm engaged in the business of importing garden tools and other basic household tools from Hong Kong and other places. Because of the falling dollar in recent months, the firm has been forced from having been in the black to a substantial loss situation and its future is now very much in doubt. That is why I shall not mention the company's name, but I have the documentation with me. The firm has allowed me to use the figures which clearly indicate the effect of the falling dollar on that enterprise.

The firm has taken a basic tool which can be found in any garden shed or household workshop and indicated precisely the effect of the falling dollar on the cost of that tool over a period. When the dollar was rated at 70c against the United States dollar, the firm was able to put this garden tool on the shelf at $46.20; when the dollar went to 65c against the United States dollar, the firm then had to up the price to $58.61. As the dollar came down to 63c, it was forced to move the retail price to $60.29. Finally when the Australian dollar reached the 60c mark against the United States dollar, the firm would be looking at a retail price of $63.39. This has put the firm into the red, and it may go out of business. The item to which I refer is not easily manufactured in Australia. That is just one indication of what has happened to one firm. It is not a particularly large firm, indeed it is a fairly small one. It is a local firm which up to now has had a good record. It has now been thrown into complete disarray and its future is very much in doubt because of the impact of the dollar.

Let me take another firm, and the gentleman concerned has allowed me to use his name. He is a constituent, Mr Gordon Griffiths, a local businessman who imports cosmetics and toiletries from New Zealand. The goods that he imports to and markets in Australia include skin care preparations, face powders, lipsticks, nail enamels, colognes and deodorants. These goods are manufactured entirely in New Zealand-the particular line that he wants to market here cannot be obtained within Australia, therefore he must bring them across the Tasman to sell them here. Under the closer economics relations he is not subject to import duty so his problems have been created by the falling dollar alone. Back in June 1985 when one Australian dollar bought 1.385 New Zealand dollars he would have to pay $7,200 to meet a bill of $10,000 worth of New Zealand cosmetics. That was just over a year ago. Since then the Australian dollar has fallen markedly against the New Zealand dollar and by June 1986 one Australian dollar bought 1.23 New Zealand dollars. The effect of that is that when he buys $10,000 of New Zealand cosmetics now he has to pay out $8,130. That is a significant increase of $930 for the same quantity of goods. That has thrown all his budgeting and planning for the immediate future into disarray. He does not quite know where to go with his marketing strategy and he must think very carefully about the sorts of things he will do in the future. At this point he has not yet been pushed into the parlous situation of the importer of garden tools whom I mentioned previously, but certainly he has been put in a very difficult situation, brought about by the falling Australian dollar.

I also wish to draw attention to another case study from a small business in my electorate. In this case the information was provided by a Mr Peter Harkness who runs a small electronic firm. This constituent of mine is engaged in the business of selling video and audio cassettes and other related equipment. He brings video tapes from Japan in pancakes for use particularly in television studios and one of the key components that he uses in the assembly of these products is a device which is called a DL control print motor. That equipment is used to assemble and cut video tapes to the required size and type. This particular commodity, which is quite critical to his operation, cost him $150 in August 1985. He will now have to purchase another identical unit from Japan and in 12 months the price has risen to $350-a rise of 133 per cent. Of course there is an inflation factor in that as well as the depreciation.

I use these case studies to illustrate the very telling point that the fundamental difficulties that have been created for Australian industry by the falling dollar go very much to the survival of various types of industry in a number of different facets. During the period this Government has been in office the fall in the dollar has not brought about the great benefits that it was supposed to bring. One must be very aware of this. Not only does the falling dollar indicate a collapse in credibility of our economy but also for all forms of business-small, medium and large-it is playing havoc with their budgeting, planning, marketing strategy and everything else. Of course recently their woes and troubles have been added to by this Government's idiotic fringe benefits tax which I have talked about at length on other occasions.

In conclusion I wish to draw to the Government's attention the fact that when it talks about the falling dollar it should not talk about it in terms of its being some mythical benefit to Australian industry. It is not. In fact it is another factor that is destroying industry in this country, creating havoc and making it very difficult to survive. I would hope that in future discussions in this chamber about the falling dollar some element of common sense prevails in the argument that the Government puts forward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleeland Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Regrettably we have not heard much common sense from the honourable member for Bruce (Mr Aldred) who has just finished speaking. We have just heard the old hoary argument that somehow we should have a fixed exchange rate. If we had a fixed exchange rate in Australia today, what would be our position? The Government would be spending 24 hours a day trying to determine the rate of the dollar. Surely such arguments have gone out once and for all in this country. But no, dinosaurs from the Opposition still exist. They pop up and come back with these strange notions of economic principles which have long been thrown out in most other countries. I would have thought by now that most Australians-except members of the Opposition-would have realised that there is a fundamental crisis in the Australian economy and that is caused by our terms of trade. The price we get for our commodities is much less than the price we are paying for our imports. Pretty obviously if one increases the value of the dollar one will decrease the price of imports, hence one sucks in further imports. If the view of the honourable member for Bruce is the position of the other members of the Opposition, what they are saying is this: We should increase the value of the dollar the way the Opposition did when it was in government-that is our problem and the Opposition caused it-to the stage where imports are cheaper than locally produced products. Thus we suck in imports all over the place, reduce our own manufacturing capacity and cause the disaster that we now face. Do Opposition members never learn anything? It is pretty obvious that they do not.

SPEECH.PARA: I had a nicely prepared speech tonight, but when I heard the failed former Treasurer, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), speak I threw that speech away and decided that it was time to expose very quickly some of the strange and fallacious statements that he made tonight. One of the statements he made which really encouraged me to throw away that speech was that the Opposition would scrap the capital gains tax, throw out the fringe benefits tax and throw out the Prices Surveillance Authority. Let us take the last of those three items first-the Prices Surveillance Authority. The capacity to purchase of Australian wage earners during the last two years has been drastically reduced. This year earnings rose by about 7.1 per cent while costs went up more than 9 per cent. We all know that the capacity of Australian consumers to purchase is diminishing severely. I might add that we should be very thankful that the average Australian wage earner is acting so responsibility in accepting the wage cuts. The Opposition does not appreciate that. It does not want to give the workers any wage increases. It wants a wage freeze for three years.

Every wage earner in Australia should shudder at the thought of no wage increases when the Opposition, at the same time, would throw out the Prices Surveillance Authority. Honourable members should just think about that. What a lot of nonsense! The Opposition is asking wage earners not to take a wage increase for three years, yet it wants to throw out the Prices Surveillance Authority. The Opposition is saying to industry: `You can increase your prices any way you like-this way or that way. We will not worry about prices, we are on about big profits'. Yet the Australian wage earner will carry not just the discounting of wages but the effect of no wage increases at all. What a lot of economic drivel. The Leader of the Opposition talks about his concern for families. I wonder which families he is concerned about-the ones who are making the profits or the wage earners whom he wants to destroy. They are Australian families and I think the Opposition should be condemned. The whole of Australia should be horrified by this concept.

Let us have a look at the fringe benefits tax. The Opposition has made a great deal of political capital out of this in the last few months. It has had a ball; it has distorted the truth and it has basically distorted what the tax is all about. Let us get a few facts on this matter. Since 1915 there has been a section in the Income Tax Assessment Act known among those involved in taxation as section 26 (e). It is known as section 26 (e) because there is also a section 26e. Section 26 (e) is very simple. It has always said that all benefits paid to employees are taxable. That has been in the Act since 1915. Honourable members might well ask why benefits which have been paid so often in this country have not been taxed. The Opposition cannot tell me that these benefits have been taxed because everyone in Australia knows, and no one denies it, that benefits paid to employees have not been caught by tax. Why not? What did honourable members opposite, when they were in government in the seven years prior to this Government coming into office, do to make sure that that section was enforced? What did this miserable Opposition do, in the 30-odd post-war years in which it was in government, to make sure that that tax law was enforced? The answer is zero. You did not do a damn thing about it because you did not care. It was part of the tax rorts when you were in government, when the whole taxation system of this country was destroyed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for McEwen is obliged to address the Chair. I trust that he is not charging the Chair--

—My apologies, Mr Deputy Speaker. One gets a bit enthused when such disasters have occurred in our history and honourable members opposite are still making the same mistakes. Let us get back to section 26 (e). As I will explain, fringe benefits have always been taxable but the tax has never been collected. The old system operated as follows: If a benefit was paid to an employee the employer was obliged by the then current tax law to value the benefit to each employee receiving the same. Payee tax was then required to be deducted from the value of the benefit. It was not the employee who had to deduct it; it was the employer. Was it done? Did it ever happen? Of course it did not. It was never deducted and never paid, so the system did not work. It was a disaster. It is impossible to make the existing section 26 (e) work.

SPEECH.PARA: How do we tackle this problem? How do we change a system which has proved to be false, which does not work, and on which we could not collect tax at a time when the amount being paid in benefits in Australia was increasing at an alarming rate and the amount of revenue being received by the Commonwealth was diminishing. The answer is simple: If the employer will not comply with the existing tax law we change the law to ensure that the employer pays the tax. That is exactly what the fringe benefits tax does. But the people on the other side of the House do not seem to understand that. Of course, when it comes to tax matters they do not have a brain among them. If we listen to what they say in this House about income tax and tax-related matters we realise right away that they have had no professional practice in this area. They do not know about section 26 (e); they have never made it work.

That is the fundamental truth about section 26 (e) and the fringe benefits tax. But honourable members opposite are going to abolish it. They are going to legitimise certain people in this country having their wives paid a hostess allowance. That is right; a hostess allowance which can range from $5,000 to $10,000. The excuse for paying a wife a hostess allowance is that the wife may be required to assist the husband on some company matter. She might require her hair to be styled, she might require particular clothing or she might want a new imported pair of shoes so that she fits the bill of the company executive's wife. That is wonderful. I have no objection to that. That is a fair proposition, but why should the rest of Australian taxpayers subsidise such expenditure? I would like to hear an answer from any member of the Opposition as to why that should happen.

What about free schooling and bursaries paid to private schools? Why should an individual taxpayer, at the expense of the rest of the Australian wage earners, have the privilege of paying less income tax simply because, with the connivance of his employer, he decides to take $10,000 off his $50,000, $30,000 or $20,000 salary to be paid as a bursary to a private school so that his children can then go to school free? In that way a taxpayer reduces his taxable income by $10,000 a year and, accordingly, pays less tax. If he pays tax at the rate of 60 cents in the dollar that represents $6,000 slashed off Commonwealth revenue, yet honourable members opposite support that sort of thing. They want to change all that and re-institute that rotten system under which 11 per cent of Australian taxpayers have been subsidised by the other taxpayers of this country on such rorts. That is what honourable members opposite are going to do. They are going to stand up in this House and try to convince the rest of Australia that that is equity, that that is Liberal fairness. Is fairness and equality what they are on about? They want equality for whom?

Let us look at the capital gains tax. Honourable members opposite amaze me. Their incompetence in matters of tax just baffles me. Why do they think we need a capital gains tax in this country? We need a capital gains tax because people abuse the income tax system. The Opposition has known about it for years. It was the most incompetent government when in office. It let every tax rort slide under its feet. It destroyed the tax system, yet it wants to go back to it. It amazes me.

Let us look at the tax system. Any person involved in the business of taxation advising, which I was for many years, can tell anyone who has the capacity how to convert a source of taxable income into a capital gain. Any reasonably competent accountant or tax lawyer can tell any person who has the capacity how to convert a taxable income to a tax-free capital gain. That is what honourable members opposite are again on about. They want to go back to the system under which the Income Tax Assessment Act did not just leak but had a flood pouring out of it, a flood that honourable members opposite created. When this Government came into office it did its job and plugged up the holes, but no, the coalition's friends bleated. So we have that privileged few against all the Australian wage earners, against the vast majority of families who depend on wages and pay their fair measure of tax. Honourable members opposite are going to rort them again, are they not? I do not understand the people opposite. They just baffle me. One would think they would have learnt in government what equity and fairness in taxation was all about, but they have not.

There is enormous hypocrisy about this matter. Honourable members will recall that, back in 1980, the failed former Treasurer, the Leader of the Opposition and the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), was the Treasurer. We should not forget what happened in 1980. The then Treasurer decided that some of the rorts occurring in relation to the provision of mining housing had to be stopped. He understood then that these rorts were not fair and that somehow we had to change the system. He tried to introduce a new section into the Income Tax Assessment Act-from memory it was section 26aaa. He introduced in the House a Bill designed to impose a tax on the benefit provided to mining company employees in the form of a house. We should congratulate him on that as that was to be a tax on fringe benefits. The former failed Treasurer, to his credit, tried to do it in 1980. Let us look at what he said about it. I refer to Press release No. 81 of the then Treasurer, the honourable member for Bennelong, the hypocrite, dated 11 July 1980. What did he say about it? I quote him:

A provision such as Section 26 (e) has been a feature of our taxation laws since 1915. Fairness demands that employees who are paid solely in cash as most Australians are-should not be asked to pay more tax, and thus effectively subsidise those whose income is obtained partly in cash and partly in the form of valuable benefits of other kinds, such as employer-provided residences.

That statement was made by the then Treasurer, the honourable member for Bennelong. What do the people of Australia say to him today? An effective fringe benefits tax has been set up in this country to stop this practice, which he opposed in 1980, from occurring, and he now says that he is going to throw it out the door. People can make their own judgment on the credibility, the honesty and the integrity of a man such as that and the Party he represents. Let us go further. This is the man who wants to take on the trade union movement. This is the man who will do all the strong, tough things.

What happened in 1980 when the union movement in Queensland went out on strike because of the Act? Did he stand up to the unions? Did he take them on? Did he exercise that toughness that he now says he has to tackle the trade union movement? Do honourable members know what he did? He capitulated. He withdrew the proposition and walked away from taxing fringe benefits. That was the action of the brave Leader of the Opposition we now have-the man full of rhetoric, the man who will not cost one promise in this House, the man who will promise everything for power but never deliver-the fistful of dollars former Treasurer. That demonstrates the sort of Leader of the Opposition and the sort of Opposition we have at the moment. Honourable members opposite should be ashamed of themselves and their proposal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hicks Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1986-87 with misgivings not only for my electorate but also for the people of Australia. We on this side of the House have warned the Government for many months of the folly of its economic policies. Now those policies have brought us to the presentation of a Budget which, according to socialist policy, will cure Australia's financial problems. Looking at the Budget, what do we find? Naturally enough, we discover the common socialist elixir of imposing more taxes. In fact, the increase in taxes will amount to $1,500m in one year. When will this Government ever learn? Apart from the extra taxes announced in the Budget that will be imposed on every Australian, there are other additional taxes that will severely impact upon the viability of many small farmers, businesses and individuals in the electorate of Riverina-Darling. The recent decision by the Federal Government to reduce funding to the States will also add even more costs indirectly to every Australian because of the need for State governments to increase their taxes and charges to cover the reduction in funding. With all these additional taxes on top of the asset test, the capital gains tax and the most recent nightmare, the fringe benefits tax, I believe that the Government's promise to reduce the number of public servants is a nonsense. If anything, it will have to increase the numbers significantly to implement and process all these taxes.

SPEECH.PARA: To understand fully why the people whom I represent, particularly those in the Murrumbidgee and Colleambally irrigation areas, are so upset about the Budget, I must turn back the clock to a speech made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on 20 February 1983 at the Yoogalie Club in Griffith, which is in the heart of the Murrumbidgee irrigation area. The Prime Minister addressed a packed hall and clearly said:

The wine industry is beset with problems. The industry is faced with the need to make bold decisions at a time of low profitability, if the industry is to be in a position to meet the opportunities of the 1980s. Labor is pledged not to impose a sales tax or an excise tax on wines.
I shall repeat that. The Prime Minister said:
Labor is pledged not to impose a sales tax or an excise tax on wines.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did it keep that promise?

—No, it did not keep it, along with many other promises. This, along with the Prime Minister's guarantee not to introduce a capital gains tax, is another of his many broken promises. After bringing the fortified wine industry to its knees with an on-again off-again tax arrangement, a sales tax of 10 per cent was placed on all Australian wine in August 1984. Since then, because of the extremely competitive market-place and the over-production of grapes and wine since the imposition of the sales tax, the retail price of wine has risen only 6.5 per cent. This compares with an increase in the total consumer price index over the same period of 12.3 per cent. Therefore, the retail price of wine in real terms has declined by 5.2 per cent since the imposition of the sales tax. Clearly, the sales tax on wine has been completely absorbed along the production and distribution chain.

SPEECH.PARA: From the reaction of growers in South Australia to the vine pull scheme, it is clear that growers have absorbed a considerable amount of the tax. This could be expected given their relative bargaining position, which is weakened by the overall level of individual family farm debt. Certainly growers in the electorate of Riverina-Darling have had major problems over the last season.

In the 12 months to March 1986, sales of Australian wine were only 2.7 per cent. In volume sales were greater than the sales in the 12 months to March 1985, and this situation is not helped by the amount of wine presently being imported. A new product has recently come onto the market and, without the phenomenal sales growth exhibited by this new drink, the wine industry would be in further economic trouble. This product has also received a 10 per cent sales tax imposition. Given the current problems besetting the grape and wine industries, the Mckay Committee recommended: There should be no increase until sufficient time has gone by to measure the impact of the present tax (at least 2 to 3 years). This is particularly relevant, and obviously has been ignored by the Government.

The importation of wine is another burden the local industry is having to bear. Some weeks ago I was amazed to receive a letter from a brewery lobby suggesting that because beer was heavily taxed, wine should also be taxed. What a puerile argument. If the beer lobby is savage about the amount of tax that it is paying, and I do not blame it, why does it not lobby the Government for the reduction of the taxes placed on beer rather than trying to have wine grape growers ruined and the economy of whole regions adversely affected? With this attitude it appears that much of the nation is suffering from the heavy taxing socialist mentality.

The arguments against placing a tax on wine are not new but I would like to remind the House of the following: There are in excess of 400 wineries, located mainly in decentralised rural regions throughout Australia; there are 19 plants producing beer, mainly located in capital cities; and there are fewer than five distilleries in Australia making spirits other than brandy. Brandy, it should be noted, is produced in distilleries integrated with wineries. Ninety-six per cent of all wine sold in Australia is made in Australia in an annual production period of maximum duration of three months. From the highly perishable grapes grown throughout Australia, approximately 70 per cent of the grapes used for wine making are in fact suitable only for winery purposes and have no other use. Honourable members can therefore see the very real problems wine grape growers in particular face. This additional tax is going to cause extreme hardship not only to the wine industry but also to those people in regional areas who depend so much upon that industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —A decentralised industry.
—Yes, a decentralised industry. We all know of the problem that we are having in rural Australia because of the Government's policies, and this will cause further hardship.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to the citrus industry and the Government's 10 per cent taxation on Australian fruit juice. Harking back to another quote of the Prime Minister of 20 February 1983, the honourable gentleman said:
The citrus industry is threatened by the Fraser Government's decision to reduce its protection. A Labor Government will maintain existing protection levels.

How this situation has changed. It is yet another broken promise. Honourable members will understand if I dwell on the citrus industry because I know that other will speak of the tax placed on other fruit juices and flavoured milk. Recently a telex was sent to the Prime Minister, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and other senior Ministers. This telex from the Australian Citrus Industry Council, representing the interests of the citrus industry, placed before the Government a request that in consideration of matters pertaining to the 1986 Budget, no action be taken to remove the current sales tax exemption provision applicable to fruit juices, fruit juice drinks and fruit juice cordial.

I shall mention some of the contents of the message. It pointed out that fruit juices, fruit drinks and fruit juice cordials were subject to sales tax, but were granted exemption from tax provided that they contained not less than 25 per cent Australian fruit juice. This vitally important exemption arrangement was first introduced in 1932 to encourage the use of Australian fruit juices. The present 25 per cent content arrangement had been in place since 1953. The exemption arrangement provided an incentive to manufacturers to use Australian fruit juices at a time when the Government was encouraging a `Buy Australia' approach by consumers and, of course, we are back in that phase again. It ensured that, even though economic consideration may have favoured the greater use by manufacturers of lower-priced imported fruit juices, at least 25 per cent of the fruit juice content in the said fruit juice products would be of Australian origin.

The removal of the exemption arrangement would eliminate this incentive and result in a dramatic increase in the use of imported citrus juices, with disastrous effects for Australian citrus growers and processors. We can see what is happening at this moment in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is crippling them.

—Yes, it is crippling them. Australian citrus juice production in 1985-86 was estimated at 150 million litres, and this production would be subject to severe economic pressures in competing with the lower priced imported product if the exemption were removed. Next week in my electorate I have a meeting with the citrus growers, who are very concerned about these imports.

SPEECH.PARA: The citrus industry was already suffering extreme hardship in the 1986-87 season due to the collapse in world orange juice prices in 1986 and its resultant effect on the industry, particularly the growing and processing sectors. The removal of the exemption would undoubtedly further exacerbate this hardship and contribute to additional grower viability problems, loss of employment opportunities in the industry and a serious effect on the economies of the inland citrus-producing regions and irrigation districts, including those in the Riverina.

The removal of the exemption would increase the retail cost of the product to the consumer and this increase would be particularly severe on pensioners and low-income families who see these products containing at least 25 per cent Australian fruit juice as an important `food' in the `necessities of life' categories.

TALK.START.PARA: —Vitamin C.

—Yes, vitamin C. As an alternative to increasing the retail price, manufacturers could move away from producing products containing at least 25 per cent fruit juice to lower juice content products. The product would be then in the same category as carbonated soft drinks, which contain little or no fruit juice. Consumers, particularly pensioners and low-income families, would have reduced access to these beverages, which contain an important level of nutritional value. This research has confirmed the important role of fruit and fruit juices in providing an invaluable source of dietary fibre to the community.

SPEECH.PARA: Previous governments have always wisely recognised the value of fruit juice products to the community and now, despite the crisis faced by the growers and their families in the citrus industry, the Hawke Government has decided to deal them another savage blow. The worst fears of the industry previously mentioned have been realised.

I should like to draw to the attention of the House and recommend a document produced by the Australian Catholic Welfare Commission entitled `A Fair Go for Families'. We in the National Party believe that the family is the primary unit of support and nurture for individuals. The document points out the serious situation in which many Australian families find themselves today as the result of this and previous Federal Budgets. Over the last 10 years there has been a major decline in Federal economic support for the Australian family. For instance, the tax imposed on the family with four children living on average weekly earnings has increased by 435 per cent while wages have increased by only 135 per cent. This, in Australia, is simply unbelievable. Even families with two children will be receiving tax rebates worth 0.78 per cent of average weekly earnings, whereas in 1951 the average weekly earner with two children had his taxable income reduced by a deduction worth 21.56 per cent of average weekly earnings; that is, 0.78 per cent compared with 21.56 per cent.

It is a sound principle of social philosophy that the State should not take upon itself functions which can be performed efficiently by smaller bodies. The family is a natural society which existed prior to the State or any other community and possesses rights which are inalienable. Poverty hinders many Australian families, whether living on their own income or supported by social security benefits, from performing with dignity their role of caring for family members. Family incomes must be sufficient for establishing and maintaining a family with dignity either through an appropriate salary, often called a family wage, or through other social measures such as family allowances, tax rebates or the financial recognition of the work performed in the home by one of the parents. Family incomes should be such that one parent is not obliged to work outside the home to the detriment of family life and especially, the emotional stability and education of the children. Yet the only area of welfare that has received spending cuts is that of family allowances. Spending has been cut by 11.2 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —And aged pensions.

—Certainly aged pensions have been delayed, but actual recognised cuts to Australian families amount to 11.2 per cent. The Government has decided to penalise families at the most expensive time for parents by means testing the family allowance payments for 16- and 17-year-olds. I wonder what happens when one has a 16- or 17-year-old on unemployment benefits. Is that situation means tested? I can see a very serious problem developing here and I can see the whole situation getting out of hand.

SPEECH.PARA: There is also the new Government scheme to pay an amount to those 16- and 17-year-olds who wish to live away from home for one reason or another. I can see a serious situation developing in that respect. Surely the Government should be spending some money in trying to keep families together instead of trying to keep families apart, or so it seems from every piece of legislation that comes before this Parliament. Most Australian taxpayers with dependants, especially single income families, will suffer a decline in real income by 1988, despite the proposed new tax scales devised after the 1985 Tax Summit. It is clear that the tax system penalises families with children, particularly single income and large families.

Failure to protect the interests of families, particularly large single income families, in the taxation system and in some components of the social security system means that the Federal Government is allowing the standard of living of parents and children to fall while protecting childless groups through the accord and the indexation of adult pensions. The Australian tax system effectively ignores the cost of caring for dependants. In the main, it treats taxpayers with children no differently from their childless workmates. Family unit taxation is already a component of the Australian taxation system. The tax system allows voluntary income sharing for tax purposes among family members in company and business partnerships. If the tax system can be arranged to suit the families of owners of businesses and investment property, there is no reason why family unit taxation, through splitting family income against family members, should not be made available to pay as you earn taxpayers with dependants. To refuse income splitting to these taxpayers, as the present Federal Government advocated in its 1985 draft White Paper on taxation reform, is to treat ordinary workers as second class citizens. It is notable that the Australian Council of Trade Unions supported the extension of income splitting rights to wage and salary earners before the Asprey Taxation Review Committee. Children are a social asset, not a luxury. They are a nation's investment in the future.

My time has almost run out and there are many things I would have liked to have spoken on, particularly the increase in the excise on fuel from 6.1c per litre in March 1983 to 23.9c per litre today. In my electorate of Riverina-Darling, where most things have to be trucked in, where everything is transported and a great amount of fuel is used, not only on the farms, it will add to the price of just about every commodity that is brought into the electorate. I would also just quickly like to mention the Army Reserve. At last the Government has woken up to the fact that the only way to have any sort of an Army Reserve is to reward those people who provide that service to the nation, all of them very dedicated people. We were all aghast to learn that the Government had cut out the taxation provisions for Army reservists. I am pleased to say that now the Government has restored those taxation provisions for the Army reservists. I say also to the Government, while I am on my feet, that I think it is about time that it got very serious about this matter and provided some finance for these young people, particularly in country areas, to travel to their units for training, and also so that these people can have some time in training. They are dedicated; otherwise they would not be in the Army Reserve, and I just ask the Government to think seriously about supporting these young Army reservists in the way they deserve.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free Mr R.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —In Melbourne last evening, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), in the course of an address on the Budget, favoured his audience with a literary illusion in terms of Norman Lindsay's famous The Magic Pudding. This marvellous creation in the book was a self-replacing pudding. The characters in the book could place enormous demands on the pudding and its response was to regenerate itself. In the words of the book, one could cut and come again. I must say that I am pleased with that Prime Ministerial allusion for two reasons. First, it allows me the opportunity to do a commercial. It allows me the opportunity to draw to the attention of the House to an excellent exhibition titled `The Plague of Lindsays', which is currently on display at the National Trust's Norman Lindsay Gallery at Faulconbridge. The exhibition is sponsored by James Hardie Industries Ltd. It was opened last weekend by John Reid, the Chairman of Hardies, and the exhibition concentrates on the early illustrative works of the remarkable Lindsay family. As the member for the electorate which bears the Lindsay name, I am pleased to discharge my responsibility by saying that the exhibition is certainly well worth a visit and to encourage people to go along and enjoy it.

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased with that allusion for a second reason. It very neatly encapsulates the message of this Budget. We all recognise that while demands may be infinite, the resources to meet them in the real world of 1986 most certainly are not. In many ways they are diminishing resources and that means difficult choices and unpalatable decisions for the Government. Given this environment, the Government has had the courage to do three very necessary things. First, it has faced the realities of Australia's current position and it has taken the public into its confidence. Secondly, it has recognised that there is no easy way out of our difficulty, that there is absolutely no quick fix and that sacrifices have to be made in the short term for long term benefits. Thirdly, the Government has asserted very firmly that in the face of these difficulties the burden of sacrifice must be shared. That is the government position. I believe that it is the position of the overwhelming majority of Australians. It is certainly the position of the overwhelming majority of the commentators, and I believe it to be the position of the trade union movement.
The commentators yesterday gave the Budget a response that could really only be described by the term `rave reviews'. Let me quote from the Melbourne Age. The commentator said:

As the Prime Minister amply warned, the Budget is `tough'. But, also as promised, the Treasurer has done his utmost, within the constraints imposed by economic imperatives, to distribute the burdens fairly.
Further down he said:
. . . The imposed burdens have been necessary in aggregate and have been generally distributed to the best economic advantage and least social detriment.
The Australian said of the Budget:
The Federal Government has given us a tough budget, but one that deserves considerable praise.

The Australian Financial Review referred to the Budget as `economically responsible and politically honest'. The Canberra Times headed its editorial `A Sensible Budget'. I referred earlier to the trade unions. The co-operation that the trade unions have provided to the Government under the prices and incomes accord has been magnificent. That co-operation has been an essential ingredient in the many successes and important achievements of the Government and of the progress that has been made since March 1983. I remind the House of the record. In the past four successive financial years, real labour costs have fallen each year. So, too, have working days lost through strikes. The paradox was noted by Ross Gittins in the Sydney Morning Herald in April. He said:

The more the unions have lifted their game, the more strident the Right's anti-union rhetoric has become. The more evidence has emerged of the Accord working, the more demands have grown that it be smashed. At a time when union militancy is demonstrably at its lowest ebb in memory, we're hearing more about `the abuse of union power' than ever before. Katharine West has drifted so far from reality as to speak of `ousting the union dictatorship'.
Far from what commentators such as Katharine West would have us believe, it is widely recognised that all Australians have been the beneficiaries of sensible, co-operative industrial relations.

In particular, I am glad that sense appears to be prevailing on the question of holiday loadings and flexitime. Despite claims to the contrary, holiday loadings operate at equal or greater levels in many overseas countries. The hidden agenda behind the current campaign for their abolition is to impose a selective wage cut and to throw the burden on to wage and salary earners. It is certainly a burden that would not be borne by the non-wage sector. Those who argue for the abolition of flexitime also miss the point. Flexible hours maximise the use of plant and equipment in the work place, provide overall extended hours of service and reduce peak demand on transport systems. The practice should be encouraged and extended. Those who point to the abuses, whether real or imagined, are arguing only against badly administered systems of flexible hours. Those arguments would apply in respect of any badly run system. Properly run, the system can and does produce great benefits.

I referred earlier to the common position which I believe is emerging following Tuesday night's Budget-a position that is shared by the Government, the majority of the public, the commentators and the unions-

TALK.START.PARA: —But not the financial markets.

—And not you either. In this context, it is not unreasonable to ask where the Opposition stands. One commentator in the Melbourne Age mentioned the `responsibility and duty' of the Opposition to at least agree that a nation in crisis has to face up to hard options. He asked the question:

SPEECH.PARA: Will John Howard be big enough to accept that national survival is at least as important as short-term political advantage?

On recent form, the chances of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) being big enough to accept that proposition are 100 to one. It is not even a chance, because he is not even a trier. He made his position clear at the Liberal Party's recent Adelaide conference, when he said that he would be concentrating on the 2.5 per cent of voters that he needs to sway to win the next election. The Leader of the Opposition-the leader of the party of individual selfishness and collective greed-will seek to anaesthetise public intelligence for a period sufficient to extract those necessary votes.

The evidence is clear from the Liberal Party's recent advertising campaign. We have all seen the advertisements where a hairy fist squeezes an object of unknown origin to produce a liquid that varies in colour in the different editions of the newspapers from orange through to red. The advertisements say that only a Liberal government will scrap Labor's fringe benefits tax, scrap Labor's capital gains tax, scrap Labor's superannuation lump sum tax and scrap Labor's assets test. Those four promises would cost $940m each year. That is $940m on top of the Leader of the Opposition's April expenditure promises of $1,500m a year and on top of the National Party's promises to the rural sector of $500m. Those figures are all part of John Howard's $11 billion credibility gap that we heard about at Question Time today. It is clear that the architect of the $9.6 billion deficit has learnt nothing and forgotten nothing. Given the chance, he would do it to Australia all over again.

In the first edition of the National Times on Sunday, Patrick Cook identified the Liberal obsession with the hairy fist syndrome in political advertising. It began many years ago with one of Bob Askin's advertisements in New South Wales. That consisted of two hands clasped. It has been a recurring theme in Liberal Party advertising since then. Who could possibly forget the Liberal Party advertisement in the 1977 election campaign? That was the famous fistful of dollars campaign. There were two hairy fists, one empty and one full of $5 notes. The message back in 1977 was:
Liberal gives tax cuts. Wage earners will receive extra dollars in every pay packet.
The slogan was:
Liberal. Doing the job.

We all remember what happened to those tax cuts. They were the famous Claytons tax cuts, which were taken away by the Liberal Treasurer, who is now the Leader of the Opposition. I am sure that he remembers equally the reaction to the mini Budget that broke those promises and took those tax cuts back. I am sure that the Leader of the Opposition remembers the article in the Illawarra Mercury at the time, which had the headline `Lies, lies, lies!'. There was a picture of John Howard and the comment that Mr Howard had brought down a savage mini Budget which broke two promises on personal income tax.

The Leader of the Opposition simply cannot be believed and cannot be trusted. The promises to scrap fringe benefits tax, capital gains tax, the tax on lump sums and the assets test would not only cost $940m a year but would reintroduce the abuses of tax avoidance and double dipping that were abolished by the reforms of the Labor Government. I refer especially to the fringe benefits tax, because the Liberal Party in New South Wales has been writing to people recently. Most of their mail is passed on to me pretty smartly. This was a letter sent last week by Mr Robert Frost, the chairman of the central Finance Committee of the Liberal Party's New South Wales division. It uses pretty extravagant language. It is printed in two colours with much underlining. The sting is in the tail of the letter, where he says:

If you could send a special contribution of at least $50 it would be a great help . . . Or better yet, if you could manage $75, $100 or even more, we could fund the most intensive campaign to get rid of Labor . . . Right now we're pre-selecting Liberal candidates in marginal Labor seats and it's their campaigns we have to fund to beat Labor. And your contribution will help do that.
They have not been very successful in my area. Twice in recent weeks they have opened and closed nominations without finding a candidate.

I should add that Mr Frost seems to be a little out of date. He gets stuck into the Australian Democrats in this letter as well, and calls them the `soft-bellied Democrats'. He invites the recipients of the letters to send postcards to Senator Don Chipp. I do not think he was aware that the leadership was about to change. It is a fascinating item of correspondence in the Liberal Party's current campaign against the fringe benefits tax, which has been a most dishonest campaign. We all recognise that abolition of the fringe benefits tax would mean a return to a system under which the vast majority of pay as you earn taxpayers would, once again be subsidising the lurks and perks enjoyed by the privileged few at the expense of the many. The abolition of the tax would mean a return to the days of tax minimisation, for which the majority of taxpayers would pay $500m a year.

The fringe benefits tax is an essential part of this Government's tax reform package. It is essential for three reasons: Firstly, because it brings fairness and equity into the overall tax system; secondly, because it will help pay for the cuts in personal income tax that are an integral part of the package, the Government's two stage program to reduce marginal rates as well as the corporate taxation return; and thirdly, because it is only through a fairer and more stable taxation system and a more efficient economy that we will be able to help to give Australia a better economic future. We need have no doubt about it-the Liberals commitment to abolish the fringe benefits tax amounts to a commitment to tax loopholes, to an unfair system and to higher levels of direct taxation. It amounts to a return to injustice in taxation.

Earlier in my remarks I referred to the importance in the Budget strategy of sharing the burden. I am pleased that the Budget contains some measures to protect the poorest Australians. In particular, I was pleased to see that the family income supplement was increased because I have been concerned for some time about the extent to which the family income supplement is taken up. My concern began at the opening of the new office of the Department of Social Security in Penrith in my electorate some months ago when I noticed that the regional office statistics for the family income supplement showed that only 73 families in the area served by that office were receiving the family income supplement. I believe that many more than that number would be eligible. In thinking about it, I can see some problems with the administration of the family income supplement.

I think there are two important problems that ought to be addressed. The family income supplement is not a terribly visible benefit and, for that reason, public awareness of its existence tends to be lower than awareness of other benefits. There is obviously very wide awareness in the public that the age pension becomes available at a particular age and that people apply for this pension as they become eligible. The family income supplement is rather different because eligibility depends on the income level of the family concerned. The second reason is that eligible families-to be eligible one cannot be in receipt of another benefit-would be unlikely to be regular or even occasional visitors to Department of Social Security offices, and that is where the information is available.

The actual extent of the problem across Australia is very difficult to gauge. There are some overseas figures on take-up rates of similar programs and they are not terribly satisfactory either. A similar program, called the family income supplement scheme, runs in Britain. The best estimates in the mid-1970s of the take-up rate in the United Kingdom was 75 per cent. Following some controversy about difficulties involved in actually measuring the take-up rate there was a rather dramatic downwards revision of the estimates in 1979 that suggested that only about half of those eligible families in Britain actually participated. There is a similar scheme in the United States of America as well-the assistance to families with dependant children scheme. There have been estimates of the take-up rate in the United States also, but they are equally unsatisfactory. In the 1970s the estimates of the take-up rate varied from 20 per cent to almost all eligible families participating.

The task in Australia is equally complicated by a lack of appropriate information. But a calculation based on the 1984 household expenditure survey suggested that of a possible 150,000 eligible families only 26,000 families were taking up the benefit. It is likely that the estimate of 150,000 is a high estimate. Some of those families may be ineligible because they are receiving some other cash benefit. This difficulty does concern me. I trust that it will be taken up in the current review and that some investigation will be undertaken into the means of providing better information services, co-ordination of the Commonwealth Employment Service with the Department of Social Security and the possible use of the records of the Australian Taxation Office to identify the eligible and very needy families that may be missing out on a very important Commonwealth benefit.

I simply say in commending the Budget that I am pleased that it recognises the great challenges that face this nation and recognises and spells out very clearly that there is no easy way out of our problems and no quick fix. It is a long haul. I commend the Budget to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beale Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Budget Speech made by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has firmly identified that Australia is suffering a serious economic crisis. He even acknowledged in his preliminary remarks that the economy was `doing so poorly in 1986'. He further identified that `the answer lies in the dramatic collapse in world commodity prices since late last year'. Having diagnosed the economic crisis, the Treasurer then told us not to worry, that he would fix everything, and he proposes to do it by increasing taxation.

SPEECH.PARA: Everybody is now aware that both the Treasurer and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) have acknowledged Australia's economic difficulties only in the last few months. Until that time they were telling the Australian people that our economy was running along smoothly, that we were experiencing healthy growth and that the Government had the situation well under control. Incredible as it may seem, in view of their bullish statements for the greater part of the last fiscal year, the Treasurer's own Budget Papers for the year 1985-86, which were presented to the Parliament and the people of Australia a year ago, had already drawn attention to what the Treasurer now calls the heart of our economic problems. On page 73 of last year's Budget Paper No. 1, the following sentence appears:
A marked deterioration in the terms of trade is expected reflecting primarily the relative weakness of world prices for our commodity based products.

Not a slight deterioration, a small deterioration, or even just a deterioration, but a marked deterioration in terms of trade was expected according to the Budget Paper. It is to be hoped that, in sharp contrast to last year, the Treasurer actually reads the present Budget Papers. If he reads them they will tell him the following: Inflation in Australia will be several times higher than the inflation rate of our major trading partners; unemployment in our community will rise; our terms of trade will continue to deteriorate despite the savage decline in the value of the Australian dollar against the currencies of our major trading partners that has occurred over the past year; and interest rates will stay at high levels.

It should be noted that there is very little mention of the sort of monetary policy the Government intends to pursue. Will it defend the dollar or not? What trade off does the Government see between interest rates and currency stability? For how long will monetary policy be used to protect the value of our currency if the technical recession in which Australia now finds itself is to continue? The Budget Papers also say that household disposable income and domestic demand will fall; investment will be lower; wages will increase by 6 per cent; the public sector debt is now over 50 per cent of gross domestic product; public sector interest payments are at record levels; and our overseas debt is at a record level and will probably be around $100 billion by the end of the current financial year. In the housing industry, expenditure on dwellings will fall by 5 per cent and expenditure on non-dwelling construction will also fall. If the Treasurer reads the Budget Papers, that is what he will find.

Those points are a very succinct summary of the economic mess into which the Government has led us. Unbelievably, the Treasurer's response is to increase taxation. Taxation receipts for the current year will be substantially higher than in the last two years, as will be total receipts. Furthermore, in another piece of sleight of hand, the Budget's funding is assisted by an involuntary donation from the Reserve Bank of Australia. This involuntary donation from the Reserve Bank is spelt out on page 392 of Budget Paper No. 1. In 1976-77, the Reserve Bank contributed $80m to the coffers of the Commonwealth Treasury. In the first Budget of the current Government in 1983-84, this figure rose to $746m but the estimate for the current year is a massive $2.6 billion. That is the extent to which the Reserve Bank has been forced to dip into its reserves to help bale out the Government.

There has been a great deal of hoopla from the Government about the fact that the deficit has been reduced. The forecast for the current year is $3.5 billion compared with the forecast for the previous year of $4.9 billion. This reduced deficit has been achieved not by spending cuts, as promised by the Government, but by increases in taxation and a huge and reluctant donation from the Reserve Bank. Here we see yet another action by the Government that will contribute further to the seriousness of Australia's economic position. At present the Reserve Bank is spending a great deal of money, valiantly trying to protect the value of the Australian dollar. Yet the Government has weakened the Bank's ability to protect our currency by robbing it of the necessary reserves that it requires to do so. Furthermore, it should be clear to everybody that the deficit assumption of $3.5 billion is very shaky indeed. There could be no better way to justify this than to examine what happened last year. Last year, the Treasurer estimated a deficit of $4.9 billion. The deficit turned out to be $5.7 billion, or really $6.5 billion if one counts the extra $800m taken from the Reserve Bank. That figure would have been even higher had not the Government broken its trilogy promise by raising taxes earlier this year.

We heard a great deal about the trilogy in the 1984 election campaign. We have heard very little from the Government about the trilogy since the Government broke its promise not to lift tax revenues as a share of gross domestic product from the 1984-85 level either in 1985-86 or over the life of the Parliament. Accordingly, the deficit figure looks very shaky indeed. Furthermore, we should be quite clear that a deficit is a deficit. It is grossly misleading to say, as the Treasurer has implied, that the Government has improved its position by $1.4 billion from last year to this year as a result of a reduction in the deficit year to year from $4.9 billion to $3.5 billion. The fact is that this year, according to the Treasurer, Government debt will increase by a further $3.5 billion. The Government has made us $3.5 billion worse off this year. Repayment of Commonwealth debt is the third largest item of expenditure in the Federal Budget. It is higher than expenditure on defence; it is higher than expenditure on health and higher than expenditure on education. What we are now seeing is that funds that might have been used for legitimate government services or given back to the taxpayer as lower taxes in order to increase demand, investment and jobs are now being dissipated in debt repayment.

In order to achieve this deficit level of $3.5 billion, the Government has proudly boasted that there will be no increase in Government expenditure in real terms in the current year. What sort of achievement is that?
Debate interrupted.
