Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beale Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —What sort of an achievement is that when we are looking at such a high base? Government expenditure in real terms rose at an annual rate of just over 2 per cent in the seven years of the previous coalition Government. Yet in three years of the current Government, expenditure in real terms has risen at around 7 per cent, 6 per cent and 3 per cent respectively. After having increased Government expenditure so sharply in the past three years, it can hardly be described as a worthwhile achievement that the Government is estimated to contain Government expenditure to zero per cent growth in real terms in the current year.

SPEECH.PARA: We need to understand how the Government has got Australia into such an economic mess. We need to understand how the Government has lost the confidence of both international and local investors. What has happened is that as a nation we have been spending at a much faster rate than we have been earning. This has resulted in a massive increase in Australia's overseas debt relative to our total output. In the past four years our gross overseas debt has increased from around 16 per cent to nearly 36 per cent of our gross domestic product. Our overseas reserves have been run down and we have now had four years in which the current account deficit has climbed from around 4 per cent to around 6 per cent of gross domestic product. This deteriorating situation compares with the historical two and a half per cent level of current account deficit to gross domestic product.

As the Treasurer said, the problem arises because our terms of trade have deteriorated sharply. Since most of this deterioration has occurred over the past two years, the Government should have acted responsibly to change its policies and to create an environment which would allow the necessary adjustments to occur without creating the instability and uncertainty that now exists. The Government has failed to take the necessary steps to create that environment. It has blamed everybody but itself. It has blamed overseas investors; it has blamed the financial markets; it has blamed local management and it has blamed local investors. The Government should have recognised-and taken the appropriate responses-that we have been living in an increasingly competitive world in which demand for our products has been slowing. What the Government should have been doing was to take steps to improve our international competitiveness and contain our domestic spending to a rate more consistent with our capacity to earn.

The Government's fundamental mistake was to rely on the depreciation of our exchange rate to allow it to maintain its big spending policies. The effect of Government policies, and the splurge in domestic spending, increased imports and held back exports, added to our current account deficit and external debt and caused the depreciation of our exchange rate 12 to 18 months ago-long before the terms of trade started their major deterioration. The Government's policy of growth at all costs has indeed been costly and we will have to pay a high price. A good deal of our economic growth over the past few years has been based on shaky ground. It has been overseas borrowings that have financed the binge of consumption in both the public and private sectors. The Government's economic policy failures now mean that for some years we will need to contain domestic spending consistent with reducing the current account deficit.

Furthermore, the Government has failed to realise that there will be continued weak demand for our exports and the likelihood of a fall in price of those exports. The Government should not base its economic strategy on the assumption that revenue from our exports will show any significant increase over the years ahead. The Government must also recognise that it will take some time to create an economic environment that is conducive for Australian manufacturers to develop facilities that will produce import replacements. Our heavy dependence on imports of capital equipment should continue, and when business investment starts to recover, import volumes will increase.

The Government has also failed to recognise that the Australian currency remains very much at risk. Some of the depreciation that has taken place over the past 18 months may have been necessary to improve international competitiveness, but it should be emphasised that further falls would be counter-productive. If we are to attract the foreign capital that is required to finance our large current account deficit, we must have domestic conditions conductive to foreigners making large purchases of Australian securities and to discourage Australians from making large investments offshore. It is clear that there has been a complete loss of confidence by both overseas and domestic investors in the Government's capacity to adopt the policies needed for a stable exchange rate. That confidence must be restored by firmer domestic policies to achieve exchange rate stability.

What has happened to the Australian economy over the last few years demonstrates the high price we are paying for our inflexible wages system. The small reduction that has occurred in real wages in recent times is totally inadequate for Australia's economic needs. It is this that marks the accord between the Labor Party and the Australian Council of Trade Unions as a failure and makes nonsense of claims by the ACTU that the trade union movement is unable to bear any further cuts in real wages. If a significant reduction cannot be achieved through adjustments to real wages, we will see the emergence of much higher unemployment and a stagnating economy. Bold and firm decisions are needed to restore Australia's economic viability, and this Government has failed the test. It is clear that what needs to be done is for the Government to adopt significant changes in its fiscal and wages policies. What has been suggested in the Budget Papers is totally inadequate.

Australia needs reduction in taxation, both personal and corporate, in order to restore incentive. Australia needs the abolition of disincentive taxes-the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax. Australia needs less government expenditure. It is vital that we reduce our reliance on external savings. To achieve this, the Government must effect a major reduction in the public sector's call on savings. If it does not do this, the only way in which our reliance on external savings can be reduced is by a recession in private sector spending. A zero per cent increase in government expenditure is inadequate, given the high base from which the current financial year commenced. Australia needs a sharp curtailment in the growth of wages; major changes in work practices; the abolition of all unnecessary regulations which inhibit business and personal freedom; and a review of our education system so that it is geared to careers and not to teacher's hobbies.

We in the Opposition know what Australia needs. A coalition government would create a climate of lower taxes, less government involvement in our lives, a freer wages market and lower interest rates that would encourage investment in our industry. The Government has identified that Australia is in a severe economic crisis and that the major contributing reason for this lies in our inability to sell more to the rest of the world than we buy from the rest of the world. But this Government has introduced a Budget that demonstrably fails to deal with the crisis. It should have created an environment for lower interest rates; it should have cut taxes, not increased them; it should have cut government expenditure in real terms; and it should have determined a policy that will cause real wages to fall. This Budget is a major disappointment and the Government has failed the Australian people. However, the next coalition government will not fail them.
Debate (on motion by Mrs Kelly) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Institute of Sport-Qantas Airways Ltd-National Times on Sunday Article-Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr West) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise briefly an important matter relating to the Australian Institute of Sport. It has been reported that on 5 August members of the Criminal Investigation Branch of the Australian Federal Police raided the Australian Institute of Sport, a private home in New South Wales and some premises in Melbourne. Because the Criminal Investigation Branch is involved, it is obviously no light matter. This is but one of the continuing saga of the problems that have beset the Institute of Sport for some time. People at the Institute, people who take an interest in sport generally, and I, are disturbed that the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) has not made a statement on this matter. I have spoken to him and he has declined to make a statement. I believe the matter should be raised in the House in an effort to get some response from the Government. At the very least, the Minister owes it to the staff and members of the Australian Institute of Sport to give an explanation as to what is happening, because the morale of the staff and the athletes at the Institute has suffered.

SPEECH.PARA: We should have had a full inquiry last November. Although at that time the Minister said that all was well, I said that an auditor's check on the problems at the Institute was not enough and, as it has turned out, it was not enough because the Criminal Investigation Branch of the Federal Police is now involved. Since last November the Auditor-General's staff and the Department of Finance have been crawling all over the place in an effort to tighten up the administration. On behalf of the Opposition and all the taxpayers of this country who are contributing $12m in this year's Budget to the Australian Institute of Sport, I ask these questions: When will the Minister address the problem? Will he address it before he retires from this Parliament-which, according to him, might be imminent as apparently he has had enough? Did the raids in fact take place?

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not going to tell you.
—There is the man who should be answering the question. What about the staff and athletes at the Institute? Will they be kept in limbo for days, weeks or months?
—We are not going to tell you.
—I see. It will be a deep, dark secret in the Minister's little cabinet.
—You wait until you win the election in the year 2020.
—It will not be that long, my friend. When are we likely to know what is to happen as a result of these police raids?
—Why don't you join the police force?

—The honourable gentleman is the responsible Minister. What about telling the taxpayers who are contributing $12m to keep the Institute running? That is a fair question. Why does not the Minister say something instead of having a little giggle and saying `I'm not going to tell you'. Does the Minister still maintain that all is well? Does he intend to get up and tell us another funny joke about the police, the Institute and the 300 athletes who are waiting to find out what is happening? Why was there not a full inquiry in November? Is all of the staff at the Institute under suspicion? If not, who is? Why were the police raids also carried out in New South Wales and Victoria? Why were the raids carried out by the Criminal Investigation Branch?

SPEECH.PARA: These are some of the questions that should be answered. There is no question of the matter being sub judice. It is not before the courts; no charges have been laid. Why did those raids take place? How long will the people at the Institute be kept in suspense as to what is going on out there? The Minister is obviously too tired or too disillusioned to turn his attention to this matter. As I said, this matter was raised a couple of weeks ago. For God's sake, if the Minister cannot address the problems that have been going on at the Institute for months on end, he should get out and give someone else a go. The fact is that these problems have been going on for months. The Criminal Investigation Branch of the Federal Police is now involved. The Special Minister of State (Mr Young), who is responsible for the police, sits on the front bench and giggles as though it is a light matter. Thirteen or 14 people from the Criminal Investigation Branch raided the Institute and other premises. For God's sake, show some sense and tell us what is going on out there, instead of leaving all of those people in limbo.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to refer to a letter written by Mr J. B. Leslie, Chairman of Qantas Airways Ltd published in the Australian Financial Review of 28 July 1986. I would say in passing that, if that newspaper wants to maintain its claim to being a responsible newspaper, it should at least give an opportunity for an alternative point of view to be put in its letters column. On that occasion it gave Mr Leslie a large amount of space in which to put his case.

SPEECH.PARA: In view of Australia's most recent and worrying balance of trade figures, I feel it is timely to take to task recent critics of Australian exporters attempting to increase the nation's share of world trade. In particular I would like to correct the defence of Qantas recently reported by its Chairman, Mr J. B. Leslie. Mr Leslie has poured scorn on attempts by other international airlines to help Australia's present trading problems by providing air freight services to our falling Middle East markets and elsewhere. He argued against a deregulation of international air rights and the freeing of international freight markets. His public arguments were made shortly before it was officially announced that Australia's current account deficit in July of $1.5 billion was almost $500m more than in June. While the fluctuating Australian dollar helps the export side of the Australian economy, it is obvious from the latest figures that more needs to be achieved and by all possible means.

While Mr Leslie may feel that Qantas has the capacity to service chilled primary produce markets, two salient points need to be made. First, Qantas is, as fast as possible, introducing one stop flights to London, by passing most Middle East ports. Secondly, Australian exports to the Gulf states fell from a peak of $115m in the year ending June 1984 to $70m in the year ending June 1985. These specific markets were found to be highly attractive by the Middle East food export drive set up by the then Secretary to the Department of Trade, Mr John Menadue, who now happens to be the General Manager of Qantas. Mr Leslie is on record as asserting that there are no new markets for which Qantas and other scheduled carriers are not currently catering. These assertions not only fly in the face of findings by the Scully Review of International Airfreight Policy but go against independent studies by the State governments of New South Wales, Victoria and Western Australia and such bodies as the National Farmers Federation. For example, the Western Australian Government old the Scully Review:

It seems to have been too easy for regulators and the regulated alike to convince themselves that the service they provide caters for demand. What disturbs both the producer representatives bodies and the Western Australian Government is that, if this situation persists, would-be exporters will lose heart and cease to attempt to produce for markets which an inadequate transport service denies them access to.

Mr Leslie, in his public comments, attempted to shoot down the attempts by an Asian airline which is seeking to resume scheduled flights to and from Australia and promising to deliver Australian primary produce to the Middle East.

On 15 August the Government of Sri Lanka lodged an application for the resumption of scheduled direct air services between Australia and Colombo by its national airline, Airlanka. The application was lodged under the existing air service agreement signed by the two countries in 1950. The agreement is still in force. Airlanka proposes to run a twice weekly Sydney- Melbourne-Perth-Colombo and return service using a Boeing 747 Combi aircraft. Each aircraft would be capable of carrying 42 tonnes of freight, which could to transhipped at Colombo to lucrative Middle East markets. A key to the Airlanka proposal will be the establishment of chilling facilities, with Australian management and equity participation in the free trade zone at Colombo. It will make use of 30 outward flights a week to the Gulf states. To the Gulf area alone ex Colombo, there are six weekly flights to Abu Dhabi, two to Bahrain, four to Dhahran, one to Doha, seven to Dubai, two to Jedda, four to Kuwait, three to Muscat and even two to Tripoli. It is positive offers such as these which will help Australia trade its way out of economic difficulties. It is the negative and knocking attitudes of certain sections of the Australian business world and the bureaucracies which will not help.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the standards of good government is for Ministers not only to be above reproach but to be seen to be above reproach. It is a standard that is acknowledged throughout the Western democracies and was a hallmark of the Fraser Administration. Last week the National Times on Sunday raised serious allegations about the conduct of the Treasurer (Mr Keating). On Tuesday at Question Time I asked the Treasurer what steps he intended to take to answer the allegations. On Wednesday a question from the media provided him with an opportunity to answer one aspect of the allegations. On both occasions he avoided the question and heaped abuse on the questioner. I make no allegations. I simply put the proposition that the newspaper article raises more questions than it answers and the Treasurer has an obligation to clear the air. The questions that should be answered--
-Order! The honourable member should be aware that he cannot come into the House and make allegations about another member except upon a substantive motion. That is the standing order.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I made it quite clear that I was making no allegations. I was simply going to ask some questions which I believe required answering. One can hardly call a question an allegation.
—One cannot couch questions in the form of an aspersion.
—Perhaps we ought to hear the questions first.

—The honourable member for Barker does not have the call, so he will remain seated and quiet. If a member wishes to make allegations against another member, it has to be by substantive motion. That is clearly the forms of the House. I am quite happy to entertain a motion from the honourable member, except that it would be out of order at this stage, I would think. The honourable member may wish to couch his points in some other way, but he should be aware of the fact that he cannot just stand up and do what I think he is about to do.

—Frankly, that may be rather indicative, may it not? The simple situation is that I have made the statement that I do not intend making any allegations. I simply intend to ask the questions and as you said, Mr Deputy Speaker, you have not as yet heard one of the questions. I would appreciate the opportunity to put the questions.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member said that he thought that there were allegations made which needed answering. The Standing Orders provide that if a member makes imputations, if he makes allegations, if he wishes to say something that is open to debate, he does so by substantive motion. I refer the honourable member to the standing order concerned-it is standing order 76. Standing Order 76 reads:

INTERJECT.PARA: All imputations of improper motives and all personal reflections on Members shall be considered highly disorderly.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not as yet made any allegations, nor have I had an opportunity as yet-an opportunity I should have as a private member in the adjournment debate-to ask the questions, which I do intend asking.
—I am warning the honourable member that he should be aware--

—In that case I shall proceed. I shall be quite happy to proceed, Mr Deputy Speaker. My first question is: On how many occasions has the Treasurer utilised for free helicopters provided by Mr Warren Anderson or any company in which Mr Warren Anderson is a shareholder and/or director?

—Order! The honourable member for Flinders is aware that one cannot use the form of questions as a method of imputation against a member. If one wishes to canvass issues such as that, one should do it by substantive motion. The Chair would be quite happy at the appropriate time to entertain a substantive motion.

—If you are ruling, Mr Deputy Speaker, that there was an imputation in my first question, I invite you to make a similar ruling in regard to my second question, which is: Has the Treasurer ever sold any property to Mr Warren Anderson?
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to refer to a recent media release by Senator Michael Baume who often comes into the Eden-Monaro electorate for five minutes or speaks from afar, pontificating about local issues with little regard to local knowledge. He also pontificates about national issues with little regard to accuracy. In a recent media statement Senator Baume said that Australia's pensioners were being forced into paying for a number of commonly used drugs from 1 November. These drugs had previously been available free under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. I would point out that this is a gross inaccuracy. In fact, it is not the Government which has removed certain items from the pharmaceutical benefits scheme; it was the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) acting on the advice of the Pharmaceutical Advisory Committee which consists of medical practitioners and pharmacists who are specially appointed to look at the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. Senator Michael Baume went on to say that the Government had tried to sneak the changes in by stealth, by advising pharmacists that a number of analgesics and other products had been deleted from the pensioner list. First of all, I would point out that the reference was to the Minister from the Committee-a committee of doctors and pharmacists-who told him that these items were not essential.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Eden-Monaro is trying to make a point. Honourable members on my left might listen to him carefully.

—I point out to honourable members opposite that pharmacists and doctors made this recommendation. They recommended that there were other items which were more important and which should come under the scheme. These items were more expensive and therefore it was more important that they should be available to pensioners. Senator Baume also made the point that an item prescribed for angina-glyceryl trinitrate-had been deleted from the pensioner list. There was only one particular product in that range of items that had been deleted from the list-it was a patch containing the glyceryl trinitrate medication which is far less effective than the oral dose. In fact, the longer it is used the less effective it becomes.

SPEECH.PARA: I stress the point that the recommendations of the Advisory Committee were based on medical, not financial grounds. The Committee meets three times a year and recommends both additions to and deletions from the scheme. The specific meeting that recommended the deletions also recommended that 19 new drugs be added to the PBS list. I wish to make another point about the actual cost to the Government of providing some of these non essential drugs through the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. It is far more than the cost of producing the drugs. A well known item is paracetamol and one of the over-the-counter lines of that product is Panadol. Paracetamol is available over the counter at a cost between $2 and $3 from any chemist. Under the national health scheme the taxpayers of Australia have been required to pay $17 for this item which is available at between $2 and $3 over the counter in the family chemist shop. This $17 is made up of $13.30 for Medicare benefits for a normal consultation, $1.66 for the cost of the drug and $2.40 for the dispensing fee. That totals $17.36 to be exact. I am sure honourable members would agree that it was in the interests of taxpayers that non essential items like this should be removed and replaced by more expensive items. I also point out that Senator Michael Baume's aspersions against Medicare are grossly untrue. Total health costs in Australia are two per cent less than total health costs in the United States.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable members time has expired. I call the honourable member for Dunkley.

INTERJECT.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker: Would you inform the House why you have chosen two members from the Government side in succession?

—I would have thought that the honourable member for Warringah, having been in this House even longer than I, would be aware of standing order 91. That standing order allows me to call the honourable member for Dunkley.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I am very pleased to rise to--
—You cannot ignore this point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. We are worried that this is a factional coverup--
—The honourable member will resume his seat.
—On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker--
—They are taking up my time, Mr Deputy Speaker. This is just filibustering.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, as I understand it the practice in this chamber has been, for as long as I can remember--
—There is no point of order.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, you know very well that you must hear the point of order. In the years I have been here the practice as I understand it is that you will call a speaker from one side of the House alternately with one from the other. As I understand it, the honourable member of Flinders was on his feet and seeking the call--
—There is no point of order.
—But I have not finished making my point of order. You have a duty to this House to wait until I have finished.
—The honourable member for Curtin is a Deputy Chairman of Committees in this House. He knows about standing order 91. I suggest that he read it, and I now call the honourable member for Dunkley.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, you can see by what has happened here tonight-

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I draw your attention to standing order 91. There is no requirement under that standing order for you to call members alternately, but there is a practice in the House that you do so.
—I draw the honourable member's attention to the standing order. He should read it, then he would realise.
—I have read it, Mr Deputy Speaker. There is no requirement to call members alternately, but the-

—Order! The problem that the Chair has is that I have drawn the attention of members of the Opposition to the standing order's provisions. The Opposition member who sought to rise was the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) who had already spoken in the debate. Standing order 91 provides that if no other member rises then a member who has already spoken can rise again. I call the honourable member for Dunkley.

—Thank you Mr Deputy Speaker. Opposition members have been at a party and they have been drowning their sorrows. Now they come in here and they just do not know what they are doing. They have had to put up with a speech from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) which was pure rubbish, so I do not blame them for being upset and for forgetting exactly what the Standing Orders are in this place.

—I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. In arriving at a decision you impugned upon me a certain knowledge as a result of the fact that I am a Deputy Chairman of Committees in this Parliament. I resent your imputation that somehow I should have a superior sort of knowledge than that which stands in the conventions of the conduct of this place. I say to you, Sir, that you are quite wrong. How is the clock going? Is this bloke's time nearly finished? I will sit down any time you like as long as the honourable member for Flinders gets the call the next time.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.
